history: A 65-year-old woman with no relevant medical or surgical history presented to the orthopedic clinic with a 3-week history of a painful mass in her right arm that manifested 1 week after trauma. Physical examination revealed a firm palpable mass in the right biceps muscle, without overlying skin changes. She was afebrile. Laboratory studies did not reveal any abnormalities. Conventional radiography (images not shown) depicted a soft-tissue mass, without any soft-tissue calcification or skeletal abnormality. Magnetic resonance (MR) imaging was performed (,Figs 1,,,–,4).
findings: MR imaging of the right upper extremity revealed a well-defined soft-tissue mass (7.0 × 3.5 × 3.0 cm) in the belly of the right biceps muscle. The lesion had high signal intensity on fat-saturated T2-weighted spin-echo sagittal (,Fig 1a) and coronal (,Fig 1b) MR images, had moderately high signal intensity on a transverse T2-weighted gradient-echo MR image (,Fig 2), and was isointense compared with the signal intensity of skeletal muscle on a T1-weighted sagittal spin-echo MR image (,Fig 3). Imaging performed after intravenous administration of gadopentetate dimeglumine (Magnevist; Schering, Berlin, Germany) revealed almost homogeneous enhancement of the mass (,Fig 4). The T2-weighted and contrast-enhanced MR images also demonstrated continuous muscle fibers without disruption in the lesion. There was no infiltration of soft tissues surrounding the involved muscle on any images. The osseous structures demonstrated normal morphologic and signal intensity characteristics with all imaging sequences.

There are no important blood- or calcification-related signals.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2442041504/asset/images/large/r07au43g03x.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 3: Sagittal T1-weighted spin-echo MR image of the right arm (600/15) shows an isointense homogeneous intramuscular mass (arrows).'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2442041504/asset/images/large/r07au43g04x.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 4: Contrast material–enhanced sagittal T1-weighted spin-echo MR image of the right arm (600/15) shows a soft-tissue mass (arrows) with almost homogeneous enhancement preserving the muscle fibers without disruption.'}]]

history: A 17-year-old boy was referred to our institution for cardiovascular analysis and therapy. He had no symptoms besides dyspnea on exertion. Auscultation revealed a cardiac murmur. His medical history included a prior episode of endocarditis involving the pulmonary valve after tooth extraction. This was successfully treated with antibiotics.
findings: MR imaging included T1-weighted black-blood sequences in various directions and cine imaging of the right ventricular outflow tract with balanced fast field-echo sequences. The coronal T1-weighted black-blood sequence revealed marked hypertrophy of the right ventricle wall (,Fig 1). The T1-weighted black-blood image of the right ventricular outflow tract showed thickened muscular bands between the thin-walled infundibulum and the inflow segment of the right ventricle. These bands reached inward from the interventricular septum and the anterior free wall and divided the right ventricle into two chambers. The muscular bands created a marked stenosis between the chambers (,Fig 2). The muscular bands were also seen on coronal images. The stenosis resulted in a jet phenomenon seen on the balanced fast field-echo right ventricular outflow tract image (,Fig 3) because a steep pressure gradient between the inflow tract and the infundibular segment of the right ventricle caused high-velocity blood to enter slower flowing blood in the infundibulum. Although the jet phenomenon was visible on an MR image, it was best appreciated with cine imaging (Movie, http://radiology.rsnajnls.org/cgi/content/full/244/4/617/DC1).

The pulmonary valve (short arrow) is also visible.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2442041242/asset/images/large/r07au44g03x.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 3: Sagittal balanced fast field-echo MR image of the right ventricular outflow tract of the heart (4.0/2.0; flip angle, 50°) shows jet phenomenon (arrows) due to the pressure gradient distal to the stenosis.'}]]

history: A 75-year-old woman presented to the emergency department and reported new onset of diffuse abdominal cramps, nausea, fever, and chills. The patient had an extensive history of cardiac procedures, including placement of an aortic valve prosthesis and cardiac catheterization performed 10 days prior to the current admission. Her medical history was also notable for long-standing celiac sprue and acute appendicitis at age 13 that was treated with appendectomy. The patient denied recent foreign travel. Physical examination revealed mild right lower quadrant tenderness without signs of peritonitis and a fever of 100.4°F (38.0°C). White blood cell count, including absolute neutrophil count, was normal. Computed tomographic (CT) examination of the abdomen and pelvis was performed with only intravenous contrast material (100 mL of iohexol, Omnipaque 300; Amersham Health, Princeton, NJ) on day 1 (,Fig 1,,) and with both oral (15 g of diatrizoate sodium in 24 oz of water; Hypaque Sodium, Amersham Health) and intravenous contrast material on day 2 (,Fig 2,).
findings: The CT scout view of the abdomen revealed gas-filled small-bowel loops displaced from the right lower quadrant, sternotomy wires, and an aortic valve prosthesis (,Fig 1a). A cecal “target sign” enhancement pattern, which indicated submucosal edema (,Fig 1b), was evident. The remainder of the bowel appeared normal, without evidence of obstruction or pneumoperitoneum. A small amount of free fluid was present in the pelvis, and there was a small unenhanced fluid collection adjacent to the right common femoral artery (,Figs 1c, ,,2b). CT was performed with oral and intravenous contrast material the day after admission and again revealed persistent pelvic ascites and a markedly thickened cecum (,Fig 2a) that displaced normal small-bowel loops from the right lower quadrant of the abdomen (,Fig 2b).
diagnosis: Ischemic Colitis Limited to the Cecum1

history: A 41-year-old African-American woman with a medical history of poorly controlled hypertension was found unresponsive. She was intubated by paramedics in the field. When she arrived at the emergency department, neurologic examination revealed obtunded mental status with right-sided hemiparesis and diminished peripheral reflexes. Vital signs were remarkable for a blood pressure of 220/170 mm Hg. An unenhanced computed tomographic (CT) scan of the head (,Fig 1) was obtained, and the patient was admitted to the neurosurgical intensive care unit for further observation. Routine chest radiography performed at admission revealed symmetric but abnormal widening of the superior mediastinum. This finding led us to obtain contrast material–enhanced CT scans of the chest and upper abdomen (,Figs 2,, ,3,) after intravenous administration of 140 mL of iopromide (Ultravist; Berlex Laboratories, Wayne, NJ). Several years later, this patient's older sister presented with worsening uncontrolled blood pressure. Diagnostic work-up, including intravenous contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen, was performed in the patient's sister (,Fig 4).
findings: Unenhanced CT of the head revealed an acute large left basal ganglia and frontal lobe intracerebral hemorrhage with mass effect, left-to-right midline shift, subfalcine herniation, and intraventricular extension into the left lateral ventricle (,Fig 1). Admission chest radiography revealed symmetric but abnormal superior mediastinal widening. This finding was confirmed with subsequent contrast-enhanced chest CT (,Fig 2,), which revealed diffuse fatty infiltration of the mediastinum. This finding was consistent with mediastinal lipomatosis. The upper abdominal portion of this examination revealed incidental findings of bilateral soft-tissue masses in the expected location of the adrenal glands (,Fig 3,). Several years later, contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen was ordered as part of the patient's sister's directed work-up for worsening uncontrolled hypertension. This examination revealed similar, albeit more dramatic, findings of large bilateral macronodular soft-tissue adrenal masses (,Fig 4).
diagnosis: Familial Adrenocorticotropin-independent Macronodular Adrenal Hyperplasia Causing Cushing Syndrome1

history: A 28-year-old woman presented with increasing pain and swelling of 2 months duration in her medial right forefoot. The patient was in good health and had an unremarkable medical history. At physical examination, she did not appear to be in acute distress, and she was afebrile. Evaluation of the right foot was notable for mild diffuse erythema over the medial aspect of the dorsum of the forefoot, with maximal tenderness noted over the second metatarsal. Radiography was performed in the right foot (,Fig 1) and revealed an abnormality that prompted further evaluation with magnetic resonance (MR) imaging (,Fig 2,,). The results of laboratory blood tests, which included white blood cell count, were normal.
findings: Radiography of the foot (,Fig 1) revealed nearly complete destruction of the entire second metatarsal by a uniformly radiolucent and expansile process that did not involve any adjacent osseous structures. MR imaging (,Fig 2,,) demonstrated a solitary solid enhancing tumor that caused almost complete destruction of the second metatarsal, with expansion of the residual osseous margin.
diagnosis: Giant Cell Tumor of the Second Metatarsal1

history: Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen was performed to evaluate the liver in a 19-year-old woman who had undergone treatment for β-thalassemia intermedia. CT revealed findings that prompted further investigation with cardiovascular magnetic resonance (MR) imaging. MR imaging was performed with a 1.5-T system (Signa Cvi; GE Medical Systems, Milwaukee, Wis). Selected CT and MR images are shown (,Figs 1,–,3) on the next page.
findings: CT of the abdomen revealed increased attenuation in the liver and spleen and normal attenuation in the pancreas (,Fig 1). These findings indicated secondary hemochromatosis; iron overload in the liver and spleen and sparing of the pancreas are characteristic imaging findings of secondary hemochromatosis caused by reticuloendothelial deposition of iron in this patient with known thalassemia intermedia. Iron reduces the relaxation rates of T1- and T2-weighted sequences by introducing local magnetic field inhomogeneities (,1,,2). A coronal localizer image obtained with fast imaging employing steady-state acquisition (FIESTA; GE Medical Systems) (,Fig 2) showed low signal intensity in the liver, spleen, and vertebral body marrow resulting from iron deposition.
images: [[{'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2433040851/asset/images/large/r07jn33g01x.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 1: Unenhanced transverse CT scan of the abdomen (120 kV, 240 mA, 5-mm-thick section, 1.3 pitch, 512 × 512 matrix).'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2433040851/asset/images/large/r07jn33g02x.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 2: Coronal fast imaging employing steady-state acquisition (FIESTA; GE Medical Systems) localizer MR image of the chest and upper abdomen obtained with a torso coil (repetition time msec/echo time msec, 760/20; 5-mm-thick section with 1-mm skip interval; 256 × 192 matrix; 32 × 32-cm displayed field of view).'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2433040851/asset/images/large/r07jn33g03x.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 3: Short-axis oblique T2-weighted MR image obtained through the left ventricular myocardium and the trapezius.'}], [{'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2451040867/asset/images/large/r07oc50g01x.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 1: Selected unenhanced transverse CT scan of the abdomen (120 kV, 240 mA, 5-mm-thick section, 1.3 pitch, 512 × 512 matrix) demonstrates abnormally increased attenuation of the liver (L) and spleen (S) in contrast to the attenuation of the head of the pancreas (arrow), which is normal, and hyperattenuating lymph nodes immediately anterior to the inferior vena cava. These findings indicate iron overload in the reticuloendothelial system consistent with secondary hemochromatosis in a patient undergoing multiple red blood cell transfusions to treat thalassemia intermedia.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2451040867/asset/images/large/r07oc50g02x.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 2: Coronal fast imaging employing steady-state acquisition localizer MR image of the chest and upper abdomen obtained with a torso coil (repetition time msec/echo time msec, 760/20; 5-mm-thick section with 1-mm skip interval; 256 × 192 matrix; 32 × 32-cm displayed field of view). There is profound hypointensity of the liver (L), spleen (S), and vertebral bone marrow. These findings are consistent with a diagnosis of iron overload.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2451040867/asset/images/large/r07oc50g03x.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 3: Short-axis oblique T2-weighted MR image obtained through the left ventricular myocardium and the trapezius with a torso coil (3038/20, 7.0-mm section thickness, 3.0-mm spacing, 256 × 128 matrix). Normally, the myocardium demonstrates the same signal intensity as other skeletal muscles of the body. In this case, the myocardium demonstrates a substantial decrease in signal intensity compared with the skeletal muscle. This finding is in keeping with myocardial hemosiderosis in a patient with thalassemia treated with multiple red blood cell transfusions.'}]]

history: A 53-year-old Puerto Rican man presented with long-standing and gradually increasing dyspnea. He also reported occasional abdominal pain, easy bruising, and occasional epistaxis. The patient denied smoking. He stated that his sister had died of pulmonary fibrosis many years earlier.
findings: Posteroanterior chest radiography was performed at admission (,Fig 1) and revealed diffuse bilateral reticular abnormalities that involved mostly the periphery of the lungs, with lower lobe predominance. The diaphragm was elevated, suggesting volume loss in the lungs. High-spatial-resolution CT of the chest was performed subsequently and revealed diffuse subpleural blebs that were relatively large in the upper lobes (,Fig 2a) and gradually decreased in size from the middle of the thorax (,Fig 2b) to the lung bases (,Fig 2c). There was a generalized ground-glass appearance of the lungs, as evidenced by the black bronchus sign, which was described as “increased conspicuity of the bronchi within a ground-glass opacity” (,1) (,Fig 2b), and by traction bronchiectasis (,2), indicating the presence of diffuse fibrosis (,Fig 2c).

history: A 15-year-old boy was admitted to our hospital with acute weakness in the left upper and lower extremities. He was febrile (39.1°C) and somnolent. Two hours prior to arrival, a migraine attack with visual aura began. The patient had experienced a transient attack of right upper and lower extremity weakness 6 years earlier.
findings: T2-weighted images showed diffuse cortical swelling and mild cortical hyperintensity of the right hemisphere. These findings were most likely caused by cortical edema (,Fig 1,). Diffusion-weighted images (,Fig 2) and MR angiograms (,Fig 3) were normal.

history: A 63-year-old man was admitted with a history of gradually increasing abdominal pain of 3 days duration. At admission, the pain was mostly localized to the right upper quadrant. The patient had a slightly elevated white blood cell count (10 × 109/L). The clinical impression of acute cholecystitis was confirmed with ultrasonography and computed tomography (CT). Several gallstones were also depicted, and cholecystectomy was performed. Chest CT studies were obtained postoperatively to evaluate an abnormality seen on the admission chest radiograph (,Figs 1, ,2,).
findings: The posteroanterior chest radiograph obtained at admission (,Fig 1) showed a smoothly outlined mass posterior to the heart on the left side of the body. There was also the hint of a retrocardiac opacity on the right side. The heart was moderately enlarged. Contrast material–enhanced CT of the chest was performed after cholecystectomy and revealed inhomogeneously enhancing bilateral paraspinal masses in the lower half of the thorax (,Fig 2,). Air was visible in the biliary tree on a lower section obtained through the midportion of the liver. There were surgical clips in the left upper quadrant of the abdomen and the spleen was absent, indicating previous splenectomy.

history: A 37-year-old man presented to his physician with sharp and continuous upper abdominal pain. Upper endoscopy was performed for evaluation and revealed Helicobacter pylori–negative gastritis. Treatment with a proton pump inhibitor failed to alleviate his symptoms. The patient subsequently developed diarrhea and dark stools, followed by a petechial rash that involved his lower extremities. At this point, he was admitted to an outside hospital for evaluation. Colonoscopy and repeat endoscopy revealed nothing that could account for his symptoms. After an observation period, he was discharged.
findings: Contrast-enhanced multidetector CT revealed several key findings. A long segment (estimated to be 25–30 cm) of proximal jejunal thickening was identified (,Fig 1,,,,). The affected segment had mucosal enhancement and low attenuation in the submucosa owing to edema. A second thickened small-bowel segment was seen in the distal ileum (,Fig 2), but the terminal ileum was normal (,Fig 1). In addition, mesenteric edema and adenopathy were present (,Fig 1). Minimal ascites (not shown) was identified in the pelvis. The mesenteric arteries and veins were well opacified and patent (,Fig 1). No infarcts were seen in the kidneys or spleen.

history: A 33-year-old nulliparous woman presented with pressure in the left abdomen of several weeks duration. Her medical history was remarkable for multiple resections of basal cell carcinomas. Pelvic sonography (,Figs 1,, 2) was performed and was followed by contrast material–enhanced (140 mL of ioversol [Optiray 320; Mallinckrodt, St Louis, Mo] and 500 mL of diatrizoate sodium [Hypaque; GE Healthcare, Princeton, NJ]) computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis (,Figs 3,, 4).
findings: Initial transvaginal sonography revealed a normal uterus, a small amount of free fluid in the cul-de-sac (,Fig 1), and a large, heterogeneous solid right adnexal mass containing hyperechoic areas with posterior acoustic shadowing consistent with calcification (,Fig 2). CT was performed to enable further characterization of the adnexa and revealed bilateral grossly calcified adnexal masses (,Fig 3) and a normal-appearing uterus deviated to the left (,Fig 4). The larger mass was located in the midline and measured 11.5 × 8.5 cm. A 4.5 × 2.5-cm left adnexal mass was also seen.
diagnosis: Bilateral Ovarian Fibromas in Nevoid Basal Cell Carcinoma Syndrome1

history: A 68-year-old man presented with fever of unknown origin, generalized weakness, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. His symptoms had progressed for several weeks prior to admission. Initially, he experienced weight loss. This was followed by lower extremity edema that progressed to anasarca. The results of a comprehensive work-up for infection were negative and included negative blood and stool cultures and negative human immunodeficiency virus and Lyme disease test results. Results of transesophageal echocardiagraphy were negative for vegetations, and work-up was negative for hepatitis. Laboratory findings included a white blood cell count of 20 × 109/L (normal level, [4 to 10] × 109/L) and an albumin level of 1.2 g/dL (normal level, 3.2–5.2 g/dL). Liver function test results were normal. Antinuclear antibody test results were positive. This patient's erythrocyte sedimentation rate was 42 mm/h (normal level, 0–20 mm/h), and his C-reactive protein level reportedly was elevated when he had visited another hospital. Biopsy of the temporal artery was performed. Although the biopsy findings were difficult to interpret, the pathologist believed that severe giant cell temporal arteritis was the most appropriate diagnosis. Computed tomographic (CT) images of the sinuses and chest were normal, with the exception of bilateral pleural effusions. CT of the abdomen and pelvis was then performed to evaluate chronic abdominal pain and weight loss (,Fig 1,,,). This examination was followed by arteriography (,Fig 2).
findings: CT (,Fig 1,,,) revealed pneumatosis intestinalis of the small bowel. Gas (likely portal venous gas) was seen within mesenteric vessels on multiple CT sections. In addition, there were air-fluid levels within the small bowel and small-bowel distention. Vasculature in the mesentery was dilated. Small nonspecific low-attenuating lesions were seen within both kidneys (,Fig 1d). The frontal arteriogram of the superior mesenteric artery (,Fig 2) showed multiple numerous small aneurysms.

history: A 37-year-old healthy woman who did not smoke underwent computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance (MR) imaging of the abdomen for further work-up of a hepatic lesion that was incidentally detected at ultrasonography (US) and was thought to be an atypical liver hemangioma. US was performed to assess mild abdominal discomfort. The patient's medical history was unremarkable. The liver lesion had characteristics of a proteinaceous cyst on CT and MR images; however, upper sections of abdominal CT scans revealed a mass in the right cardiophrenic angle. Thus, CT and MR images of the chest were obtained (,Figs 1,,,,,–,7).
findings: The scout radiograph (,Fig 1) showed a smoothly marginated 10-cm-diameter mass in the area of the right cardiophrenic angle that obscured the cardiac border. This mass had a broad base at the mediastinum and formed an obtuse angle superiorly in keeping with a mediastinal location. Careful inspection revealed punctate calcific opacities within the mass. This finding was confirmed with transverse unenhanced CT (,Fig 2). A calcification showed central lucency and had a ringlike appearance. The mediastinal mass demonstrated heterogeneity and consisted of soft-tissue and fat attenuation with multiple scattered calcifications. When 150 mL of iohexol (Omnipaque 240; Winthrop-Breon Laboratories, New York, NY) was administered, nodular and tubular enhancing structures were identified, with a degree of enhancement comparable to that of the adjacent inferior vena cava (,Fig 3).

There is no evidence of pericardial invasion or effusion.'}]]

history: A 21-year-old woman was referred for cerebral and craniofacial magnetic resonance (MR) imaging and computed tomographic (CT) examination (,Figs 1,,,,–,4) because of the asymmetric appearance of the right side of her face and the consideration of facial paralysis. Neurologic examination revealed that the patient did not have facial nerve palsy and that her appearance was caused by facial asymmetry. Laboratory studies revealed no abnormality. There was no family history of congenital anomaly. Physical examination revealed an asymmetric soft-tissue prominence on the posterior part of her chest and abdomen. There was a history of a progressive course of asymmetry of the hands and feet and a hyperpigmented epidermal nevus on the left dorsal aspect of the trunk. (Asymmetric overgrowth of the patient's hands and feet was stabilized after puberty.) Radiographs of the pelvis, vertebrae, and extremities (not shown) were normal except for mild scoliosis. Unenhanced CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis was performed (,Figs 5,,6).
findings: MR imaging of the brain revealed enlargement of the right cerebral hemisphere, mainly in the frontal lobe, that was caused by hypertrophied white matter. The cortex of the right cerebral hemisphere was dysplastic, with broad and shallow gyri and diminished sulci. The deep and subcortical areas of the underlying white matter had multiple scattered lesions that appeared as low-signal-intensity areas on T1-weighted MR images and as high-signal-intensity areas on T2-weighted and fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) MR images. The ipsilateral ventricle was also enlarged and distorted (,Fig 1,,).

history: A 37-year-old healthy female nonsmoker presented with hemoptysis. Her medical history was remarkable for sickle cell trait and iron deficiency anemia. She had not traveled outside North America. Computed tomography (CT) (,Figs 1,,–,4) and magnetic resonance (MR) imaging (,Fig 5) were performed in the chest and abdomen.
findings: Contrast material–enhanced CT revealed a mass that was located predominantly in the right lower hemithorax but extended across the midline to the opposite side of the body, consistent with a mediastinal location (,Fig 1). This low-attenuation lesion was seen in the middle and posterior portions of the mediastinum and showed no discernible wall or central enhancement from intravenous contrast material. There was some contrast-enhanced compressed lung tissue adjacent to the lesion. The mass enveloped the right inferior pulmonary vein without displacing, narrowing, or deforming it, and thus was suggestive of a soft pliable nature (,Fig 2). Another discrete nonenhancing low-attenuation lesion was noted in a right paratracheal location (,Fig 3). A small right pleural effusion was seen (,Fig 3), and multiple cystic lesions were identified in the spleen (,Fig 4).

history: A 31-year-old otherwise healthy woman presented with frequent unilateral headaches that lasted from a few hours to a few days and occurred as often as three or four times per week. Symptoms started at the time of her first pregnancy 3 years earlier and persisted without any progression in intensity or frequency. Physical examination findings were normal, and there were no neurologic deficits. Magnetic resonance (MR) images of the brain (,Fig 1,,) and unenhanced computed tomographic (CT) scans of the head (,Fig 2,,) were obtained.
findings: An oval lesion was seen to the left of the basilar artery in the retroclival prepontine location on the MR images (,Fig 1,,). The lesion was minimally hyperintense to CSF on the T1-weighted image, more homogeneously hyperintense than CSF on the T2-weighted image (,Fig 1b), and showed no enhancement after contrast material administration (,Fig 1c). On the T2-weighted image, the homogeneously hyperintense signal intensity may have been due to less pulsation artifact in the lesion than in the surrounding prepontine CSF. The lesion was subtle on the unenhanced CT scans and was seen as a low-attenuation structure not clearly separable from the prepontine cistern (,Fig 2,,). An osseous stalk arising from the clivus was well appreciated on transverse CT scans obtained with soft-tissue and bone window settings (,Fig 2).

history: A 32-year-old man was admitted to the hospital with headache, vomiting, and complex partial seizures. Thirty weeks earlier, he had undergone ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt placement to treat hydrocephalus that had been diagnosed with cranial magnetic resonance (MR) imaging. Hydrocephalus was the only abnormality present. During the 30-week interval, two consecutive whole-spine MR examinations were performed 8 weeks apart at different institutions (,Figs 1,, ,2,,). Neurologic examination revealed mild decreased consciousness, papilledema, and deficits in cranial nerves III, IV, V, and VII. The patient was afebrile, and physical examination revealed no other abnormalities. The findings of laboratory tests, including extensive cerebrospinal fluid studies, were unremarkable. Cranial computed tomography (CT) was performed (,Fig 3,).
findings: Cranial MR imaging performed 30 weeks before this patient was admitted to the hospital revealed hydrocephalus, with dilatation of the third and lateral ventricles. The brain, upper cervical spinal cord, and subarachnoid space were otherwise normal. MR imaging of the whole spine performed 12 weeks after placement of the VP shunt revealed diffuse irregular involvement along the surfaces of the lower brainstem and the spinal cord that obscured the subarachnoid space. The involvement showed punctuate hyperintensities on an unenhanced sagittal T1-weighted fast spin-echo MR image (,Fig 1a) and diffuse irregular and intense subarachnoid enhancement on a contrast-enhanced sagittal T1-weighted fast spin-echo MR image (,Fig 1b). There were also serpiginous low-signal-intensity areas along the dorsal surface of the spinal cord that were caused by enlargement of the dorsal venous plexus.

In a, punctuate irregular hyperintensities (black arrows) along the surfaces of the lower brainstem and the cervical and upper thoracic spinal cord can be seen. There are also serpiginous low-signal-intensity areas along the dorsal surface of the spinal cord that represent enlargement of the dorsal venous plexus (white arrows). In b, diffuse irregular and intense enhancement (arrowheads) of the subarachnoid space along the surfaces of the lower brainstem and the cervical and upper thoracic spinal cord can be seen. The unenhanced hypointense areas along the dorsal surface of the spinal cord within the dorsal area of the diffuse surface enhancement represent enlargement of the dorsal venous plexus (arrows).'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2473050507/asset/images/large/r08jn46g02a.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 2a: (a, b) Midline sagittal (a) unenhanced and (b) contrast-enhanced T1-weighted fast spin-echo MR images (566/10) of the cervical spine obtained 20 weeks after VP shunt placement. The serpiginous low-signal-intensity areas along the dorsal surface of the spinal cord that represent enlargement of the dorsal venous plexus (arrowheads) show progression. In b, progression of the diffuse irregular and intense enhancement of the subarachnoid space with superficial spinal cord invasion (arrows) is visible. The unenhanced hypointense areas caused by venous engorgement (arrowheads) along the dorsal surface of the spinal cord show progression. history: An 82-year-old woman presented with a history of coronary artery disease and lower abdominal pain of 3 months duration. Computed tomography (CT) was used to examine the abdomen and pelvis (,Figure,).
findings: Two axial CT images (,Fig 1,) showed a 4.5 × 3.5-cm well-defined heterogeneous presacral mass that was in direct contiguity with the sacrum but did not invade it. The mass was predominately composed of soft tissue, but macroscopic fat was present within it.

The mass is predominately composed of soft tissue; however, macroscopic fat (arrows) is present within it.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2481050321/asset/images/large/r08jl43g02a.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 2a: MR images obtained in a 63-year-old woman with a presacral myelolipoma. The portion of the mass that is hyperintense (arrow) could be secondary to blood products or fat. (b) Axial fat-suppressed gadolinium-enhanced (0.1 mmol/kg gadopentetate dimeglumine, Magnevist; Bayer Healthcare, Wayne, NJ) T1-weighted image (4.6/1.4; flip angle, 12°) shows that the portion of the mass that was hyperintense in a is now hypointense. This finding is diagnostic of macroscopic fat. This finding is diagnostic of macroscopic fat. The mass was resected, and presacral myelolipoma was diagnosed.'}]]

history: A 57-year-old man presented with a 3-month history of abdominal pain. Physical examination revealed a large firm palpable mass in the epigastric region. There was no history of alcoholism, trauma, or previous pancreatitis. Laboratory findings were unremarkable. The patient underwent abdominal upright radiography, upper gastrointestinal barium examination, abdominal ultrasonography (US) (,Fig 1), and abdominal computed tomography (CT) (,Fig 2,,,).
findings: US (,Fig 1) revealed a heterogeneous complex mass that contained cystic and solid areas in the epigastric area. CT revealed an 11.6 × 11.5-cm well-circumscribed mass (,Fig 2a,,,) that was localized to the uncinate process of the pancreas and displaced but did not invade the adjacent viscera, namely, the right kidney. After intravenous injection of contrast media (,Figs 2b–2d), heterogeneous enhancement of the mass was seen. This enhancement revealed a peripheral enhancing thick rim that surrounded a central nonenhancing low-attenuation area. At a slightly higher level, the main pancreatic duct was markedly dilated distally (,Fig 2b) and displayed discrete intraluminal solid enhancing nodules (,Fig 2c). The adjacent pancreatic tissue appeared slightly atrophic (,Fig 2b). There was no intra- or extrahepatic bile duct dilatation, nor were there any extrapancreatic signs of malignancy. No abnormalities were seen in the rest of the abdomen. Surgery was performed with a Whipple procedure. Pathologic examination of the surgical specimen revealed a yellowish solid tumor (,Fig 3). Histologic analysis revealed the papillary component of this huge intraductal papillary mucinous tumor (IPMT) of the pancreas.
diagnosis: Intraductal Papillary Mucinous Tumor (Main Duct Type) of the Pancreas1

history: A 3-year 7-month-old boy presented to the emergency department with a 12-day history of cough and fever. Laboratory tests revealed mild anemia, monocytosis, and neutrophilia with a left shift. Both the platelet count and the C-reactive protein level were increased. A chest radiograph (,Fig 1) was obtained. This patient was discharged after 5 days of treatment with oral antibiotics. Two weeks later, recurrence of the symptoms prompted readmission. Laboratory findings were unchanged. Imaging evaluation consisted of chest radiography (,Fig 2), ultrasonography (US) (,Fig 3), and computed tomography (CT) (,Fig 4,,).
findings: Anteroposterior chest radiography was performed at first admission (,Fig 1) and showed opacification of the right lower zone of the chest with air bronchograms and loss of clarity in both the right hemidiaphragm and the inferior aspect of the right heart border. There was depression of the minor fissure and multiple lobulated branching air spaces, in keeping with a diagnosis of air bronchograms in dilated bronchi.
diagnosis: Pneumonia and Bronchiectasis Secondary to Unrecognized Peanut Impaction1

history: A 66-year-old woman presented with numbness in the anteromedial aspect of her right thigh and difficulty with right leg movement for the past year. She did not have back pain or lower limb pain, nor did she have a history of relevant trauma. At the time of presentation, her arterial hypertension and osteoarthritis were being treated. She had a history of localized laryngeal amyloidosis, which was found at 30 years of age and treated with laser excision and tracheostomy. Physical examination revealed mild spasticity and impaired pain and temperature sensation in the right leg. She underwent magnetic resonance (MR) imaging (,Figs 1,–,3), myelography, and postmyelography computed tomography (CT) (,Figs 4, ,5) of the thoracic spine.
findings: MR examination of the thoracic spine revealed anterior displacement of the spinal cord and slight reduction in its anteroposterior diameter at the level of the T5-6 disk. A small part of the spinal cord was seen herniating into the disk space (,Figs 1,–,3). There was an associated widening of the posterior subarachnoid space at this level. On the basis of the MR findings, a diagnosis of transdural idiopathic spinal cord herniation was entertained. This diagnosis was subsequently confirmed with myelography and postmyelography CT. During myelography, the contrast material column posterior to the spinal cord flowed superiorly without a myelographic block. On the lateral thoracic myelogram, a focal discontinuity of the anterior subarachnoid space was noted at the T5-6 disk level. The herniated spinal cord segment could be seen clearly on the axial CT image acquired after myelography (,Fig 4). Sagittal reformations also showed the remodeling of endplates of the T5 and T6 vertebrae (,Fig 5). There was no filling defect or loculation in the subarachnoid space at the level of spinal cord herniation. This finding was helpful in excluding a diagnosis of arachnoid cyst or arachnoiditis.
images: [[{'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2473020675/asset/images/large/r08jn26g01x.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 1: Sagittal T1-weighted MR image (repetition time msec/echo time msec, 700/13; two signals acquired) of the thoracic spine.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2473020675/asset/images/large/r08jn26g02x.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 2: Sagittal T2-weighted MR image (3400/102, one signal acquired) of the thoracic spine.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2473020675/asset/images/large/r08jn26g03x.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 3: Axial gradient-echo T2*-weighted MR image (716/18, one signal acquired) at the level of the T5-6 intervertebral space.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2473020675/asset/images/large/r08jn26g04x.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 4: Axial postmyelography CT image at the T5-6 level.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2473020675/asset/images/large/r08jn26g05x.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 5: Sagittal postmyelography CT reformation of the midthoracic spine.'}], [{'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2491020676/asset/images/large/r08oc36g01x.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 1: Sagittal T1-weighted MR image (repetition time msec/echo time msec, 700/13; two signals acquired) of the thoracic spine reveals a small amount of spinal cord substance (arrow) in the extradural space at the level of the T5-6 disk, with anterior extension into the intervertebral space.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2491020676/asset/images/large/r08oc36g02x.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 2: Sagittal T2-weighted MR image (3400/102, one signal acquired) of the thoracic spine shows the signal intensity of the herniated spinal cord segment parallels that of the thoracic spinal cord. Note the enlarged cerebrospinal fluid space posterior to the spinal cord at the level of herniation.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2491020676/asset/images/large/r08oc36g03x.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 3: Axial gradient-echo T2*-weighted MR image (716/18, one signal acquired) obtained at the level of the T5-6 intervertebral space shows transdural ventral herniation of the spinal cord.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2491020676/asset/images/large/r08oc36g04x.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 4: Axial postmyelography CT image through the level of spinal cord herniation (T5-6 disk level) shows a continuous column of contrast material posterior to the spinal cord. There is no filling defect to suggest a mass lesion, such as an arachnoid cyst.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2491020676/asset/images/large/r08oc36g05x.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 5: Sagittal postmyelography CT reformation of the midthoracic spine shows the herniation clearly and provides bone detail. Remodeling of endplates (arrows) at the posterior margin of the T5-6 disk can be seen on this image.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2491020676/asset/images/large/r08oc36c06x.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 6: An intraoperative photograph shows the herniated cord segment (arrow).'}]]

history: A 63-year-old woman presented with progressive swelling of the hard palate of 4 months duration. She had no other symptoms and no medical history of note. Physical examination revealed a 2-cm-diameter round mass on the underside of her hard palate. The mass was hard in consistency and immobile. The overlying mucosa was intact. There was no cervical lymphadenopathy. Computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance (MR) imaging were performed (,Figs 1, ,2,,,).
findings: CT images showed a large mass that was inseparable from the nasal septum in the midline of the nasal cavity (,Fig 1). There were matrix calcifications within this mass, consistent with a tumor of chondroid origin. These calcifications may be punctate; they may be dystrophic, with a jigsaw pattern; or they may have a ring and arc pattern. The tumor extended through the hard palate to the medial wall of the left maxillary antrum and superoposteriorly to involve the ethmoid and sphenoid sinuses. The tumor also abutted the left orbital wall and cribriform plate.

history: A 31-year-old otherwise healthy man presented with early satiety and left-sided abdominal pain. His medical history was remarkable for a 20-pack-year smoking habit. Physical examination revealed a firm left-sided abdominal mass that was approximately 12 cm in diameter and slightly tender. Complete blood count and routine serum chemistry test results were within normal limits. Abdominal ultrasonography (US) (,Fig 1,) and thoracic, abdominal, and pelvic computed tomography (CT) (,Figs 2,, ,3,) were performed.
findings: US revealed a large, left-sided complex retroperitoneal mass and multiple, predominantly hyperechoic, heterogeneous solid hepatic masses with irregular borders throughout the right and left hepatic lobes (,Fig 1,). A follow-up contrast material–enhanced (120 mL ioversol, Optiray 350; Tyco Health/Mallinckrodt, St Louis, Mo) CT examination of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis was performed with a 16-channel multidetector scanner (16 × 0.75-mm collimation, 5-mm section thickness) for further evaluation. CT images revealed heterogeneous, continuous rim-enhancing hypovascular hepatic masses that corresponded to the US findings (,Fig 2,) and a large, necrotic retroperitoneal mass with similar peripheral enhancement (,Fig 3,). This large retroperitoneal mass lacked internal fat and apparent calcification and exerted substantial mass effect that displaced the kidney, colon, and adjacent vasculature. In addition, mildly enlarged aortocaval and left paraaortic lymph nodes were noted (,Fig 3).

history: A 38-year-old man was referred for follow-up magnetic resonance (MR) imaging 8 months after gamma knife radiosurgery for a predominantly intraventricular (third ventricle) arteriovenous malformation. During the past 9 years, the patient had experienced multiple episodes of intraventricular hemorrhage and resultant hydrocephalus that had necessitated multiple ventricular shunt revisions. During this time, he refused any other type of therapeutic intervention for his arteriovenous malformation (,Figs 1,,,–,3,). At physical examination, the neurologic examination findings were unremarkable, with the exception of mild gait unsteadiness that had decreased in severity after the gamma knife procedure.
findings: On the axial T1-weighted MR images (,Fig 1,), a variably thick hyperintense rim partially outlined the medulla oblongata, the inferior cerebellar peduncles, and the seventh and eighth cranial nerve complexes. A partially corresponding hypointense rim was evident on axial T2-weighted MR images obtained at this same level (,Fig 2,). The extent of involvement was more conspicuous on the axial gradient-recalled-echo T2*-weighted MR images (,Fig 3,), which displayed a relatively symmetric hypointense rim that partially delineated the brain stem, cerebellum, and some of the lower cranial nerves. The involved nerves demonstrated a thickened appearance on the T2-weighted MR images (,Figs 2, ,3).

history: A 21 year-old woman presented with decreased visual acuity in her right eye. At admission, visual acuity was 20/70 in her right eye and 20/20 in her left eye. For the previous 20 days, this patient had also experienced migrainelike headache, vertigo, tinnitus, and vomiting. She had no uveitis or keratoconjunctivitis. Her medical history did not include any other pertinent findings.
findings: Multiple small low-signal-intensity abnormalities that were located in the central fibers of the corpus callosum and that spared the peripheral fibers were seen on T1-weighted MR images (,Figs 1, ,2). These lesions corresponded to the high-signal-intensity abnormalities seen on the T2-weighted MR image (,Fig 3). There was also a small high-signal-intensity focus in the posterior limb of the right internal capsule (,Fig 4).

history: A 49-year-old woman was referred to the internal medicine outpatient clinic for work-up of nonpitting edema. Her history was remarkable for a substantial weight gain (75 lbs [33.75 kg]) in the 6 months before presentation; this weight was distributed mainly in her thighs and upper arms.
findings: There was symmetric distribution of subcutaneous fat in the upper arms, back of the neck, back of the torso, anterior chest wall, and upper thighs, with relative sparing of the abdomen (,Figure,,,,,,). An incidental retroaortic left renal vein was seen. The solid organs and hollow viscera were normal, and there was no adenopathy, soft-tissue mass, or vascular or lymphatic anomaly.

history: A 28-year-old right-handed man presented with long-standing occipital headache, progressive ataxia, and blurred vision. He had begun vomiting 8–10 days earlier. He had no other important history. Neurologic examination revealed average intelligence and was remarkable for cerebellar ataxia. Papilledema was noted at fundoscopy. Magnetic resonance (MR) imaging of the brain was performed (,Figs 1,,,,–,4). No abnormality was noted on apparent diffusion coefficient maps or T2*-weighted gradient-echo images (not shown).
findings: On multiplanar MR images (,Figs 1,–,,,,4), the cerebellum appeared enlarged, with a mass lesion of abnormal signal intensity in the region of the cerebellar vermis. On T1-weighted images, the mass was predominantly hypointense and had typical prominent hypo- and isointense striations (,Fig 1). On T2-weighted images, the mass was predominantly hyperintense and had hyper- and isointense striations with respect to gray matter (,Fig 2). The mass remained hyperintense on the fluid-attenuated inversion-recovery image (,Fig 3). Sagittal (,Fig 1b) and coronal (,Fig 2b) images further showed the extent of the lesion. The fourth ventricle was compressed because of the mass effect (,Figs 1a, ,2a). Associated hydrocephalus was seen on the coronal image (,Fig 2b). The aqueduct of Sylvius was dilated (,Fig 1b). No enhancement was noted on contrast-enhanced images (,Fig 4).

history: A 73-year-old man who had undergone right hemicolectomy for colon cancer 1 year previously had an abdominal mass that was found at follow-up computed tomography performed at an outside institution. We performed contrast agent–enhanced (15 mL gadodiamide, Omniscan; GE Healthcare, Princeton, NJ) abdominal magnetic resonance (MR) imaging to assess this mass (,Figs 1,,–,3).
findings: Abdominal T1-weighted MR images obtained with a 1.5-T unit (Signa; GE Healthcare, Milwaukee, Wis) revealed a 14.5-cm-diameter well-circumscribed round mass in the right side of the abdomen, with intermediate signal intensity relative to that of skeletal muscle (,Fig 1,). Punctate foci of lipid were seen in this mass, with high signal intensity on in-phase T1-weighted images and low signal intensity on out-of-phase T1-weighted images because of a chemical shift artifact (,Fig 1,). In addition, two low-signal-intensity foci that were attributed to metallic clips were seen adjacent to the mass on T1-weighted images, with associated blooming artifacts on in-phase images (,Fig 1,). On the heavily T2-weighted image, the mass had internal high signal intensity that was similar to that of cerebrospinal fluid, internal wavy low-signal-intensity structures, and a low-signal-intensity rim (,Fig 2). A postcontrast T1-weighted image showed smooth thick rim enhancement without internal enhancement (,Fig 3). There were no findings of metastatic disease or lymphadenopathy elsewhere in the abdomen.

history: A 27-year-old gravida 1, para 1 woman who had a history of pelvic inflammatory disease presented to the emergency department with lower abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and chills. She began menstruating the night before presentation and reported an acute exacerbation of her chronic abdominal pain, which typically worsened with her menses. Her surgical history included one caesarean section and laparoscopic excision of a tubo-ovarian abscess. She was afebrile. Physical examination revealed mild diffuse abdominal tenderness and tenderness of the cervix. Laboratory findings revealed a white blood cell count of 17 000 cells per cubic millimeter. (A normal white blood cell count is between 4800 and 11 000 cells per cubic millimeter.)
findings: US of the pelvis revealed a multicystic mass within the left adnexa posterior to the uterus (,Fig 1). The left ovary was normal. Doppler US revealed no vascular flow to the mass, which extended to the right lower quadrant of the abdomen (,Fig 2). Oral and intravenous contrast material–enhanced CT of the abdomen and pelvis depicted a complex low-attenuation multicystic mass in the pelvis, with noncalcified septa, that extended to the right upper quadrant of the abdomen (,Figs 3, ,4). The coronal image shows the displacement of multiple small-bowel loops to the left, with no scalloping of the liver or spleen (,Fig 4).

history: A 12-year-old boy presented with pain in the right thigh that had persisted for 4 days. There was no trauma, and the patient's history provided no clues. The proximal thigh was tender on palpation, and there was no swelling or reddening. The patient's white blood cell count and other laboratory parameters were unremarkable. Conventional radiography and 3-T magnetic resonance (MR) imaging of the right femur were performed before and after administration of gadoterate meglumine (Dotarem; Guerbet, Paris, France) (,Figs 1,,,,–,3). Open biopsy was performed 5 days after imaging to enable histologic confirmation.
findings: Conventional radiography revealed a 1.5-cm-diameter lesion located centrally in the proximal femur diaphysis (,Fig 1,,). The radiolucent process was well-defined, without a sclerotic rim. A periosteal reaction and endosteal scalloping were seen, but there were no signs of cortical destruction.
diagnosis: Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis of the Femur1
images: [[{'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2503080092/asset/images/large/r09mr03g01a.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 1a: Transverse T1-weighted fast spin-echo 3-T MR images (1000/12.6) obtained (a) before and (b) after intravenous contrast agent administration. The contrast material–enhanced image was obtained with selective fat saturation.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2503080092/asset/images/large/r09mr03g01b.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 1b: Transverse T1-weighted fast spin-echo 3-T MR images (1000/12.6) obtained (a) before and (b) after intravenous contrast agent administration. history: A 61-year-old man presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of inability to walk, worsening of long-standing back pain, and bilateral lower limb weakness. There were no bowel or bladder problems. He had an 18-month history of progressive back and bilateral lower limb pain and difficulty walking. (He required rest after walking 100 yards.) He did not have a history of peripheral vascular disease. Relevant medical history included diet-controlled diabetes mellitus and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, for which he had received high-dose inhaled steroids for 4 years prior to admission. He had received oral steroids occasionally but for no more than a few days at a time. Neurologic examination revealed spastic paraparesis and decreased sensation below the T9 vertebra. Magnetic resonance (MR) imaging of the thoracolumbar spine was performed (,Figs 1,, ,2,).
findings: The sagittal T1- and T2-weighted MR images (Fig 1) showed a high-signal-intensity mass in the posterior epidural space that was deeper than 7 mm on the midsagittal section. The mass extended from the level of the T4-5 intervertebral disk to the level of the T8-9 intervertebral disk and had signal intensity similar to that of fat when examined with all sequences; however, specific fat-saturated sequences were not performed. On T1-weighted MR images (Fig 1a), the T6 vertebra was wedged anteriorly and had diffuse low signal intensity. On T2-weighted MR images (Fig 1b), the T6 vertebra had diffuse high signal intensity and a linear horizontal area of low signal intensity above the inferior endplate that was indicative of a fracture with marrow edema; however, there was no associated paravertebral soft-tissue mass that was indicative of a tumor. In addition, sagittal MR images showed probable old fractures of the T7 through T9 vertebrae. These old fractures, together with the probable acute fracture, produced a kyphotic curve of the thoracic spine that appeared to have contributed to spinal cord flattening. This made the spinal cord more vulnerable to compression by the small disk protrusion at the level of the T6-7 intervertebral disk. There were no abnormal signal intensity changes within the spinal cord. The axial T1-weighted MR image (Fig 2a) obtained at the T7 vertebral level and the T2-weighted MR image (Fig 2b) obtained at the level of the T6-7 intervertebral disk showed the homogeneous high-signal-intensity mass occupying the posterior epidural space and compressing and anteriorly displacing the spinal cord. The mass spanned the length of several thoracic vertebrae. In addition, the axial T2-weighted image (Fig 2b) showed the disk protrusion at the level of the T6-7 intervertebral disk compressed the spinal cord and acutely worsened the patient's symptoms. We concluded that the patient's clinical history and MR findings were consistent with a diagnosis of acutely manifesting thoracic epidural lipomatosis due to focal disk herniation and vertebral fracture.

history: A 43-year-old man was admitted for new onset of bitemporal headache, bilateral lower extremity numbness, and generalized tonic-clonic seizure. Physical examination findings were remarkable for bilateral lower extremity weakness. Magnetic resonance (MR) imaging of the brain was performed (,Fig 1). Initial analysis of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) revealed an elevated nucleated cell count, with 92% lymphocytes (normal range, 37%–75%) and 8% monocytes and/or macrophages (normal range, 0%–15%). CSF staining, cell culture, and polymerase chain reaction results were negative for cryptococcus, histoplasmosis, Coccidioides infection, syphilis, cytomegalovirus, West Nile virus, herpes simplex virus, and Epstein-Barr virus. Enzyme immunoassay, Western blot analysis, and indirect immunofluorescence assays were positive for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) antibodies. The plasma HIV RNA level was 32 806 copies per milliliter, and the CD4+ T-cell count was 29 cells per microliter (normal range, 500–1800 cells per microliter). The antitoxoplasmosis immunoglobulin G titer was elevated; however, the immunoglobulin M titer was normal. CSF samples from two lumbar punctures did not show signs of acid-fast bacillus growth; however, an antituberculosis regimen was initiated because of positive purified protein derivative skin test results and positive MR findings. In addition, the patient received a 2-week course of sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine to treat toxoplasmosis.
findings: Initial MR imaging of the brain (Fig 1) revealed abnormal T2 hyperintensity and faint contrast enhancement in the right precentral gyrus, bilateral parahippocampal gyri, superior cerebellar vermis, and cerebellar nodules. The ventricular system was normal in size, and there was no dural enhancement. Six weeks later, MR imaging revealed an increase in T2 hyperintensity and enhancement in the right precentral gyrus and cerebral peduncles but decreased T2 hyperintensity and enhancement in the parahippocampal gyri and cerebellum (Fig 2). Seven weeks later, repeat MR imaging revealed multifocal areas of T2 hyperintensity and contrast enhancement involving the right precentral gyrus, bilateral parahippocampal gyrus, midbrain, right posterior temporal lobe, and white matter surrounding the lateral and fourth ventricles (Fig 3). Repeat MR imaging 6 weeks later depicted decreased contrast enhancement at all sites (Fig 4).

history: At presentation, a 43-year-old man had multiple cranial nerve deficits that had been progressing since early childhood. In addition, he had an angular face, a protruding chin, irregular alignment of the teeth, frontal bossing, and bulging eyes. He had experienced bilateral mixed conductive and sensorineural hearing loss since the age of 4 years; this subsequently led to total deafness in his left ear and only residual hearing in his right. (A pure tone audiogram revealed a bone conduction threshold of approximately 50 dB and an air-bone gap of 50 dB.) Furthermore, intermittent headaches, peripheral facial palsy, and recurrent trigeminal neuralgia predominantly localized on the right side became evident early in childhood. During adolescence and adulthood, the patient also reported swallowing difficulties and a mild speech impairment. His stature was normal, and he had never sustained any bone fractures. Previously obtained radiographs revealed symmetric hyperostosis of tubular bones, such as the ulna, radius, metacarpal bones, clavicles, and ribs. Cranial CT and MR images showed generalized thickening of the skull, particularly affecting the vault, petrous bones, and mandible (,Figs 1,,,,–,4,,). Results of laboratory blood tests—including those to assess serum parathyroid hormone, calcitonin, and alkaline phosphatase levels—were unremarkable. His IQ was measured with the Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale and found to be 106 (verbal IQ, 94; performance IQ, 118), which was slightly above average. The patient had two older sisters, one of whom had similar symptoms but in a milder form. The parents were neither affected nor consanguineous.
findings: The cranial CT scout image revealed severe hyperostosis that mainly affected the skull and mandible (Fig 1). The calvarium was as thick as 3.3 cm and consisted entirely of dense bone. Axial CT images of the skull base were obtained with a high-spatial-resolution bone algorithm and depicted extensive sclerosis and hyperostosis of the petrous bones, orbital walls, and calvarium. The latter presented with loss of the diploë mainly due to cortical thickening (Fig 2). The temporomandibular joint was constricted by massive hyperostosis of the condylar processes and the mandibular fossa. Irregular hyperostosis at the level of the foramen ovale could have restricted the mandibular nerve. Similarly, bony narrowing of other neural exit foramina and neural canals could have caused the multiple cranial nerve deficits, such as facial and hypoglossal palsy. Notably, the left external auditory canal was nearly occluded by extensive hyperostosis, despite several attempts to surgically decompress these structures. The internal auditory canals were circumscribed, which caused encroachment of the 7th and 8th cranial nerves. Inner ear structures on both sides of the head appeared to be encompassed by dense bone masses. Bilateral coarsening of the orbital walls reduced the intraorbital volume and resulted in mild proptosis of 13 mm (not shown). However, the optic nerve did not appear constricted. There was considerable signal noise on the CT images obtained with routinely used scanning parameters (100 mAs, 120 kV), a limitation that was most likely caused by the patient's thick bones.

history: A 21-year-old man presented to the emergency department with a history of acute upper abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. He received a presumptive diagnosis of and treatment for gastroenteritis and was released. He returned to the emergency department later that same day with worsening upper abdominal pain and vomiting.
findings: Coronal reformatted contrast-enhanced CT depicted diffuse circumferential thickening of the gastric antrum and all segments of the duodenum (Fig 1). There was marked 1.0–1.5-cm thickening of the affected segments of the duodenum, with low attenuation in the submucosa, compatible with edema. There also were dilated loops of proximal jejunum. Axial contrast-enhanced CT (Fig 2) revealed a focal area of thickening in the more distal jejunum, with proximal jejunal dilatation. Adjacent fat stranding and inflammatory changes were present surrounding the descending and transverse duodenum. No abnormally enlarged lymph nodes were present.

history: A 64-year-old woman presented with symptoms of bilateral eye ptosis, which had been slowly progressing for more than 1 year. Her left eye was more affected than her right eye. Her symptoms were not relieved by rest. She reported no neuromuscular disorders. Ophthalmologic examination findings confirmed profound bilateral ptosis, as well as limited downward and upward gaze, which elicited diplopia. There was no pupillary abnormality. The results of a neurologic examination were otherwise normal. This patient underwent magnetic resonance (MR) imaging of the orbits to enable further evaluation (Figs 1–4).
findings: There was intermediate- to low-signal-intensity abnormal episcleral tissue on spin-echo T2-weighted images, with similar abnormal T2-weighted hypointense signal in the extraocular muscles. In addition, the orbital fat was abnormally hypointense on T2-weighted images. Furthermore, there was inward depression of the globe, consistent with enophthalmos (Fig 1). Coronal short inversion time inversion-recovery images (Fig 2) and axial postcontrast T1-weighted images with fat saturation (Fig 3) revealed abnormal enlargement of the bilateral extraocular muscles that did not spare the tendinous insertions on the globe. The axial postcontrast T1-weighted images with fat saturation (Fig 3) again revealed bilateral symmetric enophthalmos and abnormal enhancement of the bilateral orbital soft tissues, including the intraconal fat, extraocular muscles, and preseptal periorbital soft tissue. There was extension of this process into the infraorbital subcutaneous tissues that was more noticeable on the left side than on the right (Fig 4).
diagnosis: Orbital Metastatic Disease from Breast Carcinoma1

history: A 15-year-old boy was reevaluated for brief episodic nonexertional chest pain that was neither exacerbated by activity nor relieved by rest. His medical history included dizzy spells and palpitations, and he had no family history of cardiac abnormalities. A cardiovascular examination revealed a grade II/VI low-pitched systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border, without positional change in character or intensity. The rest of the physical examination findings were normal. Cardiac magnetic resonance (MR) imaging was performed with and without gadolinium-containing contrast material (Figs 1–4). Cardiac MR examinations performed 3 and 6 years earlier and multiple prior echocardiographic examinations yielded similar imaging findings.
findings: Cardiac MR imaging revealed masslike thickening of the apical and midanterior interventricular septum that extended to the right ventricular free wall (Fig 1). This abnormality had smooth lobulated margins and was isointense to normal ventricular myocardium on images obtained with proton-density–weighted and T2-weighted sequences (Fig 2). When we used a myocardial tagged sequence, the abnormality exhibited reduced contractility in comparison to that of normal adjacent myocardium (Fig 3). Resting first-pass perfusion characteristics were similar to those of normal myocardium, and there was no delayed enhancement (Fig 4). Functional analysis (not shown) revealed otherwise normal biventricular wall motion, a left ventricular ejection fraction of 60%, and increased left ventricular mass (z score, 2.3; normalized to body surface area).

history: A 58-year-old otherwise healthy woman reported intermittent swelling of several years duration on the right side of her neck. She did not smoke or drink alcoholic beverages. Computed tomography (CT) of the neck was performed (Figs 1, 2). The patient was lost to follow-up; however, 20 months after the original examination was performed, she presented again with continued gradual progression of swelling on the right side of her neck and new dysphagia. Repeat CT was performed at this time (Fig 3).
findings: The initial study (Fig 1) revealed an enhancing pharyngeal mass involving the right lateral oropharynx, including the palatine tonsillar fossa, extending to the hypopharynx. The mass appeared to be based within the mucosa of the upper oropharynx, with a submucosal component that extended along the posterolateral oropharyngeal wall to the hypopharynx, elevating the mucosa and effacing the right pyriform sinus. There were numerous prominent vessels and calcifications within the mass. The mass was separate from the thyroid gland, which was normal.
diagnosis: Pharyngeal and Retropharyngeal Tuberculosis with Nodal Disease1

history: A 50-year-old woman presented with fatigue, shortness of breath, and cough. She had increasing palpitations, occasional dizziness, orthostasis, marked dyspnea on exertion, and hemoptysis that led her to the emergency department in search of care. Laboratory work-up revealed a (a) white cell count of 6.7 × 109/L (normal range, [3.8–9.2] × 109/L) with a normal differential, (b) hemoglobin level of 7.7 g/dL (77 g/L) (normal range, 11.9–15.0 g/dL [119–150 g/L]), (c) hematocrit of 23.7% (0.237) (normal level, 34.8%–43.6% [0.348–0.436]), (d) mean corpuscular volume of 79.8 μm (normal range, 81–97 μm3), (e) mean corpuscular hemoglobin level of 26.0 pg per cell (normal range, 27–32 pg per cell), (f) mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration of 32.6 g/dL (326 g/L) (normal range, 32–36 g/dL [326–360 g/L]), and (g) platelet count of 370 × 109/L (normal level, [150–450] × 109/L). The coagulation profile revealed a prothrombin time of 14.6 seconds (normal range, 12.2–14.8 seconds), a partial thromboplastin time of 34.2 seconds (normal range, 23.8–36.6 seconds), and an international normalized ratio of 1.1 (normal range, 0.9–1.1).
findings: Posteroanterior and lateral chest radiographs (not shown) demonstrated faint opacities in both lower lungs. These opacities were somewhat diffuse in the left lung and patchy in the right lung. Contrast material–enhanced (iopromide, 300 mg of iodine per milliliter, Ultravist 300; Bayer Healthcare Pharmaceuticals, Wayne, NJ) CT images acquired with the lung window setting revealed diffuse ground-glass opacities in large parts of the left lung (Figure). Patchy areas of ground-glass opacity were seen in the upper and middle lobes of the right lung (Figure).

history: A 37-year-old woman presented with hematochezia of 1-month duration. She had undergone cesarean section 6 years previously. She had an otherwise unremarkable medical history. Physical examination revealed mild tenderness in the lower abdomen. Serum hemoglobin level and hematocrit were 6.3 g/dL (63 g/L) and 21.3% (0.213), respectively. Laboratory findings were otherwise unremarkable. Small-bowel follow-through (Fig 1) and computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen (Fig 2) were performed. Radionuclide bleeding scanning with technetium-99m–labeled red blood cells was also performed, but the findings were normal (not shown).
findings: Small-bowel follow-through revealed an elongated, smoothly marginated polypoid intraluminal mass with a rounded tip in the proximal ileum (Fig 1). The polypoid mass was approximately 6.5 cm in length and 2 cm wide; it occupied almost the entire lumen of the undistended proximal ileum and ran parallel to the long axis of the small bowel. There was no bowel obstruction or intussusception. Contrast material—enhanced CT was performed in the portal phase (72-second delay) after injection of 150 mL of iopromide (Ultravist 300; Bayer Schering Pharma, Berlin, Germany) and without administration of oral contrast material. The resultant images (Fig 2) showed an elongated intraluminal mass of fat attenuation that was located in a pelvic ileal loop and that corresponded to the lesion location on small-bowel follow-through images. The fatty lesion appeared much thinner (1 cm wide) than the polypoid lesion seen at small-bowel follow-through, and it was surrounded by a thick collar of enhancing soft tissue that was not clearly distinguished from the normal small-bowel wall at CT, as the bowel lumen was collapsed at the time of CT (Fig 2).

history: A 52-year-old male smoker who was otherwise healthy presented with a recent history of intermittent left calf claudication (left calf pain when walking approximately 500 m). The results of a physical examination were unremarkable, and normal arterial pulses were present bilaterally in the femoral, popliteal, dorsalis pedis, and posterior tibial arteries. There was no evidence of ischemia.Color Doppler ultrasonography (US) of the lower extremities was performed (Figs 1, 2) and was followed by magnetic resonance (MR) imaging of both knees (Figs 3, 4) and MR angiography of the lower extremities (Fig 5).
findings: Color Doppler US of the popliteal vessels revealed anechoic cystic lesions with thin-walled well-defined margins and posterior acoustic enhancement that were adjacent to both popliteal arteries (Figs 1, 2). The popliteal vessels on both sides of the body showed no changes in diameter, wall thickness, or blood flow.
diagnosis: Bilateral Adventitial Cystic Disease of the Popliteal Artery1

history: A 51-year-old man presented with abdominal pain, fever, and diarrhea. He was suspected of having enteric infection, and he received oral antibiotics and rehydration therapy. Despite these regular measures, his clinical status did not improve.
findings: Contrast material–enhanced CT (120 mL of iopromide, Ultravist 300; Schering, Berlin, Germany) revealed a nonocclusive intrahepatic thrombus in the portal branch of the right anterior liver segment that was causing nonhomogeneous enhancement of the hepatic parenchyma (Fig 1). There was also a nonenhancing low-attenuation thrombus within the lumen of the superior mesenteric vein (Fig 2). Finally, CT images acquired at the level of the cecum (Fig 3) showed evidence of fat stranding in the retrocecal area, a wall-thickened and contrast-enhanced appendix emerging from the cecum, and extraluminal gas that was indicative of perforated appendicitis.

history: A 76-year-old man presented to the outpatient neurology service with fatigue and confusion of several months duration. His wife had recently noticed that he also had some memory impairment. The patient was a dental technician and was still active at work. He had mild hypertension. The only medication he was taking was aspirin (100 mg per day). At presentation, his systolic blood pressure was 160 mm Hg, and his diastolic blood pressure was 80 mm Hg. Funduscopic examination revealed mild arterial narrowing and sclerosis. The patient was alert and perfectly oriented. His Mini-Mental State Examination score was 27 (25.3 after correction for age and education), with some failure on memory tasks. The rest of the neurologic examination was normal. The results of routine blood tests performed at presentation were normal. The erythrocyte sedimentation rate; levels of C-reactive protein and extractable nuclear antigen, lupus anticoagulant, and anticardiolipin antibodies; and prothrombin and partial thromboplastin times were normal. Serum protein electrophoresis findings were negative. This patient was considered to have mild cognitive impairment (amnestic type) and was referred for brain computed tomography (CT) (Fig 1), which was followed the next day by 0.5- and 1.5-T magnetic resonance (MR) imaging (Figs 2–4).
findings: Multiple low-attenuation areas in the subcortical white matter of the cerebral hemispheres were unexpectedly found at CT (Fig 1). CT also revealed a small well-defined area of low attenuation in the right basal ganglia that was consistent with the appearance of an old infarct (not shown). MR imaging showed that the areas of abnormal signal intensity were asymmetrically distributed, mildly swollen, and more extensive in the posterior parts of the cerebral hemispheres, where they partly involved the cortex (Fig 2). Smaller lesions were present in the subcortical white matter of the orbital and superior frontal gyri. No evidence of hemorrhage was present on CT or T1-weighted MR images. No lesions were seen in the posterior fossa. No abnormal enhancement was seen on postcontrast images (not shown). On diffusion-weighted images and apparent diffusion coefficient maps, the white matter lesions did not show restricted diffusivity and instead were consistent with vasogenic edema (Fig 3). An MR perfusion study revealed decreased cerebral blood volume in the swollen lesions of the white matter and, to a lesser degree, in the adjacent cortex (Fig 3). A T2*-weighted gradient-echo sequence was performed, and it revealed multiple cortical punctate hypointensities due to microhemorrhages, consistent with cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA) (Fig 4). Diagnosis of CAA enabled us to make the final comprehensive diagnosis of CAA-related inflammation. Intramuscular administration of 8 mg/d of dexamethasone in the 1st week and 4 mg/d of dexamethasone in the 2nd week was followed by administration of 50 mg/d of oral prednisone, which was gradually tapered in the following months. Control MR images obtained after 4 weeks of treatment (not shown) revealed dramatic improvement of the white matter lesions. At 6-month follow-up, with prednisone maintenance dosage of 7.5 mg/d, the white matter hyperintensities had almost completely disappeared (Fig 5), and the cognitive profile, as assessed with the Mini-Mental State Examination, had returned to a normal score of 30/30. Subsequent genotype testing revealed this patient had the apolipoprotein E (APOE) ε4-ε4 genotype.

history: A 64-year-old woman with a history of mantle cell lymphoma and stem cell transplantation 2.5 years earlier presented with cough and chest pain. She had received voriconazole prophylaxis, and she had cytopenia, recurrent graft-versus-host disease, and diabetes mellitus. Chest computed tomography (CT) was performed to assess the patient’s cough and chest pain. She was admitted shortly after this examination. Two days after admission, CT was repeated because of increased right-sided chest pain, increased cough, and hemoptysis. Three days later, tissue diagnosis was made with CT-guided biopsy (Figs 1–4).
findings: The initial CT examination (Figs 1, 2) revealed a rounded consolidation with surrounding ground-glass opacity (GGO) (halo sign) in the anterior segment of the right upper lobe. The second CT examination (Figs 3, 4) revealed that the pulmonary opacity had increased in size and changed in morphology from a halo configuration to a reversed halo configuration (central GGO with surrounding irregular rim of consolidation). In addition, the consolidation and GGO extended to the pleura, resulting in pleural thickening (Figs 3, 4).

history: An 8-year-old girl presented with pain and tenderness of 6 months duration in the distal part of her calf above the left ankle. She denied having experienced any trauma, and her clinical history was otherwise normal. A physical examination revealed a tender mass associated with redness on the skin.
findings: Conventional radiography of the ankle (Fig 1) revealed soft-tissue swelling and mass effect on the medial cortex of the fibula. The cortex was not destroyed, and there was no calcification in the soft tissues adjacent to the fibula.
diagnosis: Hydatid Disease with Water Lily Sign Manifesting as a Soft-Tissue Mass in the Calf of a Child1

history: A 50-year-old intoxicated man was brought to a level 1 trauma center after falling from his bicycle into oncoming traffic. At the scene, he was unresponsive, with hypotension and tachycardia. Intubation was subsequently performed. At initial evaluation in the trauma center, he continued to be hypotensive and tachycardic, with decreased breath sounds on the right side. A right-sided throacostomy tube was subsequently placed. He had swelling in his right upper chest and right shoulder and a pulseless right upper extremity. The following radiograph and trauma computed tomographic (CT) image were obtained (Figs 1, 2).
findings: The initial trauma chest radiograph (Fig 1) and anteroposterior CT scanogram (Fig 2) revealed lateral displacement of the right scapula and a large axillary and right anterior chest wall soft-tissue mass. There was also a lateral sternoclavicular separation, a distal clavicle fracture (Fig 2), and an acromioclavicular separation (Fig 2).
images: [[{'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.10090047/asset/images/large/10090047fig01.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 1: Anteroposterior bedside supine chest radiograph.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.10090047/asset/images/large/10090047fig02.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 2: Anteroposterior contrast material—enhanced (150 mL of iohexol; Omnipaque 350, GE Healthcare, Little Chalfont, England) CT scanogram of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis.'}], [{'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.10090048/asset/images/large/090048fig01.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 1: Anteroposterior bedside supine chest radiograph obtained in the trauma bay shows substantial lateral displacement of the right scapula and clavicle and lateral sternoclavicular separation (arrow). history: A 46-year-old male refugee who had emigrated from Burma to the United States less than a year earlier presented to the emergency department with tonic-clonic seizures. The patient’s medical history included previous seizures, the most recent having occurred about a year ago, and hepatitis B. He had no family history of epilepsy. Physical examination revealed a tired afebrile man without lymphadenopathy, and ophthalmic examination revealed signs of previous trachoma. Computed tomography (CT) of the head revealed focal low attenuation in the right frontal lobe, which suggested the possibility of an underlying mass lesion. Phenytoin therapy was initiated, and during this patient’s hospital course, he remained asymptomatic. Subsequent CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis revealed subtle anterior nodules in the right lung, some of which were in a tree-in-bud configuration, and a 1.4-cm lesion in the pole of the left kidney. A purified protein derivative test was nonreactive, a test for human immunodeficiency virus antibodies was negative, and an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay for immunoglobulin G was negative for blood cysticercosis. An electroencephalogram was obtained in the waking state, and it revealed no epileptiform discharges, paroxysmal features, or interhemispheric asymmetry. Magnetic resonance (MR) imaging of the head was performed (Figs 1–4).
findings: A solitary lesion in the right frontal lobe was centrally hyperintense on both the T2-weighted MR image (Fig 1) and the fluid-attenuated inversion recovery MR image (Fig 2); both images were acquired with a 1.5-T imager (GE Medical Systems, Milwaukee, Wis). The subcortical white matter adjacent to the lesion was also hyperintense. Peripheral enhancement was noted on the contrast material–enhanced (gadoversetamide, Optimark; Mallinckrodt, St Louis, Mo) MR images (Fig 3), and a small eccentric nodule was seen on the sagittal image (Fig 3b). There was no restricted diffusion within the lesion (Fig 4).
