history: The mother of a 12-month-old boy found swelling in the child’s right groin. He had no history of vomiting or constipation. The patient was a full-term infant born by normal vaginal delivery. There was no important past medical, surgical, or family history. On examination, the patient’s abdomen was soft, nontender, and nondistended, and there were normal active bowel sounds. A soft swelling was palpated in the right inguinal canal. The testes were descended bilaterally and were nontender to palpation. Plain abdominal radiography revealed no evidence of intestinal obstruction or perforation. With gentle manipulation, the swelling was successfully reduced; however, it recurred a few hours later. Ultrasonography (US) was then performed to further evaluate the nature of this swelling (Figs 1–4).
findings: At scrotal US, an anechoic fluid collection was seen in the region of the right inguinal canal above the right testicle (Fig 1), without any fluid around the right testicle in the scrotal sac (Fig 2). The internal inguinal ring was found to be patent superior to the fluid collection (Fig 4). These findings were consistent with a funicular type of spermatic cord hydrocele. The patient underwent surgery, and funicular hydrocele communicating with the peritoneal cavity but not the bowel contents was found.
diagnosis: Funicular Type of Spermatic Cord Hydrocele1

history: A 51-year-old woman had a history of multiple poorly healing fractures over the course of the previous 4 years. Her medical history was remarkable for asthma, fibromyalgia, and hypothyroidism. Laboratory tests revealed serum calcium, parathyroid hormone, and 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D levels were within normal limits; however, the serum phosphorus level was low at 1.2 mg/dL (0.388 mmol/L) (normal, 2.5–4.5 mg/dL [0.807–1.45 mmol/L]). After radiography (images not shown), octreotide scintigraphy was performed (Fig 1). Magnetic resonance (MR) imaging of the left knee was performed later (Figs 2, 3).
findings: Whole-body images obtained 24 hours after intravenous injection of 6.0 mCi indium 111 (111In) pentetreotide (OctreoScan; Mallinckrodt, Hazelwood, Mo) revealed an area of increased radiotracer activity localized to the left lateral femoral condyle (Fig 1). Subsequent MR imaging of the left knee revealed an ovoid mass in the anterior portion of the lateral femoral condyle (Figs 2, 3). The 2-cm mass was of intermediate signal intensity, with a punctate central focus of low signal intensity and a peripheral ring of lower signal intensity on intermediate-weighted images. On T2-weighted images, there was uniform high signal intensity, with a central punctate area of low signal intensity and a peripheral ring of low signal intensity. Additional MR findings included multiple low-signal-intensity linear bands in the lateral femoral condyle and tibial plateau, consistent with prior fractures.

history: A 54-year-old man had a history of hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer. Colon cancer was initially diagnosed in 2001, and the patient underwent right colectomy. In 2002, the patient developed duodenal cancer, and he underwent a Whipple procedure. A second colon cancer was discovered in 2004, and the patient underwent completion colectomy. Surveillance body computed tomography (CT) was performed in 2007 and revealed a new right hilar mass. Additional imaging included fluorine 18 (18F) fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) combined positron emission tomography (PET) and CT (Figs 1, 2) and follow-up intravenous contrast material–enhanced (90 mL of iohexol 300, Omnipaque; GE Healthcare, Fairfield, Conn) chest CT (Fig 3).
findings: Maximum intensity projection (Fig 1) and axial (Fig 2) 18F FDG PET/CT images depicted a large hypermetabolic mass in the right hilum, a second hypermetabolic soft-tissue lesion in the region of the aortopulmonary (AP) window and left pulmonary artery, and a hypermetabolic left hilar lymph node. No abnormalities below the diaphragm were noted. Follow-up intravenous contrast-enhanced chest CT (Fig 3) performed 21 days later again depicted a large right hilar mass causing severe narrowing of the superior vena cava and right superior pulmonary vein and encasing the right pulmonary artery, resulting in marked narrowing. The soft-tissue lesion at the level of the AP window seen with PET/CT was now more clearly seen to be an intraluminal filling defect in the left pulmonary artery. This lesion extended into the left lower lobe pulmonary artery and was the source of left hilar uptake seen with PET/CT.

history: A 70-year-old man with a history of radical cystoprostatectomy, pelvic node dissection, and urinary conduit diversion for transitional cell carcinoma of the prostate and urinary bladder 7 years prior to presentation was admitted with hematuria of 3 months duration. He had experienced anorexia and weight loss of about 25–30 lbs (9–14 kg) over the previous 6 months. His renal function had steadily worsened, as his creatinine level had increased from 1.1 mg/dL (97 μmol/L) at baseline to 5.1 mg/dL (451 μmol/L) in the past 3 months. Urinalysis revealed a pH of 8.5 nd was positive for the presence of blood and leukocyte esterase.
findings: US of the kidneys revealed mild left hydronephrosis and bilateral renal calyceal echogenicities with shadowing. These were initially thought to be calculi (Fig 1). Unenhanced CT of the abdomen and pelvis revealed mild bilateral hydroureter and hydronephrosis, with curvilinear calcifications involving the urothelium of the renal pelves and calyces (Fig 2). These CT findings were not seen at CT performed approximately 1 year previously. On the basis of these radiologic findings, a presumptive diagnosis of alkaline-encrusted pyelitis was made.

history: A previously healthy 10-month-old girl (patient A) was brought to the emergency department with persistent postprandial nonbilious emesis of 1 week duration. After vomiting, her condition appeared to improve. Her mother noted that the patient had been irritable over the past several days. This infant was the product of a full-term pregnancy, and the pre- and postnatal courses were uneventful. The findings of a physical examination were normal. Magnetic resonance (MR) imaging (Fig 1a–1c) and computed tomography (CT) (Fig 1d) were performed.
findings: In patient A, cranial CT (Fig 1d) revealed a mixed solid and cystic mass along the posterosuperior margin of the third ventricle. No internal calcifications were seen. Cranial MR imaging (Fig 1a–1c) revealed a large mixed solid and cystic mass arising from the septum pellucidum that obstructed the third and lateral ventricles. A second mixed cystic and solid mass was seen within the fourth ventricle. The solid component of both masses demonstrated T2-hypointensity and decreased water diffusion. In patient B, abdominal CT (Fig 2) revealed a heterogeneously enhancing left paraspinal mass medial to the left kidney with areas of central necrosis but no calcifications or hemorrhage. In both patients, we diagnosed rhabdoid predisposition syndrome, with an inherited mutation in one hSFN5/INI1 tumor suppressor allele, which manifested as an atypical teratoid rhabdoid tumor (AT/RT) in patient A and a malignant rhabdoid tumor of a peripheral nerve in patient B.
diagnosis: Rhabdoid Predisposition Syndrome—Familial Cancer Syndromes in Children

history: After relocating to a newly remodeled older home, a 45-year-old man in good health noticed the onset of drenching night sweats and fatigue. Subsequently, he contracted an upper respiratory tract infection and developed a cough that produced yellow to brown sputum, a fever of 38.6°C, and shortness of breath. This infection was treated empirically with an oral antibiotic for 5 days, with minor symptomatic improvement. The patient had an unintentional weight loss of 7 kg over the course of 6 weeks and bilateral parahilar air-space opacities on chest radiographs; he was subsequently admitted for further investigation. Thoracic computed tomography (CT) was performed (Fig 1). Except for pancytopenia and a nonspecific lymphoproliferative reaction at bone marrow biopsy, the work-up for possible causes remained inconclusive. The patient was started on multiple antibiotic regimens to cover bacterial or fungal infection because of a fever spike to 40°C and worsening lung involvement at chest radiography (Fig 2).
findings: The initial chest radiograph (not shown) showed nonspecific bilateral parahilar airspace opacities. Contrast material–enhanced thoracic CT (lung window setting) images obtained at admission showed bilateral ill-defined ground-glass opacities and small pulmonary nodules with a predominant peribronchovascular distribution (Fig 1). The pulmonary periphery was relatively spared. Cardiac size was normal, there was no mediastinal or hilar lymph node enlargement, and there was no pleural or pericardial effusion (images obtained with mediastinal window settings not shown). Repeat anteroposterior portable chest radiography was performed to assess clinical deterioration during the course of admission and revealed progressive, ill-defined, bilateral parahilar airspace opacities (Fig 2). Follow-up thoracic CT (lung window settings) performed while the patient was receiving empirical antifungal treatment revealed bilateral progressive parahilar pulmonary opacities (Fig 3). Although some of the previously present larger ill-defined areas of peribronchovascular opacity had decreased in size, there was an increased profusion of discrete small nodules located diffusely in the central portions of the lungs. The pulmonary periphery remained relatively spared. Cardiac size remained normal, there was no mediastinal or hilar lymph node enlargement, and there was no pleural or pericardial effusion (images obtained with mediastinal window settings not shown).

history: A 30-year-old man presented to our emergency department with acute pleuritic chest pain. He had no fever, dyspnea, or other symptoms, nor did he have a history of chest trauma. A physical examination yielded normal findings. Laboratory test results and electrocardiographic findings were normal. Axial chest computed tomography (CT) was performed (Figs 1, 2).
findings: Contrast material–enhanced (90 mL of iomeprol administered at a rate of 2.5 mL/sec, Iomeron 400; Bracco Diagnostics, Milan, Italy) thoracic CT revealed an encapsulated low-attenuation lesion (−50 HU) with high-attenuation strands, which indicated inflammatory changes adjacent to the pericardium in the left epipericardial fat. There were no other associated abnormalities, with the exception of bilateral pleural effusion, which affected the left side of the pleural space more than the right (Fig 1). Sagittal and coronal multiplanar reformation CT images revealed the absence of diaphragmatic defects and no connection with abdominal fat (Fig 2). Follow-up unenhanced CT was performed 2 weeks later after conservative treatment. This examination revealed complete resolution of the inflammatory changes in the epipericardial fat. Pleural effusion had resolved (Fig 3).

history: A 50-year-old man presented with left peripheral facial nerve paresis, which gradually progressed to complete paralysis over the course of several weeks. The patient underwent examination of the temporal bones with magnetic resonance (MR) imaging, which was followed by computed tomography (CT) (Aquilion 64; Toshiba Medical Systems, Togichi, Japan) (Figs 1–4).
findings: MR imaging revealed an area of abnormal T2 hyperintensity (Fig 1) in the left geniculate ganglion. The lesion had intrinsic T1 signal that was isointense to brain parenchyma (Fig 2). Postgadolinium MR images showed intense enhancement of the lesion, with punctate areas of nonenhancement (Fig 3). These nonenhancing foci within the mass corresponded to the stippled foci of hypointensity visible on T1- and T2-weighted images. On axial CT images of the temporal bone, these punctate areas of hypointensity and nonenhancement corresponded to foci of bone density within an expansile lytic lesion involving the geniculate ganglion and labyrinthine segment of the facial nerve (Fig 4a). This intralesional osseous matrix had a honeycomb pattern, best demonstrated on the coronal CT image (Fig 4b).

history: A 24-year-old woman presented with intermittent dull abdominal pain of 2 months duration. She reported no association with food and no alleviating factors. She denied any recent travel. She did not report any fever, flushing, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, melena, or hematochezia. She had no relevant medical history; specifically, there was no history of human immunodeficiency virus infection. Physical examination findings and all laboratory values, including complete blood count and basic metabolic panel, were normal. She subsequently underwent computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis followed by magnetic resonance (MR) imaging of the abdomen and pelvis for further evaluation (Figs 1–5).
findings: We first performed contrast material–enhanced CT through the abdomen and pelvis. This revealed a solid hyperattenuating retroperitoneal mass with a thin surrounding capsule and slightly enlarged left paraaortic lymph nodes (Fig 1). The rest of the abdominal and pelvic organs were normal.

history: An 8-year-old boy presented with subacute quadriparesis. He had traveled abroad 4 weeks earlier. During his travel, he contracted chicken pox. At presentation, the clinical examination revealed no fever; however, the patient had severe headache, flaccid quadriparesis, and anarthria. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis revealed 100 lymphocytes with normal cerebrospinal fluid glucose and protein levels; there was no evidence of bacteria. Magnetic resonance (MR) images of the brain were obtained 7 days after the onset of symptoms (Figure).
findings: T1- (Fig 1a) and T2-weighted (Fig 1b) gradient-echo MR images revealed hypo- and hyperintensity, respectively, in an isolated lesion of the pons. Gradient-echo T2-weighted MR images (Fig 1b) revealed some peripheral areas of hypointensity, which were thought to reflect areas of microhemorrhage. After administration of a gadolinium chelate, the lesion demonstrated ring enhancement (Fig 1c). The center of the lesion was hyperintense on diffusion-weighted MR images (Fig 1d), with a corresponding area of restricted diffusion on the apparent diffusion coefficient map (Fig 1e). 1H MR spectroscopy (Fig 1f) revealed high choline and lipid levels and a reduced N-acetylaspartate level in the center of the lesion. There was no elevation of acetate, succinate, lactate, or amino acid levels; these are usually elevated in patients with pyogenic abscesses.
diagnosis: Acute Disseminated Encephalomyelitis Confined to the Brainstem

history: A 30-year-old man presented with progressive lower extremity weakness and dyspnea on exertion. Physical examination revealed short stature and normal cognition. There was no history of surgery, trauma, or cancer. The patient underwent diagnostic imaging, including chest radiography, chest computed tomography (CT), and magnetic resonance (MR) imaging of the brain and spine. The chest radiograph is not included in the images provided (Figs 1–4).
findings: A sagittal T2-weighted image of the cervical spine showed severe narrowing of the upper cervical spinal canal due to a T2 hypointense lesion surrounding the dens and spinal cord compression (Fig 1). The cisterna magna was enlarged. Axial MR images of the brain showed enlarged subarachnoid spaces, ventriculomegaly, abnormal periventricular fluid-attenuated inversion recovery hyperintensity, and dilated thalamic perivascular spaces (Figs 2, 3). Tracheal stenosis was seen on the unenhanced chest CT image (Fig 4). Frontal chest radiography showed oar-shaped ribs (Fig 5).

The cisterna magna is enlarged.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.11100008/asset/images/large/100008fig02.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 2: Axial fluid-attenuated inversion recovery MR image of the brain shows ventriculomegaly with abnormal increased periventricular signal intensity and dilatation of thalamic perivascular spaces.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.11100008/asset/images/large/100008fig03.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 3: Axial T2-weighted MR image of the brain shows enlarged subarachnoid spaces in the middle cranial fossa and surrounding the optic nerves. There are orbital hypertelorism, shrunken globes, and retinal thickening.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.11100008/asset/images/large/100008fig04.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 4: Axial unenhanced CT image of the chest. The ribs have an oar-shaped configuration, and the clavicles are thickened.'}]]

history: A 43-year-old man presented to the urologist with a 1-week history of left testicular discomfort associated with mild swelling. There was no history of pyrexia or scrotal trauma. Urogenital examination revealed a small left-sided hydrocele but no palpable mass. At general physical examination, the patient had macrocrania, palmar hyperkeratosis, and multiple cutaneous papules. Relevant clinical history included a large abdominal wall lipoma excised at 4 years of age. The patient had seven siblings, two of whom had macrocrania, a sister who had hyperthyroidism, and another sister in whom breast cancer was diagnosed while she was in her early thirties. Ultrasonography (US) of the testes was performed (Figure).
findings: Longitudinal (Fig 1a, 1b) and axial (Fig 1c) US of the testes revealed multiple randomly distributed nonshadowing intratesticular hyperechoic masses of varying sizes. The testes were normal in size and contour. Small-volume hydroceles were seen bilaterally (Fig 1a, 1c). Color Doppler examination revealed minimal vascular flow within the masses (Fig 1d). The epididymes were normal in appearance (Fig 1e, 1f).

history: A 75-year-old man presented with a 1-week history of fever, chills, arthralgia, and a sense of generalized weakness. He also had double vision for 1 day associated with one episode of urinary incontinence and an erythematous rash, which started on his neck and moved to his extremities. His medical history included a recurrent rash on his extremities since 2004. A prior skin biopsy revealed acute neutrophilic dermatoses.
findings: Multiple patchy high-signal-intensity lesions were seen in the midbrain on T2-weighted (Fig 1) and fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) (Fig 2) MR images. These lesions showed restricted diffusion on diffusion-weighted MR images (Fig 3). No significant enhancement was seen on postgadolinium T1-weighted MR images (Fig 4).

Bayer Healthcare Pharmaceuticals, Wayne, NJ) MR image (1900/3.37/1100) does not show any contrast enhancement in the areas of abnormal T2 and FLAIR signal intensity.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.11092052/asset/images/large/092052fig05.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 5: Histopathologic slide shows diffuse dermal infiltration by neutrophils and leukocytoclastic debris (black arrowhead) without definite evidence of structural vasculitis (white arrowhead). Epidermis is also visible (arrow). The histologic appearance is consistent with neutrophilic dermatosis, which is compatible with Sweet syndrome. (Hematoxylin-eosin stain; original magnification ×100.)'}]]

history: A 61-year-old woman who had recently undergone resection of a left hepatic lobe mass visited our institution for a second opinion. Prior to hepatic resection, she had presented to a local emergency room with sudden-onset severe right-sided abdominal pain. Computed tomography (CT) performed at that time for suspicion of a renal stone revealed hepatic masses.
findings: Contrast material–enhanced CT revealed that the portal vein was absent and that the superior mesenteric vein joined by the splenic vein drained directly into the inferior vena cava. Consequently, the hepatic artery was the primary blood supply to the liver. The liver was within normal limits for size and configuration, but multiple hypoattenuating lesions, only a few of which are shown here, were noted scattered throughout both lobes (Fig 1). On MR images, almost all of the lesions were nearly isointense to the liver on unenhanced in-phase gradient-echo T1-weighted images (Fig 2a, 2b) and on T2-weighted images (Fig 3a). On out-of-phase gradient-echo T1-weighted images (Fig 2c, 2d), there was a substantial homogeneous signal intensity decrease in all the lesions, suggesting the presence of intralesional fat. MR imaging performed with a hepatobiliary specific contrast agent, gadoxetate disodium (Eovist; Bayer Healthcare Pharmaceuticals, Wayne, NJ), demonstrated that the hepatic masses showed only mild enhancement during the arterial phase on T1-weighted images (Fig 3c); the lesions remained hypointense relative to the liver on 5- (not shown) and 20-minute postcontrast T1-weighted images with little gadoxetate disodium enhancement (Fig 3d).
diagnosis: Congenital Absence of the Portal Vein with Hepatic Adenomatosis

history: A 23-year-old woman presented to a plastic surgeon with gradually worsening left facial asymmetry and pain. The asymmetry started in her early teens and gradually progressed, with occasional pain. A physical examination revealed that the left side of her face was smaller than the right side, with tightening of her skin and loss of subcutaneous fat. Her left eye was slightly sunken. Left eye visual acuity was normal. There was no facial nerve palsy or trigeminal dysfunction. Mastication was normal. She had no other underlying illness. She was referred for computed tomography (CT). Unenhanced CT of the face was performed, and images were viewed with bone and soft-tissue window settings (Figs 1–3). Volume-rendered reformations (Fig 4) were also obtained.
findings: Unenhanced CT of the face (Figs 1, 2) revealed generalized atrophy of the soft tissues of the left hemiface. The mastication muscles, hemitongue, submandibular and parotid glands, and parapharyngeal and subcutaneous tissues were smaller on the left side of this patient’s face than on the right side. The fat planes on the left side were not as well defined as those on the right. There was overall volume loss on the left side of the patient’s face, with minor leftward deviation of the aerodigestive tract. The nasal septum was deviated to the left with a bony spur (Fig 3). There was loss of subcutaneous fat volume on the left side of the face, the platysma muscle had a relatively thinned appearance, and the left side of the face appeared sunken. The loss of tissue volume was restricted to the left side of the face and did not cross the midline. Maxillary dentition showed slight asymmetry, with posterior nonocclusion on the left side of the face (Fig 4). There were several nonspecific prominent bilateral level 1 and 2 lymph nodes that were not pathologially enlarged by size criteria (1,2).

history: A 46-year-old man was evaluated for worsening fatigue, increasing emotional lability, and minimal libido of 1 year duration. He recently began experiencing shortness of breath on exertion. Physical examination revealed a fatigued man without evidence of jaundice. The most recent liver biopsy revealed early cirrhosis. The results of neurologic examination were unremarkable. The patient did not have any children. Notable laboratory values were as follows: hemoglobin, 10.9 g/dL (normal range, 13.0–17.5 g/dL); aspartate transaminase, 48 U/L (0.8 μkat/L) (normal range, 0–40 U/L [0–0.67 μkat/L]); serum iron, 200 μg/mL (35.8 μmol/L) (normal range, 40–170 μg/mL [7.2–30.4 μmol/L]); ferritin, 1402 ng/mL (3150 pmol/L) (normal range, 24–336 ng/mL [54–755 pmol/L]); transferrin saturation, 87.7% (normal range, 15%–50%); and testosterone, 0.06 ng/mL (0.002 nmol/L) (normal range, 2–8 ng/mL [0.07–0.28 nmol/L]). Magnetic resonance (MR) imaging of the brain and pituitary gland was performed (Figs 1, 2). All contrast-enhanced images were obtained with 14 mL of gadopentetate dimeglumine (Magnevist; Bayer Healthcare, Wayne, NJ).
findings: Sagittal and coronal T1- and T2-weighted MR images of the brain were acquired by using a 1.5-T MR imager (Avanto; Siemens, Erlangen, Germany). The T1-weighted images were obtained before and after intravenous administration of gadopentetate dimeglumine. The coronal T1-weighted images were fat saturated. The T2-weighted images were obtained without administration of intravenous contrast material.

findings: Multiplanar MR images of the thorax showed a well-circumscribed round mass that measured 5.9 × 6.7 × 7.2 cm in the anterior-posterior, medial-lateral, and cranial-caudal directions, respectively, within the lower aspect of the middle mediastinum. The mass displaced the distal esophagus leftward and compressed the inferior vena cava but appeared separate from the surrounding mediastinal structures without invasion (Figs 1–4). T1-weighted images acquired with the three-dimensional gradient-echo volumetric interpolated brain examination sequence (4.89/1.51; 15° flip angle) showed mildly increased and heterogeneous signal intensity relative to that of muscle (Fig 1). There was no relevant signal loss within the mediastinal mass when fat saturation was applied (Fig 2). The mass exhibited increased mildly heterogeneous T2-weighted signal (half-Fourier rapid acquisition with relaxation enhancement sequence, 1000/62, 150° flip angle), and the cisterna chyli, which is located just inferiorly, was dilated (Fig 3). There appeared to be a thin T2 intense track extending from the inferior aspect of the mass toward the cisterna chyli (Fig 3). The mass had a thin wall that enhanced mildly after intravenous administration of 20 mL of contrast material (Magnevist; Bayer Healthcare Pharmaceuticals, Leverkusen, Germany) (Fig 4).
images: [[], [{'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.12092468/asset/images/large/092468fig01.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 1: Unenhanced axial T1-weighted three-dimensional gradient-echo MR image of the thorax (repetition time msec/echo time msec, 4.89/1.51) shows a mildly hyperintense round mass (arrow) within the lower middle mediastinum displacing the esophagus leftward and the inferior vena cava anteriorly.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.12092468/asset/images/large/092468fig02.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 2: Unenhanced sagittal T1-weighted three-dimensional gradient-echo MR image of the thorax with fat suppression (4.89/1.51) shows a lower mediastinal mass (arrow) that remains mildly hyperintense with fat saturation.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.12092468/asset/images/large/092468fig03.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 3: Unenhanced coronal T2-weighted MR image of thorax (1000/62) shows heterogeneous hyperintense mass (small arrow) that appears distinct from surrounding mediastinal structures. A thin T2 intense track extends from cisterna chyli toward the mass (large arrow). The cisterna chyli appears dilated. (Reprinted, with permission, from Mortman KD. Ann Thorac Surg 2009;88(6):2006–2008.)'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.12092468/asset/images/large/092468fig04.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 4: Contrast material–enhanced axial T1-weighted fat-saturated three-dimensional gradient-echo MR image of the thorax (4.89/1.51) shows mild enhancement of the thin wall (arrows) of the mediastinal mass.'}]]

history: A 60-year-old white woman with a history of a cutaneous malignant melanoma excised 10 years prior presented with a 5-month history of severe midback pain and occasional painful lesions on her hands and feet. She received a trial dose of naproxen (Naprosyn; Roche Pharmaceuticals, Nutley, NJ) for 1 month, systemic corticosteroids, narcotic analgesics, a one-time dose of intramuscular ceftriaxone, and muscle relaxants without relief. There was no history of oral retinoid use. Because of intractable pain and a 5–10-lb (2.3–4.5-kg) weight loss, she was admitted to our institution for evaluation. Subsequent physical examination revealed a well-healed melanoma excision scar and pustules on her palms and soles. Radiographic and magnetic resonance (MR) imaging of the thoracic spine were performed to determine the cause of her back pain (Figs 1, 2). Chest computed tomography (CT) was performed as a routine staging examination to check for melanoma metastasis (Fig 3).
findings: MR imaging findings at the T7 and T8 vertebral bodies included bone marrow signal abnormality, a vertebral body corner cortical erosion, disk space narrowing, and prevertebral soft-tissue enhancement (Figs 1, 2). Chest CT revealed a mottled and thickened appearance of several upper thoracic posterior ribs, as seen in Figure 3. There was no evidence of erosions or sclerosis in the sternocostoclavicular region. There was no evidence of sacroiliitis or other skeletal abnormalities. A bone scan revealed mild to moderate tracer uptake within the T7 and T8 vertebral bodies. No significant tracer uptake was seen elsewhere within the skeleton.
diagnosis: Synovitis Acne Pustulosis Hyperostosis Osteitis (SAPHO) Syndrome

history: A 70-year-old woman was referred to the pulmonology clinic for progressive dyspnea on exertion over 15 years, with acceleration in the past year. The cause of her symptoms was unknown, and empirical treatment with inhaled bronchodilators and oral prednisone helped only slightly. In the past 3–4 months, she had developed chest pain on exertion. She had a 25-pack-year smoking history, but she had quit smoking 30 years ago. She had no known history of lung disease, malignancy, or connective tissue disorder. She denied any past exposure to birds or environmental fibrogenic agents. She had no cough, fever, or weight loss. There were bibasilar crackles at auscultation.
findings: Chest radiography (Fig 1) revealed dense branching opacities and numerous basal-predominant small calcified pulmonary nodules. Thin-section CT (Fig 2) revealed multiple dense nodules that were most numerous in the lung bases and included large lobulated subpleural calcifications. There were also basal cysts, and many of the calcified nodules were associated within the cyst walls or located within the cysts. In addition, there were irregular calcified linear opacities, as seen on the chest radiograph. There were no thickened interlobular septa. Mild centrilobular emphysema was also present. A technetium 99m methylene diphosphonate bone examination (images not shown) was performed later to evaluate rib tenderness and revealed technetium 99m uptake in the lung bases.

history: A 32-year-old female African Portuguese immigrant from Angola reported a progressive increase in abdominal girth for the past year with no other associated problems. The patient denied current or past substantial alcohol ingestion or toxic exposure. A physical examination revealed abdominal distention and splenomegaly; otherwise, the findings were unremarkable. Her medical history included chronic human immunodeficiency virus infection discovered in 2000 (10 years duration). She had been undergoing highly active antiretroviral therapy since that time. This therapy consisted of administration of (a) lamivudine (150 mg taken twice a day) and zidovudine (300 mg taken twice a day) for the first 2 years; (b) stavudine (30 mg taken twice a day), didanosine (250 mg taken daily), and efavirenz (600 mg taken daily) for the next 6 years; (c) abacavir (600 mg taken daily), lamivudine (300 mg taken daily), tenofovir (300 mg taken daily), and efavirenz (600 mg taken daily) for the next year; and (d) tenofovir (300 mg taken daily), emtricitabine (200 mg taken daily), and atazanavir (300 mg taken daily) from 2009 until present.
findings: Abdominal multidetector computed tomography (CT) was performed after oral administration of 900 mL of barium sulfate (4.6% weight-to-weight ratio, 4.9% weight-to-volume oral suspension) (E-Z-CT; Bracco Imaging, Milan, Italy) diluted at a 1.1% weight-to-weight ratio. Three acquisitions were made, one before and two after intravenous injection of 120 mL of iobitridol administered at a rate of 3 mL/sec (Xenetix 300; Guerbet, Villepinte, France), in the late hepatic arterial phase of enhancement (35-second delay) and in the portal venous phase of enhancement (70-second delay) (Figs 1–6).

history: A 57-year-old man with a 10-year history of shortness of breath and productive cough presented to the pulmonary clinic with acute deterioration and increasing mucopurulent sputum that was unresponsive to antibiotics. Over the past 10 years, he had undergone intermittent treatment with bronchodilators for a presumed diagnosis of asthma. During this time, no pulmonary function testing (PFT) had been performed. He had never smoked, and he was not taking any other medications. His medical history was unremarkable except for occasional hospitalization for a chronic gastrointestinal condition.
findings: The axial and coronal CT images (Figs 1, 2) showed diffuse circumferential thickening of the proximal tracheobronchial tree, with no substantial narrowing. There was bibasal cylindrical bronchiectasis, with bronchial wall thickening and distal mucus plugging (Fig 3). There were no enlarged lymph nodes. Virtual reconstruction bronchoscopy of the trachea (Fig 4) showed mucosal thickening, with absence of the normally visualized tracheal rings, which was due to mucosal edema.

history: A 19-month-old previously healthy male infant born by uncomplicated vaginal delivery presented to a local emergency department after he developed a fever and, subsequently, a new complex partial seizure. The seizure was described as “left-sided with arm flexion and lower extremity external rotation.”
findings: Unenhanced head CT (Fig 1) revealed an isolated hyperdense extra-axial mass lesion associated with the dural surface along the right aspect of the anterior interhemispheric falx cerebri. MR imaging enabled us to confirm the presence of an avidly enhancing dural-based mass (Figs 5, 6), which showed marked T2 shortening relative to gray matter (Fig 2) and moderately reduced diffusion (Fig 3). A mild degree of focal mass effect was seen in the right frontal lobe, without secondary edema. Spectroscopic analysis showed a relatively elevated choline peak and diminutive N-acetylaspartate (NAA) and creatine peaks (Fig 6).

history: A 19-year-old man with refractory epilepsy since age 14 years was referred for magnetic resonance (MR) imaging of the brain. During the past 5 years, he had experienced an average of one seizure per month. Each seizure was characterized by a cephalic aura followed by behavioral arrest, tonic left-sided deviation of the head, and bending of the whole trunk to the left side. Current medications included carbamazepine and clobazam. At electroencephalography, epileptiform discharges from both the right centroparietal region and the midline centroparietal region were recorded. The findings of a neurologic examination were unremarkable (Figs 1–5).
findings: Brain MR imaging (Figs 1–5) revealed a cystlike, wedge-shaped well-marginated intraaxial mass located in the right occipital lobe that measured approximately 3.4 × 2.2 × 3.0 cm (anteroposterior, laterolateral, and craniocaudal diameters, respectively).

There is a left-sided cortical-based lesion in the frontal lobe, localized in the medial part of the precentral gyrus. The lesion appears as a cyst with an enhancing mural nodule and is accompanied by an adjacent dural tail (arrow). The lesion was removed surgically, and pathologic analysis indicated it was a PXA.'}]]

history: A 76-year-old previously healthy woman presented to her primary care physician with a 2-week history of a right groin bulge and mild intermittent dull pain in the right lower quadrant. Nothing she did made the pain better or worse. She denied having fever, dysuria, constipation, nausea, or emesis. By the time she was seen in the emergency department, her pain had resolved. Physical examination revealed a small, firm, and tender right groin mass. Laboratory tests revealed a normal white blood cell count of 6600/×L (6.6 · 109/L) (normal range, 4000–11 000/μL [4.0–11.0 × 109/L]). The only abnormal laboratory values noted were amylase and glucose levels, which were mildly elevated at 108 U/L (1.8 μkat/L) (normal range, 0–100 U/L [0–1.667 μkat/L]) and 139 mg/dL (7.71 mmol/L) (normal range, 70–105 mg/dL [3.9–5.8 mmol/L]), respectively.
findings: MR imaging of the pelvis was performed with a 1.5-T MR imager (Symphony; Siemens Medical Solutions, Erlangen, Germany). Figure 1a shows a T1 hypointense 9-mm ovoid lesion, with directly adjacent T1 hyperintensity similar in signal to that of subcutaneous adipose tissue. A T1 hypointense rim surrounds this lesion. In addition, there is a faint T1 hypointense line encompassing the entire region. The abnormality is located medial to the femoral artery and vein and lateral to the pubic tubercle. Fat-suppressed T2-weighted MR imaging was performed (Fig 1b). A rounded lesion was noted in the right groin with surrounding soft-tissue stranding and fluid.

history: A 53-year old woman was admitted to the hospital with a 2-week history of central chest pain, shortness of breath, and syncope. The patient had a history of hysterectomy and right salpingo-oophorectomy for uterine leiomyomas, with right broad ligament involvement 1 year previously. Clinical examination and laboratory tests at admission revealed normal findings, including normal serum creatine kinase and troponin levels. Electrocardiography revealed only mild sinus tachycardia, with no features of myocardial ischemia or infarction. The patient underwent diagnostic imaging, including computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance (MR) imaging of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis (Figs 1–Figs 6).
findings: An intravenous hypoattenuating mass originating in the right ovarian vein and extending into the proximal inferior vena cava (IVC) and right atrium is seen on coronal and sagittal reconstructed contrast material–enhanced CT images (Figs 1, 2). The right ovarian vein arises from the suspensory ligament of the ovary within the right side of the pelvis. It extends superiorly into the abdomen anterior to the right psoas muscle and lateral to the right ovarian artery and right ureter. The right ovarian vein then crosses anterior to the ureter prior to entering the proximal IVC at its anterior surface, just inferior to the level of the main renal vessels. The mass is located anteriorly within the lumen of the proximal cava, with no involvement of the main renal veins, as seen on an axial contrast-enhanced CT image (Fig 3). It has heterogeneous T2-weighted hyperintensity and mild patchy enhancement after contrast material administration (as seen on an axial T2-weighted MR image and a coronal fat-suppressed contrast-enhanced T1-weighted MR image, respectively) (Figs 4, 5). Enhancement of the mass is better appreciated on the MR image than on the CT image. Aside from a simple left renal cyst (Fig 1), the intraabdominal parenchymal organs are otherwise normal on the CT and MR images. Intracardiac involvement in the form of a dumbbell-shaped hypointense mass in the right atrium and right ventricle is seen on an axial fat-suppressed T1-weighted MR image of the thorax (Fig 6).
diagnosis: Intravenous Leiomyomatosis with Intracaval and Intracardiac Involvement

history: A previously healthy 5-year-old boy presented with a 2-week history of jaundice, pruritis, and fatigue. Further evaluation revealed hyperbilirubinemia, an elevated transaminase level, and pancytopenia. Ultrasonography performed at presentation revealed hepatomegaly without splenomegaly. Laboratory evaluation for infectious and noninfectious causes of subacute hepatitis was unremarkable, with the exception of serologic evidence of prior Epstein-Barr virus and cytomegalovirus infections. Liver biopsy was performed, but the results did not enable us to identify a definitive cause of liver injury. Contemporaneous bone marrow biopsy performed due to pancytopenia showed findings of aplastic anemia. A course of steroids resulted in resolution of the transaminitis, hyperbilirubinemia, and hepatomegaly; however pancytopenia persisted. Repeat bone marrow biopsy 1 month later showed progression to less than 5% cellularity. The combination of subacute hepatitis and aplastic anemia were suspected to be due to an unidentified viral cause.
findings: Initial CT through the upper abdomen revealed marked wall thickening involving the distal gastric body and antrum (Fig 1). A few thickened folds were also observed involving the more proximal stomach (Fig 1b). No other abnormality was identified in the remainder of the abdomen or pelvis. A single-contrast upper GI series showed marked fold thickening involving the gastric body and antrum (Fig 2), with some areas having a polyp-like appearance. PET/CT was performed to address radiologic and clinical concern for gastric lymphoma and showed markedly increased metabolic activity that affected the thickened portions of the stomach (maximum standardized uptake value [SUV], 13.2) (Fig 3); this finding was deemed nonspecific but suspicious for a malignant process.

history: A 64-year-old male nonsmoker with a history of hypertension and morbus Ménière (Ménière disease) who had undergone a previous appendectomy presented with fatigue and bradycardia. Laboratory tests did not reveal any relevant abnormalities. At physical examination, normal breath sounds and no heart murmurs were heard. Chest radiography demonstrated a normal cardiac silhouette and clear lung fields. Electrocardiography showed sinus rhythm with a normal axis. The indication for transthoracic echocardiography was evaluation of bradycardia of unknown origin. Because of the suggestion of a structure closely related to the pulmonary valve, transesophageal echocardiography was performed. For further tissue characterization, cardiac magnetic resonance (MR) imaging also was performed, and the resultant images are shown (Figs 1–4; Movie E1, E2 [online]).
findings: Transesophageal echocardiography revealed a 1-cm mobile round mass attached to the posterior leaflet of the pulmonary valve (Fig 1). During systole, the entire mass prolapsed into the main pulmonary trunk. There was also an accompanying mild (grade 1 of 4) pulmonary regurgitation. Most of the lesion was hyperechoic, but a few echolucencies were suspected within the mass. In addition, a three-dimensional transesophageal echocardiographic examination was performed (Fig 2; Movie 1 [online]). These images show even better the prolapse during systole in the right ventricular outflow tract and the slightly irregular contour of the small mass.
diagnosis: Papillary Fibroelastoma of the Pulmonary Valve

history: A 40-year-old man presented with a 6-month history of progressive illness associated with mild shortness of breath on exertion, dysphagia, and lower limb hyperesthesia. No headache, nausea, vomiting, or fever was identified. The patient denied previous trauma or recent weight loss. His medical history was otherwise uneventful. Physical examination revealed no signs of peripheral motor deficit or abnormal reflexes. Imaging was then ordered (Figs 1, 2).
findings: Magnetic resonance (MR) imaging revealed a large, expansile complex cystic lesion that was centered in the medulla and extended to the level of the middle aspect of the C3 vertebral body. The lesion was separated by a thin septum into two components. The more cephalad component showed signal intensity that was nearly identical to that of cerebrospinal fluid on both T1- and T2-weighted images. However, moderately high signal intensity of this component on fluid-attenuated inversion recovery images indicated greater complexity of the fluid and, thus, not simple cerebrospinal fluid. The lower component exhibited high signal intensity on T1- and T2-weighted images, as well as on fluid-attenuated inversion recovery images, with a fluid-fluid level that indicated blood products. In addition, the lower locule had a hypointense rim that indicated the presence of a rim of hemosiderin deposition from repeated episodes of hemorrhage (Fig 1). No obvious solid component or contrast enhancement was noted (Fig 2). There was no evidence of Chiari malformation or hydrocephalus.
diagnosis: Giant Hemorrhagic Syringomyelia and Syringobulbia Mimicking Intramedullary Neoplasm

Fluid-fluid level is clearly identified in the cervical component (black arrows). (d) Sagittal fluid-attenuated inversion recovery image (9000/112) exhibits hyperintensity of the lesion, although the cervical component appears to be much brighter than the medullar component. A dark hypointense rim around the lower locule is seen on all images, regardless of sequence.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.12110071/asset/images/large/110071fig02.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 2: Coronal contrast material–enhanced (287 mg/mL gadodiamide, Ominiscan; GE Healthcare Canada, Mississauga, Ontario, Canada) T1-weighted MR image (451/10) of the craniocervical region shows no enhancement of the lesion.'}]]

history: A 58-year-old white man with a history of hypothyroidism, chronic kidney disease, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease was brought to the emergency department by his brother for evaluation of substantial weight loss of 18 pounds, polyuria, and poor appetite for 4 weeks. The patient had a long psychiatric history of paranoid schizophrenia, with multiple hospitalizations in the past for psychosis and poor impulse control. He also had a remote history of long-term lithium use.
findings: Computed tomography (CT) (Fig 1) demonstrated numerous small renal cysts in both kidneys; these cysts were mostly millimetric in size. Findings were initially thought to represent a variant of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease; however, there was no known family history of renal cysts, renal disease, or both. Moreover, the kidneys were normal in size, and no liver, splenic, or pancreatic cysts were identified. Additional magnetic resonance (MR) imaging (Figs 2, 3) was performed at subsequent admission 1 year later for further clarification of multiple indeterminate hypoattenuating renal lesions.
images: [[{'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.12111735/asset/images/large/111735fig01.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 1: Contrast material–enhanced axial computed tomographic image (section thickness, 5 mm) obtained in the nephrographic phase at the level of the kidneys.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.12111735/asset/images/large/111735fig02.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 2: Coronal half-Fourier single-shot turbo spin-echo breath-hold magnetic resonance (MR) image (repetition time msec/echo time msec, 1000/93) of the kidneys.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.12111735/asset/images/large/111735fig03.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 3: Axial fat-suppressed T1-weighted MR image (3.31/1.48) of the kidneys obtained 70 seconds after intravenous administration of gadolinium-containing contrast material (14 mL of gadopentetate dimeglumine, 0.5 mol/L, Magnevist; Bayer Healthcare Pharmaceuticals, Wayne, NJ).'}], [{'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.13111801/asset/images/large/111801fig01.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 1: Axial postcontrast CT image (section thickness, 5 mm) obtained in the nephrographic phase at the level of the kidneys shows symmetric uniform multiple microcysts (predominantly 1–2 mm) in the renal cortex and medulla. No solid masses were identified.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.13111801/asset/images/large/111801fig02.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 2: Coronal half-Fourier single-shot turbo spin-echo breath-hold MR image (repetition time msec/echo time msec, 1000/93) of the kidneys shows abundant high-signal-intensity microcysts in the bilateral renal cortical and medullary distributions. No enhancing solid masses were identified.'}]]

history: A 42-year-old former truck driver presented with dysarthria, dysphagia, and worsening of walking difficulty. The patient’s history revealed that he had developed right hand tremors at 15 years of age, gait disturbance with dragging of the right foot at 32 years of age, and a tendency to fall at 35 years of age. At clinical examination, no visual disturbance was identified, and eye movements were well preserved. Only mild cognitive impairment was noted. Generalized hypotonia was seen, which was accompanied by hyperreflexia. Indication of hypokinesia was seen, as evidenced by micrographia. Mild dysmetria was detected. Hepatic and renal function tests, serum electrolyte level, ceruloplasmin level, iron level, and the total iron binding capacity were normal. Serum ferritin levels were 5 mg/L. Cerebrospinal fluid was unremarkable. Electroencephalography revealed no abnormality. The patient’s deceased mother also had a similar movement disorder. Computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance (MR) imaging of the brain were performed (Figs 1, 2).
findings: CT revealed markedly hypodense basal ganglia bilaterally, which was consistent with the cystic changes. Ventricular dilatation was observed, representing atrophic changes in the brain (Fig 1).
diagnosis: Neuroferritinopathy—A Brain Iron Accumulation and Neurodegenerative Disorder

history: A previously healthy 48-year-old man presented with progressive asthenia and fatigue of several weeks duration associated with sporadic episodes of diarrhea and a 22-kg weight loss in the previous 6 months. He was afebrile. Physical examination revealed jaundice and a palpable epigastric mass. He reported a 10-pack-year smoking history and moderate alcohol intake (30–40 g/d). The patient had no previous oncologic history, and he was seronegative for the human immunodeficiency virus, as well as for hepatitis B and C. Laboratory tests revealed a hemoglobin level of 6.3 g/dL (normal range, 13.8–18.0 g/dL) and elevated levels of serum liver enzymes (alanine transaminase level, 98 U/L [normal level, <60 U/L]; aspartate transaminase level, 121 U/L [normal level, <40 U/L]), γ-glutamyl transpeptidase (2232 U/L [normal range, 0–51 U/L), total bilirubin (5.2 mg/dL [88.9 µmol/L]; normal range, 0.1–1.2 mg/dL [1.71–20.52 µmol/L]) and direct bilirubin (4.7 mg/dL [80.37 µmol/L]; normal range, 0.1–0.4 mg/dL [1.71–6.84 µmol/L]). Serum α-fetoprotein level was elevated (15 300 ng/mL; normal level, <10 ng/mL). The remaining tumor marker levels—including carcinoembryonic antigen, CA-19-9 (carbohydrate antigen 19-9), CA-125 (carbohydrate antigen 125), and neuron-specific enolase—were normal.
findings: Transabdominal US showed a large fairly smooth and predominantly hyperechoic solid mass located near the head of the pancreas (Fig 1). Atrophy of the distal pancreas and a double duct sign were also noted.
diagnosis: Periampullary Hepatoid Adenocarcinoma with Duodenal Invasion

history: A 48-year-old woman presented to the emergency department with a 3-month history of increasing left-sided back pain radiating to the left anterior chest. She reported no relief with nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs. She also reported chest tightness and dyspnea. She denied fever, nausea, vomiting, unintentional weight loss, or history of trauma to the area. At examination, she was tender to palpation of the left posterior chest wall. She had decreased range of motion in the back, without any loss of strength. Her white blood cell count and basic metabolic panel were unremarkable. Chest radiography, computed tomography (CT), and magnetic resonance (MR) imaging of the chest were performed. Her pain lessened with narcotic medication (Figs 1–4).
findings: The posteroanterior and lateral radiographs of the chest showed a posterior mediastinal mass (Fig 1). Contrast material–enhanced chest CT, ordered by the emergency medicine physicians to work up the abnormal chest radiograph, revealed a paravertebral mass adjacent to the T6 level, encasing the thoracic aorta and abutting the left atrium (Fig 2a). The mass contained internal coarse calcifications in a ring and arc pattern (Fig 2b). The noncalcified portion of the mass was hypoattenuated when compared with muscle, with an average attenuation of 20–35 HU. The mass resulted in cortical destruction of the adjacent thoracic vertebral body and extended into the surrounding soft tissue. The cardiothoracic surgeons and neurosurgeons requested thoracic MR imaging to evaluate involvement of the spine. The mass was heterogeneously isointense to skeletal muscle on T1-weighted images (not shown) and heterogeneously hyperintense to skeletal muscle on T2-weighted images (Fig 3). The MR images also showed bone destruction of the adjacent vertebral body and enabled us to confirm aortic encasement by the tumor. Infiltration into the left atrial wall was not shown; however, evaluation for this was limited by lack of function images. There was heterogeneous contrast enhancement within the mass; this finding is consistent with a vascularized mass (Fig 4). CT-guided percutaneous needle biopsy of the lesion was performed by using an 18-gauge core biopsy needle, which enabled us to make a definitive diagnosis.

findings: Unenhanced multidetector computed tomography (CT) of the head (5-mm transverse images with 2-mm coronal and sagittal reconstructions) showed bilateral homogeneous soft-tissue attenuation masses (Fig 1, A) in the superolateral aspects of the orbits in the expected location of the lacrimal glands. The masses involved both orbital and palpebral portions of the glands. The adjacent bony structures were intact. Additional sagittal reconstructions showed the mass effect of these lesions on the superior and lateral recti muscles (Fig 1, B). There was no cerebral abnormality.

history: A 32-year-old man presented to the emergency department with a slowly worsening headache and right scalp swelling in the past few weeks. The patient’s medical history included recently diagnosed Graves disease, which was controlled with medication, and human immunodeficiency virus infection with a CD4 cell count greater than 500 cells per microliter and an undetectable viral load. Otherwise, the patient recently had been in good health.
findings: Contrast-enhanced CT of the head revealed two avidly enhancing extraaxial masses with mass effect on the brain. There was evidence of adjacent osseous destruction and extracalvarial extension, particularly in the larger right-sided mass (Fig 1). MR images of the lesion again showed that it was highly vascular and likely extradural. The lesions were very heterogeneous, with marked enhancement and multiple areas of internal hemorrhage (Fig 2). Flow voids were present, but they were difficult to see because of the marked heterogeneity of the lesion. CT of the abdomen revealed a large enhancing heterogeneous retroperitoneal mass separate from the kidneys, adrenal glands, and pancreas (Fig 3). Hypodense areas in the liver were also noted.
diagnosis: Malignant Paraganglioma Manifesting with Calvarial Metastases

history: A 64-year-old man was referred to our hospital with a 6-month history of abdominal pain and fullness associated with asthenia. A physical examination revealed a large palpable lump in the epigastrum and right hypochondrium. Laboratory analysis revealed elevated γ-glutamyl transpeptidase (103 IU/L [1.71 μkat/L]) and alkaline phosphatase (104 IU/L [1.73 μkat/L]) levels. Bilirubin (0.4 mg/dL [6.84 μmol/L]) and transaminase (alanine aminotransferase, 26 IU/L [0.43 μkat/L]; aspartate aminotransferase, 25 IU/L [0.42 μkat/L]) levels were normal. The α-fetoprotein level was normal (3 μg/L). Tests for hepatitis B and C viral markers were negative. The patient had no history of alcoholism. His medical history was marked by a prior right colectomy for fungal infection, lung surgery for a pulmonary abscess, surgery for an inguinal hernia, and diabetes. Abdominal ultrasonography and contrast material–enhanced computed tomography (CT) revealed a large, well-defined isolated hepatic mass in the left lobe that measured 23 cm in diameter. No extrahepatic lesions were found during work-up. Liver magnetic resonance (MR) imaging (Intera 1.5 T; Philips Medical Systems, Best, the Netherlands) and combined positron emission tomography (PET) and CT (Gemini TF; Philips Medical Systems) with fluorine 18 (18F) fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) were performed for further evaluation (Figs 1–4).
findings: The mass was heterogeneous on MR images, with slight hyperintensity on T2-weighted images and slight hypointensity on T1-weighted images (Fig 1a–1c). Serpentine vessels, which appeared as flow voids, were observed through the mass (Fig 1a). No central scar was observed. The rest of the liver parenchyma did not show any dysmorphic changes (Fig 1b). Respiratory-triggered diffusion-weighted (DW) imaging (b = 1000 sec/mm2) revealed increased signal intensity compared with that of a normal liver (Fig 2a). The ADC of the mass varied from 0.9 to 1.8 mm2/sec (Fig 2b). The enhancement pattern after intravenous injection of a gadolinium chelate showed progressive and centripetal enhancement (Fig 3).
diagnosis: Solitary Fibrous Tumor of the Liver

history: A 70-year-old asymptomatic woman with a history of hypertension visited her primary care physician for a check-up. The findings of a physical examination performed at this time were unremarkable. Laboratory results were remarkable for an increased creatinine level of 1.62 mg/dL (143.21 μmol/L), which was up from her baseline level of 1.02 mg/dL (90.17 μmol/L). Renal ultrasonography (US) and subsequent computed tomography (CT) of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis were performed (Figs 1–4).
findings: Renal US revealed a large echogenic left renal mass (Fig 1). Contrast material–enhanced CT of the abdomen revealed a mixed fat and soft-tissue density mass within the left upper kidney, with fatty tumor thrombus invading the left renal vein (Figs 2, 3). Cysts within the left upper kidney laterally and within the interpolar left kidney were noted incidentally. A cortical defect within the left renal upper pole (Fig 3) and multiple tumor vessels extending into the renal cortex (Figs 2, 3) were also noted. A focus of coarse calcification was noted along the distal aspect of the renal vein thrombus (Fig 3d). There were no other masses or enlarged lymph nodes. Subsequent CT of the chest revealed emboli composed of macroscopic fat within the right and left lower lobe pulmonary arteries (Fig 4).
diagnosis: Aggressive Angiomyolipoma with Renal Vein Thrombosis and Pulmonary Fat Embolus

history: A 55-year-old man presented with chronic epigastric pain lasting for about 1 year and without fever or vomiting. The abdomen was soft and tender at physical examination. Laboratory tests revealed unremarkable liver function, normal hemoglobin level, and normal amylase level. White blood cell count was normal, and there was no inflammatory syndrome. The patient’s medical history included pancreatic gastrinoma resected by means of left pancreatectomy 31 years before, hyperparathyroidism treated with subtotal parathyroidectomy 24 years before, and a slowly growing lung mass known for 9 years. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy was performed because of a suspected gastroduodenal ulcer. The results showed numerous small (<10 mm) gastric and duodenal ulcers and multiple 10–15-mm polypoid gastric masses.
findings: Contrast-enhanced abdominal multidetector CT showed a thickened nodular gastric wall. Nodules strongly enhanced during the arterial phase (Figs 1a, 2a) and were isoattenuated with the surrounding gastric wall during the portal venous phase (Figs 1b, 2b). Nodules were mainly located in the cardia and fundus and ranged in size from 4 to 15 mm (Fig 3).
diagnosis: Gastric Enterochromaffinlike Cell Tumors in a Patient with Type 1 Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia

history: A 55-year-old woman presented to our breast clinic with 1-year history of lancinating pain in the right breast that was exacerbated by blunt pressure and cold temperature. She denied any family history of breast cancer or any personal history of trauma, infection, or surgery of the breast. On clinical examination, exquisite pain was generated by simple light pressure over the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. Mammography (Fig 1) and ultrasounography (US) with Doppler analysis (Fig 2) of the right breast were painful but were performed with the least pressure possible.
findings: Bilateral mammograms (Fig 1) revealed an oval hyperdense mass in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast, with partially obscured margins and no microcalcifications. US examination of the right breast (Fig 2a) was extremely painful. Exquisite pain was generated when the probe precisely overlaid an oval, hypoechoic, well-circumscribed mildly lobulated superficially located mass that correlated with the mammographic finding. At color Doppler analysis and spectral assessment, this mass had arterial and venous vessels without shunting and an efferent vessel (Fig 2b, 2c).

history: A 57-year-old woman was referred to our institute in 2010 by a neurologist for a follow-up brain magnetic resonance (MR) examination. She had not experienced any acute change in symptoms, but unspecific unilateral hyperintensities in her left cerebral hemisphere had been noted at a previous MR examination in 2004. Since 2001, she had been repeatedly seen in neurology departments for recurrent episodes of clumsiness of her left hand and frequent headaches. Her other medical history was unremarkable, as were the findings of a neurologic examination. She was not born prematurely, she was not hypertensive, and she had not shown signs or symptoms suggestive of immunincompetence or autoimmune disease. There was no history of meningitis or encephalitis. A source for embolic foci could not be established. Serology indicated no previous cysticercosis infection. Her laboratory test results were normal. Since no other underlying cause had been previously considered, a radiologist from another institute postulated that her left hemispheric hyperintensities could be seen as a rudimentary expression of tuberous sclerosis lacking the classic clinical triad. The MR examination in our institution was performed to rule out progression (Figs 1–3). The resulting images were compared with those obtained in 2004 (Fig 4).
findings: MR imaging, performed with a 1.5-T unit, showed multiple cystic foci on the transverse images; these foci appeared tubular on the coronal images and were located in the cerebral white matter exclusively in the left hemisphere, including the left frontal superior and left frontal inferior gyri, left precentral gyrus, left postcentral gyrus, cingulate gyrus in the left hemisphere, and left putamen. The multiple confluent oval well-defined lesions were isointense to cerebrospinal fluid on coronal T2-weighted images (Fig 1). Some of the lesions were directly adjacent to confluent glovelike hyperintensities on fluid-attenuated inversion recovery MR images, without displaying the patchy characteristics of microvascular encephalopathy (Fig 2). There was no evidence of cytotoxic edema on the echo-planar diffusion-weighted MR images (Fig 3). Although the majority of the foci had no mass effect, the sulci of the left hemisphere were narrower than those of the right hemisphere. The cortex overlying the affected white matter was also thinned. The left hemispheric cystic lesions were, in most cases, smaller than 10 mm in diameter. Compared with the MR images obtained in 2004, the follow-up images obtained in 2010 did not show any interval change of the cystic foci (Fig 4).
diagnosis: Extensive Unilateral Widening of Virchow-Robin Spaces

history: A 77-year-old woman presented with pain in the right elbow of several years duration. There was no history of trauma, immunocompromise, or known malignancy. Blood chemistry tests revealed an alkaline phosphatase level of 93 U/L (1.6 μkat/L) (30–120 U/L [0.5–2.0 μkat/L]), a sodium level of 139 mmol/L (135–147 mmol/L), a potassium level of 4.4 mmol/L (3.4–5.0 mmol/L), a calcium level of 2.38 mmol/L (2.2–2.55 mmol/L), a phosphate level of 1.81 mmol/L (0.85–1.5 mmol/L), a C-reactive protein level of less than 5 mg/L (47.6 nmol/L), and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 41 mm/h (0–15 mm/h). Hematologic findings were normal.
findings: An anteroposterior radiograph of the humerus (Fig 1) showed well-defined small lytic defects in the distal humerus, with loss and thinning of the cortex and marked bone loss distally in a geographic and moth-eaten pattern. Osteoporosis was noted radiographically. No periosteal reaction, bone sclerosis, or soft-tissue swelling was visible. There was no soft-tissue calcification.

history: An 87-year-old white woman presented to our emergency department with a 2-day history of involuntary movements of the right upper and lower extremities. The movements increased with action, decreased with relaxation, and disappeared during sleep. The patient’s medical history included diabetes mellitus type 2, congestive heart failure, and hypertension. No history of parkinsonism or other neurologic disorders was reported. Furthermore, the patient had no prior history of dopamine antagonist or estrogen medication use. At admission, she was fully alert and oriented. A physical examination revealed her muscle tone and strength were normal on both sides; however, she reported transient weakness in the right limbs. There was no evidence of sensory impairment, and cranial nerves were normal. The deep tendon reflexes were symmetrically hypoactive. Her skin was pink, warm, and dry. Laboratory tests revealed poorly controlled diabetes mellitus, with a fasting blood glucose level of 410 mg/dL (22.8 mmol/L) and a hemoglobin A1C level of 18.0%. The urine examination was negative for ketones. Shortly after admission, the patient’s blood sugar was controlled with insulin; this led to a steady correction of glycemia in the subsequent days. At admission, the patient underwent unenhanced brain computed tomography (CT) (Fig 1). Magnetic resonance (MR) imaging of the brain was performed 2 days later (Fig 2). After she was discharged from the hospital, the involuntary movements progressively decreased over the next few weeks until they disappeared. Two months later, follow-up unenhanced brain CT (not shown) showed the absence of abnormal findings.
findings: Unenhanced CT of the head revealed slight and homogeneous increased attenuation in the left lentiform nucleus (Fig 1a, 1b). By using narrow window width and slightly higher center settings, there was markedly increased conspicuity of left lenticular nucleus hyperattenuation (Fig 1c, 1d). MR imaging of the brain performed 2 days after onset of hemiballism-hemichorea revealed abnormally strong hyperintense signal in the posterior portion of the left putamen on T1-weighted images (Fig 2a) and isointensity on T2-weighted images (Fig 2b). Diffusion-weighted images revealed normal signal intensity in the left putamen (Fig 2c). Follow-up unenhanced brain CT performed 2 months later showed that the abnormal hyperattenuated lesion in the left lenticular nucleus had completely resolved (not shown).

history: An 80-year-old woman presented to the on-call surgical team with a 2-day history of abdominal distention and vomiting. Clinical examination revealed a distended tympanic abdomen with generalized tenderness but no evidence of peritoneal signs at physical examination. Relevant surgical history included previous intervention for renal stones, cholecystectomy, and cardiovascular and respiratory comorbidities. Abdominal radiography was performed in the emergency department, and computed tomography (CT) was performed based on the radiographic findings (Figs 1–3).
findings: Both plain-film radiography and contrast material–enhanced CT showed multiple grossly dilated predominantly fluid-filled small-bowel loops and collapsed distal small-bowel findings, consistent with small-bowel obstruction (Figs 1, 2a) (1). The large angular calcific mass projected over the pelvis on the plain radiograph was shown to be within the ileum on CT images (Fig 2b) at the transition point. The right kidney was grossly atrophic and contained multiple stones. The left kidney was normal in appearance and contained no stones (Fig 3a, 3b). A fistula was seen between the right renal pelvis and the second part of the duodenum (Fig 3c, 3d). A small volume of ascites was present. There was no pneumobilia, and the patient’s status was postcholecystectomy.

history: This patient was a 20-month-old full-term girl who had not received any routine pediatric care. During a physical examination, left-sided leukocoria was detected. Subsequently, a left-sided cataract was diagnosed. The patient was sent for magnetic resonance (MR) imaging of the brain and orbits (Figs 1–3).
findings: MR imaging of the brain and orbits revealed left-sided microphthalmos and an abnormal funnel-shaped structure extending from the retrolental area to the region of the optic disc (Figs 1, 2). The lateral margins of the funnel were formed by the convexities of bilateral subretinal collections that were hyperintense on T1- and T2-weighted images. The axial images revealed the presence of a T2 hypointense (Fig 1) and T1 hyperintense (Fig 2) retrolental mass anterior to the vertex of the funnel. The morphology of the lens was also abnormal, and it can be seen best in Figure 1. Figure 3 is a composite of noncontrast and postcontrast T1-weighted coronal images obtained through the retrolental tissue and seen anterior to the center of the funnel in Figures 1 and 2, suggesting enhancement. In contradistinction, the subretinal collections have intrinsic T1 signal hyperintensity without enhancement. As best seen on the axial T2-weighted image in Figure 1, there is a linear central hypointensity extending from the retrolental mass through the center of the funnel to the optic disc, between the medial boundaries of the subretinal collections, consistent with persistence of Cloquet canal. Figure 2 also shows high signal intensity within the anterior chamber.
images: [[{'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.13110857/asset/images/large/radiol.13110857.fig1.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 1: Axial T2-weighted 1.5-T MR image (repetition time msec/echo time msec, 2500/120; 4-mm section thickness).'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.13110857/asset/images/large/radiol.13110857.fig2.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 2: Axial T1-weighted 1.5-T contrast material–enhanced (15 mL of intravenously injected gadopentetate dimeglumine, Magnevist; Bayer Healthcare Pharmaceuticals, Wayne, NJ) fat-saturated MR image (416/12, 3-mm section thickness).'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.13110857/asset/images/large/radiol.13110857.fig3.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 3: Composite of, A, coronal T1-weighted (500/12, 3-mm section thickness) and, B, coronal T1-weighted 1.5-T contrast-enhanced fat-saturated (516/12, 3-mm section thickness) MR images at the level of the horizontal line in the inset.'}], [{'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.14110856/asset/images/large/radiol.14110856.fig1.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 1: Axial T2-weighted 1.5-T MR image (repetition time msec/echo time msec, 2500/120; 4-mm section thickness) shows a small left globe. There is a funnel-shaped hypointense structure in the globe extending posteriorly from approximately the 2- and 10-o’clock positions and converging at the optic disc (outlined on its right lateral aspect by short arrows) formed by the medial boundaries of bilateral retinal detachments. There is slightly more globular hypointense tissue (long arrow) immediately posterior to the lens (*). The lens has abnormal morphology compared with the normal right lens. A central linear hypointensity (arrowhead) between the convexities of the subretinal collections is consistent with persistence of Cloquet canal.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.14110856/asset/images/large/radiol.14110856.fig2.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 2: Axial T1-weighted 1.5-T contrast material–enhanced (15 mL of intravenously injected gadopentetate dimeglumine, Magnevist; Bayer Healthcare Pharmaceuticals, Wayne, NJ) fat-saturated MR image (416/12, 3-mm section thickness) shows hyperintensity of the subretinal fluid (short white arrows) outlined by the funnel-shaped structure described in Figure 1. The retrolental tissue (long white arrow) is also hyperintense. Also visible is hyperintensity of the anterior chamber (black arrows). This finding may represent enhancement due to leaky vessels in the region of the lens and ciliary processes or intrinsically hyperintense signal from proteinaceous or hemorrhagic fluid.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.14110856/asset/images/large/radiol.14110856.fig3.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 3: Composite of, A, coronal T1-weighted (500/12, 3-mm section thickness) and, B, coronal T1-weighted 1.5-T contrast-enhanced fat-saturated (516/12, 3-mm section thickness) MR images at the level of the horizontal line in the inset. This line corresponds to the region depicted by the long arrows in Figures 1 and 2. Comparison of A and B suggests that the retrolental tissue (long arrow) is enhancing, whereas the subretinal fluid (short arrow) is intrinsically hyperintense. Axial precontrast T1-weighted images would be ideal to confirm enhancement of the retrolental tissue but were not acquired in this MR examination. Thus, it is possible that this tissue is intrinsically hyperintense and represents posterior hyaloid detachment or contracted vitreous related to retinal detachment, rather than enhancing fibrovascular tissue.'}]]

history: A 15-year-old girl presented with a 2-month history of 30-lb (13.6 kg) weight loss, chest and abdominal pain, nausea, bilious emesis, cough, and shortness of breath. Initial blood count (performed at an outside hospital) showed elevated white blood cell and platelet counts but low hemoglobin and hematocrit levels. On examination, she had adenopathy in the left axillary and supraclavicular regions, fullness in the left chest, and abdominal guarding. Ultrasounography-guided fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the left anterior chest wall mass was nondiagnostic, and lumbar puncture and bone marrow biopsies were negative. At that time, the patient underwent several imaging studies—including chest radiography (Fig 1); bone scanning (Fig 2); contrast material–enhanced computed tomography (CT) of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis (Fig 3); and fluorine 18 (18F) fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) positron emission tomography (PET)/CT (Fig 4)—all performed within 1 week of each other. Pertinent serum laboratory values at the time of these tests we as follows: calcium level, 17 mg/dL (4.25 mmol/L) (normal range, 8.5–10.5 mg/dL [2.1–2.6 mmol/L]); ionized calcium level, 2.3 mmol/L (normal range, 1.1–1.3 mmol/L); lipase level, 2423 U/L (normal level, <300 U/L); amylase level, 1435 U/L (normal, <140 U/L); lactate dehydrogenase level, 253 U/L (normal level, <240 U/L), albumin level, 2.6 g/dL (26 g/L) (normal level, 3.5–5.0 g/dL [35–50 g/L]), and creatinine level, 1.7 mg/dL (150.3 μmol/L) (normal level, <1.2 mg/dL [<106.1 μmol/L]).
findings: The portable chest radiograph (Fig 1) showed a large left-sided mediastinal and pulmonary mass with a moderate left pleural effusion and a cardiomediastinal shift to the right. The technetium 99m (99mTc) methyl diphosphonate bone scan (Fig 2) revealed diffuse linear uptake in the anterior left first and second ribs and diffuse mild soft-tissue uptake in the surrounding left hemithorax; otherwise, there was no scintigraphic evidence of distant metastases in the skeleton. The contrast-enhanced CT images (Fig 3) showed a large heterogeneous mass involving almost the entirety of the visualized portion of the left upper lobe. This mass was further seen to extend directly into the chest wall anteriorly and laterally and into the mediastinum. There was encasement of the great vessels, and the trachea was displaced to the right. Additional lymphadenopathy was seen in the contralateral mediastinum and ipsilateral axilla. The axial section through the abdomen showed a diffusely enlarged pancreas, with loss of normal contours suggesting inflammation. The baseline 18F FDG PET/CT scan (Fig 4) revealed a bulky intensely hypermetabolic mass centered in the left upper lobe and extending into the chest wall and mediastinum and likely into the left lower lobe. There were also multiple additional scattered foci of uptake corresponding to lymph nodes in the neck and supraclavicular, axillary, and mediastinal regions (at a minimum). The axial scan through the abdomen again revealed a diffusely enlarged pancreas associated with moderate diffuse 18F FDG uptake that was suggestive of inflammation. A small area of hypoatenuation in the posterior spleen was also hypermetabolic, suggesting splenic involvement. The follow-up 18F FDG PET/CT image (Fig 5), which was not presented in part 1 of this case, showed favorable response to therapy in the large left upper chest mass and surrounding lymphadenopathy in the form of a marked decrease in size and a nearly complete resolution of 18F FDG avidity. Moreover, the axial image obtained through the abdomen showed that the pancreas had returned to a normal size and no longer had increased FDG uptake.
diagnosis: Hodgkin Lymphoma with Paraneoplastic Hypercalcemic Pancreatitis
