history: A 63-year-old woman with a history of left mastectomy for breast cancer and partial gastrectomy with Roux-en-Y reconstruction for nonhealing peptic ulcer presented to the emergency department and reported a 1-month history of abdominal distention, fevers, chills, and flu-like symptoms. She was initially suspected of having flu, and she completed a course of oseltamivir; however, she had continued fatigue, fever, chills, abdominal bloating, and loss of appetite. She reported no contact with a sick person or recent travel. At admission, laboratory studies revealed leukocytosis, with a white blood cell count of 15.1 × 103/µL (15.1 × 109/L) (normal range, 4.0–10.0 × 103/µL [4.0–10.0 × 109/L]), an elevated sedimentation rate of 100 mm per hour (normal range, 0–30 mm per hour), and a C-reactive protein level of 203.8 mg/L (1940.9 nmol/L) (normal range, ≤10 mg/L [≤95.2 nmol/L]). Liver enzyme levels were elevated, with an alanine aminotransferase level of 48 U/L (0.80 µkat/L) (normal range, 0–29 U/L [0–0.48 µkat/L]), an aspartate aminotransferase level of 98 U/L (1.6 µkat/L) (normal range, 10–37 U/L [0.16–0.62 µkat/L]), an alkaline phosphatase level of 682 U/L (11.4 µkat/L) (normal range, 65–195 U/L [1.1–3.3 µkat/L]), and a total bilirubin level of 1.5 mg/dL (25.7 µmol/L) (normal range, 0.3–1.0 mg/dL [5.1–17.1 µmol/L]). Abdominopelvic CT was performed (Figs 1–3).
findings: Contrast-enhanced venous phase CT (Figs 1–3) showed nearly occlusive thrombosis of the main portal vein and intrahepatic branches, as well as superior mesenteric vein and vessel wall enhancement. There are numerous periportal hepatic hypodensities compatible with abscesses. There is a curvilinear radiopaque density penetrating through the thickened third portion of duodenum into the superior mesenteric vein with a small surrounding mesenteric fluid collection, possibly an abscess or hematoma. Suture lines are seen at the gastrojejunostomy anastomosis (Figs 1a, 2a). Despite extensive mesenteric thrombosis, there were no findings of bowel ischemia.

history: A 44-year-old woman who was a resident of Bihar, which is a state in eastern India, presented to the surgical outpatient department of our hospital with a history of gradually increasing swelling of the right breast associated with redness, pain, and itching over the past month (Fig 1). She reported a general sense of malaise and experienced episodes of chills over the past 6 months; however, she had no documented fever. There was no history of breast trauma. No history suggestive of a possible hypercoagulable state could be elicited (she was a nonsmoker, had undergone uncomplicated normal vaginal delivery 15 years earlier, was not taking oral contraceptives, and had no history to suggest past deep venous thrombosis). General physical examination findings were unremarkable. On local examination, she was found to have diffuse enlargement of the right breast. The skin over the lateral part of the breast was erythematous and showed the presence of prominent superficial veins. On palpation, few ill-defined firm mobile masses were found in the upper outer quadrant with overlying skin induration. No skin ulceration or nipple discharge was present. Few firm and discrete lymph nodes were palpable in the right axilla.
findings: Local examination of the breast revealed an enlarged breast with patchy erythema (Fig 1). Bilateral mammography showed the presence of few tortuous tubular channels and a few discrete lobulated masses in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. These channels did not conform to a ductal distribution (Fig 2).

history: A 36-year-old left-handed woman with a history of developmental delay and medical refractory seizures since birth most recently presented with continuous simple partial seizures and occasional breakthrough complex partial seizures with postictal migraines. These were described as the patient “becoming pale with sinking to the floor and staring for approximately 1 minute with confusion thereafter.” The patient had years of reported seizure freedom until 2010 when she was evaluated for intractable headaches, and electroencephalography revealed her focal subclinical status. At that time, ambulatory electroencephalography findings showed asymmetric left parietal-occipital high-amplitude spike-and-wave discharges in her best awake and alert state. Since that time, the patient developed and continues to have complex partial seizures every 2–3 months that are persistent despite the implementation of several medical regimens.
findings: Unenhanced CT revealed two hyperdense foci in the left temporal and occipital regions, consistent with coarse calcifications, with surrounding white matter hypodensity (Fig 1). Enlargement of the left temporal, occipital, and parietal lobes is shown on all images provided, most prominently the MRI scans. Importantly, the MRI scans also show frontal lobe sparing, without substantial enlargement of the left frontal lobe (Fig 2). Areas of predominantly hypointense T2 and fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) signal are seen in the left temporal and occipital lobes, without enhancement (Fig 3), corresponding to the previously described calcifications. Thinning of the cortex and thickening of the white matter within the affected regions is also seen (Fig 4). Polymicrogyria is seen in the affected posterior hemisphere. There is increased FLAIR and T2 signal at the medial aspect of the left temporal and occipital lobes, with extension to the left hippocampal and parahippocampal regions (Fig 4). Effacement of the posterior portion of the left lateral ventricle is seen. Cerebellar volume loss with associated prominence of the cerebrospinal fluid spaces in the posterior fossa is likely due to long-term use of antiepileptic medication (Fig 5).

history: A 25-year-old woman was referred to our breast clinic for assessment of a palpable mass in her left breast that developed quickly in 2 weeks. She denied any associated fever, chills, redness, or pain. She had no relevant medical or surgical history; no evidence of recent pregnancy, abortion, or breastfeeding; and no family history of breast cancer. Clinical examination enabled confirmation of a firm mass occupying the retroareolar region and the outer quadrant of the left breast with no skin retraction, edema, or erythema. There was no evidence of enlarged axillary lymph nodes. US of the left breast (Fig 1), bilateral breast MRI (Fig 2), and fluorine 18 fluorodeoxyglucose PET/CT (Fig 3) were performed.
findings: US of the left breast revealed ill-defined hypervascular hypo- and hyperechoic masses infiltrating between the glandular space and the dermis in the para-areolar region and the lower outer quadrant distally and associated with subcutaneous edematous infiltration (Fig 1). There was no evidence of substantially enlarged axillary lymph nodes.

history: A 70-year-old man had a posterior left thigh lesion confirmed to be biopsy-proven melanoma. The patient underwent wide excision and sentinel node biopsy, which showed absence of residual melanoma. Two years later, the patient noticed a subcentimeter subcutaneous lump in his thigh. Repeat excisional biopsy showed involvement of the surrounding soft tissue, consistent with a satellite lesion. Follow-up combined PET/CT revealed satellite nodules around the primary lesion, enabling confirmation of subcutaneous metastatic disease.
findings: Chest CT image obtained with soft-tissue window settings showed bilateral mediastinal lymphadenopathy (Fig 1). On CT images obtained with lung window settings, there was irregular and nodular thickening of interlobular septum and bronchovascular bundles, representing involvement of the lymphatic system (Fig 2), predominantly in the bilateral upper lobes (Fig 3).
diagnosis: Sarcoidlike Granulomatosis and Lymphadenopathy—Thoracic Manifestations of Nivolumab Drug Toxicity

history: A 60-year-old woman was diagnosed with a new right upper lobe stage I lung adenocarcinoma and underwent video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) for right upper lobectomy. Her postoperative course was complicated by a large pneumothorax after chest tube removal on postoperative day 3. This was managed with repeat right-sided chest tube placement on the same day. The second chest tube was removed on postoperative day 8 without complications. A 2-week postoperative clinic visit was unremarkable. Postoperative chest radiographs on postoperative days 1, 3, and 8 (Fig 1a–1c) are provided. Subsequently, chest CT scanning was performed as part of routine 6-month postsurgical lung cancer surveillance follow-up (Figs 2, 3). The patient had no clinical complaints at routine follow-up. Physical examination revealed well-healed VATS scars in the chest wall. Laboratory results were within normal limits, including a normal white blood cell count of 6400/μL. Her surgical history included prior left upper lobectomy for remote left upper lobe stage IIIA adenocarcinoma and prior bilateral breast implantation for cosmesis. On the basis of chest CT findings, the patient was transferred from an outside institution.
findings: Chest radiographs on postoperative day 1 showed expected postsurgical changes after VATS for right upper lobectomy, namely a small residual right pneumothorax and a right-sided chest tube in satisfactory position (Fig 1a). Chest radiography on postoperative day 3 showed a large right-sided pneumothorax after chest tube removal, with increased opacity in the right lower hemithorax, presumably related to the early change in position of the right breast implant (Fig 1b). Radiography on postoperative day 8 after placement of a new chest tube continued to show increased opacity in the right lower hemithorax, presumably due to the migrating breast implant.
diagnosis: Intrathoracic Migration of a Breast Implant after Video-assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery for Right Upper Lobectomy

history: A 46-year-old woman was admitted to our hospital with decompensated congestive heart failure and pericardial effusion diagnosed on echocardiography. She had no family history of sudden cardiac death.
findings: Posteroanterior chest radiography showed severe cardiac enlargement. Electrocardiography showed atrial flutter (ventricular rate, approximately 90 beats per minute), fragmented QRS complex with diffuse low voltage, and no specific ST depression (Fig 1).

history: An 8-year-old girl presented to our hospital with painful swelling of the left thigh and soft-tissue swelling in the right chest wall. The patient’s history revealed that the swelling had been present since birth but had grown slowly. She had no history of relevant trauma. Her blood pressure was 145/95 mmHg (normal value, <115/76 mmHg), and her heart rate was 105 beats per minute (normal value, 75–118 beats per minute). The patient’s electrocardiogram displayed sinus tachycardia. Physical examination revealed soft-tissue hypertrophy in the left thigh and right lower chest wall. A painful soft and flexible mass measuring approximately 5 × 6 × 15 cm (in the anteroposterior, transverse, and craniocaudal directions, respectively) was detected at the left thigh. Moreover, a painless soft mass measuring approximately 3 × 8 × 10 cm (in the anteroposterior, transverse, and craniocaudal directions, respectively) was detected in the right lower chest wall, and the overlying skin was intact. Pink macules with a 3-cm diameter on the anterior left superior thigh and a 2.5-cm diameter in the left inguinal region were detected. Examination of other systems, including the cardiovascular system, revealed normal findings. Laboratory test results were within normal limits. Abdominal US showed perirenal vascular collaterals, and musculoskeletal US of the left thigh revealed vascular collaterals (images not shown). Therefore, thoracoabdominal CT angiography (Fig 1a–1c) and contrast material–enhanced MRI of the bilateral thigh (Fig 2a–2c) were performed.
findings: Thoracoabdominal CT angiography with sagittal reconstruction showed a fatty right chest wall mass without any cystic or solid component representing fatty tissue overgrowth and extensive abdominal and left paravertebral varicose vascular structures (Fig 1a). Thoracoabdominal CT angiography with coronal reconstruction revealed hypoplasia in the left kidney, thoracoabdominal scoliosis, and fatty infiltration in the left psoas muscle (Fig 1b). Axial abdominal CT angiography (Fig 1c) showed fatty infiltration and reduction in muscle mass in the left psoas, quadratus lumborum, multifidus, and erector spinae muscles and extensive vascular malformations. Moreover, CT shows paravertebral vascular collaterals are associated with dural veins. Axial T1-weighted MRI of the bilateral thigh (Fig 2a) revealed fatty replacement of the left quadriceps femoris muscle, including vascular malformations, and disrupted the normal fibrillary pattern of striated muscle. Coronal T1-weighted unenhanced MRI of the bilateral thigh (Fig 2b) revealed fatty replacement and disrupted the normal fibrillary pattern of the left quadriceps femoris muscle and vascular collaterals extending to the left groin. Axial fatsaturated contrast-enhanced T1-weighted MRI (Fig 2c) revealed enhancing low-flow vascular malformations in the left thigh. Time-resolved MR angiography was performed to screen for a high-flow component, and there was no high-flow vascular component in the left thigh. However, there was a high-flow vascular component in the pelvis (not shown). Excisional muscle biopsy was performed from the left thigh. In the cross-sectional macroscopic examination of the specimen, the dense fibrofatty tissue consisted of a variable mixture of vascular clusters and thin-walled blood-filled venous channels that separate skeletal muscle bundles. Abnormal lymphatic vascular components also were present. Genetic analysis of tissue biopsy revealed the PIK3CA gene mutation, and Sanger sequencing revealed the mutant allele frequency was 27.8%. The diagnosis of PIK3CA-related overgrowth spectrum (PROS) was suggested according to clinical, radiologic, and pathologic findings. Because of the congenital truncal lipomatous overgrowth, vascular malformations, epidermal nevi, scoliosis (CLOVES), and left renal hypoplasia, a diagnosis of CLOVES syndrome was made. Moreover, the diagnosis of the fibroadipose vascular anomaly (FAVA) was made according to clinical, radiologic, and pathologic analysis findings comprising fibrofatty infiltration of muscle and atrophy of the affected muscles, unusual lymphatic and venous dilatations (phlebectasia) with pain, and lipomatous overgrowth of the affected extremity.

history: A 26-year-old man presented with a 1-month history of chest pain, a palpable and painful right inguinal mass, and edema in the right lower extremity. One month earlier, he started to experience left chest pain with no cough. Pulmonary CT angiography (CTA) revealed a left lower lobe segmental pulmonary embolus. The local hospital made a diagnosis of pulmonary embolism (PE). He received anticoagulants, and his chest pain was gradually relieved. At the time of current presentation, the patient was experiencing right lower extremity swelling and pain. Physical examination revealed a 4 × 3 cm palpable right inguinal mass with no redness. His medical history and family history were negative. The results of laboratory work-up were normal, with a D-dimer level of 0.16 mg/L fibrinogen equivalent units (reference range, <0.46 mg/L) and an international normalized ratio of 2.45 (therapeutic range, 2.0–3.0 for a patient taking warfarin), except the prothrombin time was 28.2 seconds (reference range, 9.6–12.8 seconds) and the activated partial thromboplastin time was 52.2 seconds (reference range, 24.8–33.8 seconds). Echocardiography, chest radiography, chest CT, and contrast-enhanced CT revealed no abnormalities. The patient underwent right lower extremity vascular conventional US (Philips IU22; Philips) with an L9–3 probe (3–9 MHz, venous condition) and contrast-enhanced US (1.5–2.0 mL, SonoVue; Bracco) with an intravenous bolus injection at the initial evaluation. Two days later, noncontrast and contrast-enhanced CT images of the lower abdomen (1.5 mL per kilogram of body weight, 300 mg/mL iomeprol, Iomeron; Bracco) were acquired for further evaluation (Figs 1–3).
findings: The initial conventional US images revealed a 3.0 × 2.9 cm heterogeneous multilocular mass with well-circumscribed walls and hyperechoic internal septa arising from the right external iliac vein and the right common femoral vein (Fig 1a). Color Doppler flow imaging showed abundant blood flow signals in the mass, and spectral Doppler imaging depicted arterial blood flow signals with a 35.3 cm/sec peak systolic velocity and a resistance index of 0.81 in the mass (Fig 1b). CE US showed that the mass was enhanced inhomogeneously and simultaneously with the femoral artery at 18 seconds (Fig 2a[ID] FIG2[/ID]) and that the mass was multilocular with several unenhanced areas (Fig 2a, 2b). The CE US images indicated an intravascular tumor with neovascularization in the right external iliac vein and right common femoral vein. According to the contrasting features on CE US images, a tumor with neovascularization was more likely than a bland thrombus in the right external iliac vein and right common femoral vein. Thus, the patient was sent for plain CT and CE CT scans of the lower abdomen.

history: A 46-year-old woman with known mixed connective tissue disease with clinical features of scleroderma and polymyositis and who was not on specific medications was referred to our institution to assess for interstitial lung disease due to her predisposing condition. She was a nonsmoker, had no respiratory symptoms, and enjoyed good exercise tolerance. She did not have any cutaneous lesions or renal disease. There was no family history of pulmonary or systemic disease. Her routine blood test results revealed a white blood cell count of 4.6 × 109/L (normal range, [4.4–10.1] × 109/L), a hemoglobin level of 7.76 mmol/L (normal range, 7.26–9.18 mmol/L), a platelet count of 189 × 109/L (normal range, [170–380] × 109/L), a bilirubin level of 8 μmol/L (7–19 μmol/L), and a creatinine level of 63 μmol/L (45–82 μmol/L), all within normal limits. Lung function tests at presentation yielded normal results, with a diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide of 95% and a forced vital capacity of 2.29 (98% predicted value). However, this patient had an elevated serum globulin level of 47 g/L (normal range, 26–32 g/L) and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 36 mm/h (normal range, 0–20 mm/h), while C-reactive protein level was normal at less than 0.35 mg/dL. She was seropositive for antinuclear (titer >1/720), anti-Ro, anti-La, and anti-extractable nuclear antigen antibodies.
findings: On the chest radiograph at the time of referral to our institution, there was an area of focal lucency in the mediobasal left lower lung (Fig 1). Lung volumes were preserved, and there were no reticular opacities to suggest substantial fibrotic or interstitial changes. Chest CT at the time showed multiple thin-walled cystic lesions of variable sizes surrounded by normal lung parenchyma with associated small subcentimeter intra- and pericystic nodules, distributed in bilateral middle to lower zones without involvement of the apices (Fig 2). Most of the lung nodules were not calcified. The basal lucency identified on plain radiographs likely corresponded to the largest (4.3-cm) thin-walled cyst in the mediobasal left lower lobe (Fig 2e).
diagnosis: Amyloid-associated Cystic Lung Disease and Coexistent Mucosa-associated Lymphoid Tissue Lymphoma
images: [[{'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2021200027/asset/images/large/radiol.2021200027.fig1.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 1: Initial frontal chest radiograph obtained at presentation in 2006.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2021200027/asset/images/large/radiol.2021200027.fig2.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 2: Initial noncontrast axial chest CT images obtained at presentation in 2006 by using lung and mediastinal window settings in the, A, B, apices and the, C, D, middle and, E, F, lower lung zones.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2021200027/asset/images/large/radiol.2021200027.fig3.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 3: Most recent frontal chest radiograph obtained 14 years after initial presentation.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2021200027/asset/images/large/radiol.2021200027.fig4.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 4: Most recent noncontrast axial chest CT images obtained 14 years after initial presentation by using lung and mediastinal window settings in the, A, B, apices and the, C, D, middle and, E, F, lower lung zones.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2021200027/asset/images/large/radiol.2021200027.fig5.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 5: Axial serial PET/CT images obtained at, A, B, 7- and, C, D, 13-year follow-up.'}], [{'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2021200026/asset/images/large/radiol.2021200026.fig1.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 1: Initial frontal chest radiograph obtained at presentation in 2006 shows tiny nodular densities in bilateral lower zones. A focal lucency in the left lower paracardiac region (arrow) likely corresponds to the basal lung cyst seen on subsequent CT images. The rest of the lungs are unremarkable, with no pleural effusion, pneumothorax, or hilar enlargement seen.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2021200026/asset/images/large/radiol.2021200026.fig2.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 2: Initial noncontrast axial chest CT images obtained at presentation in 2006 by using lung and mediastinal window settings in the, A, B, apices and the, C, D, middle and, E, F, lower lung zones. There are multiple thin-walled cystic lesions of variable sizes surrounded by normal lung parenchyma with associated small subcentimeter intra- and pericystic nodules (arrows), predominantly distributed in bilateral middle to lower zones. Calcification was seen in only one of the larger nodules at the laterobasal left lower lobe (arrowhead), while the rest of the lung nodules were noncalcified. A prominent (4.3-cm) thin-walled cyst in the mediobasal left lower lobe was noted, corresponding to chest radiographic findings.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2021200026/asset/images/large/radiol.2021200026.fig3.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 3: Most recent frontal chest radiograph obtained 14 years after initial presentation shows a substantial increase in reticular densities and adjacent cystic lucencies in bilateral middle and lower zones. There is also increased prominence of multiple small lung nodules and enlargement of the focal lucency at the paracardiac basal left lower zone, which likely corresponds to the enlarging dominant cyst seen at CT (arrow). Mild blunting of bilateral costophrenic angles may represent pleural thickening. Lung volumes remain preserved.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2021200026/asset/images/large/radiol.2021200026.fig4.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 4: Latest unenhanced chest CT images obtained 14 years after initial presentation, with selected axial images from, A, B, apices, C, D, middle, and E, F, lower lung zones using lung and mediastinal window settings. There is a substantial further increase in the number and size of multiple lung cysts and pericystic lung nodules (arrows in C), with the largest cyst in the basal left lower lobe now measuring 9.7 cm and the largest nodule in the left lower lobe (arrow in E and F) measuring 1.2 cm. Of note is the increase in calcification (arrowheads) of the pericystic nodules and cyst wall. Overall features are suggestive of substantial progression in cystic interstitial lung disease with basal predominance. The lung apices remain spared.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2021200026/asset/images/large/radiol.2021200026.fig5.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 5: Axial serial PET/CT images obtained at, A, B, 7 and, C, D, 13 years follow-up consistently show absence of substantial metabolic activity of the largest lung nodule (arrow) in the posterobasal left lower lobe. (Hematoxylin-eosin stain; original magnification, ×40). B, Perivascular deposition of amorphous eosinophilic material (arrow), consistent with amyloid (Hematoxylin-eosin stain; original magnification, ×40). C, In situ hybridization for kappa light chain (arrows) (Congo red stain; original magnification, ×100), D, in situ hybridization for lambda light chain (arrows) (Congo red stain; original magnification, ×40), and E, the amorphous eosinophilic aggregates (arrow) (Congo red stain; original magnification, ×40) are positively stained.'}]]

history: A 24-year-old right-handed woman presented to a neuro-ophthalmology clinic in Massachusetts in the summer with acute binocular diplopia when looking down and to the left, which started about 1 month earlier. Her medical history was notable for Raynaud syndrome, recurrent streptococcal pharyngitis, and an allergy to amoxicillin. Three days prior to developing diplopia, she presented to an outside emergency department due to fever, chills, and back pain. She received ciprofloxacin for presumed urinary tract infection based on urinalysis, which demonstrated few bacteria and was negative for leukocyte esterase, nitrites, and white blood cells. She then presented again to an outside emergency department for diplopia evaluation. Initial MRI and MR angiography of the brain at that time did not demonstrate any relevant findings, and the patient was referred to our department for neuro-ophthalmic evaluation, where she was seen 4 weeks later. Neuro-ophthalmic examination revealed 20/20 visual acuity in both eyes, and a right hypertropia in left gaze, downgaze and right head tilt, with right eye excyclotorsion. There were no ocular signs of myasthenia gravis or thyroid eye disease, nor did the patient report ocular or systemic symptoms. She denied recent travel. High-spatial-resolution MRI of the brain and orbit were performed (Figs 1, 2).
findings: High-spatial-resolution 3-T MRI of the brain and orbits was performed 1 month after initial presentation. Coronal T1 pre- and postcontrast images (Fig 1) show smooth enhancement of the right fourth cranial nerve as it courses along the trochlear cistern below the tentorial leaflet. On images acquired with the coronal cisternographic T2 driven equilibrium radiofrequency reset pulse sequence, the right fourth cranial nerve can be seen along the trochlear groove, a small notch near the tentorial free edge best seen on images obtained with cisternographic sequences (Fig 2). No additional lesion within the midbrain, cavernous sinus, or orbit was identified.

history: A 6-year-old male child, born at full term via vaginal delivery, presented with a history of ataxia and delayed motor development. There was no family history of neurodegenerative disease. On examination, there was slight dysarthria, dysmetria on a finger-to-nose test, slowing of fast repetitive movements, and increased deep tendon reflexes and clonus in the lower limbs. Electromyography (EMG) revealed axonal neuropathy, which was predominantly sensory.
findings: Brain MRI scans (Figs 1–3) show linear T2 and fluid-attenuated inversion-recovery (FLAIR) hypointensities in the pons. T2-weighted sagittal image (Fig 3) shows an enlarged pons with linear hypointense striations on either side of the midline and discrete atrophy of the superior vermis.
diagnosis: Autosomal Recessive Spastic Ataxia of Charlevoix-Saguenay

history: A 50-year-old woman presented to the emergency department of our hospital with a 2-day history of lower limb pain associated with unusual asthenia and diffuse arthralgia over the past 3 weeks. She was a native of Guinea and had lived in France for most of her life, working as a personal care assistant. Her only medical history of note was an occurrence of fetal death at 12 weeks gestation when she was 35 years old. She had bilateral lower limb swelling, without changes in skin temperature or color. All proximal and distal arterial pulses were felt. General physical examination findings were otherwise unremarkable.
findings: Contrast-enhanced (90 mL of iomeprol, Iomeron 350; Bracco) axial CT image of the lung bases demonstrates a filling defect in the left lower lobe pulmonary artery, corresponding to an acute pulmonary embolism, associated with a left pleural effusion and left lower lobe consolidation consistent with compression atelectasis (Fig 1). On the abdominal images acquired at a later phase, a wedge-shaped perfusion defect of the left kidney is depicted, consistent with a kidney infarct. Low-abundance pericholecystic fluid is also present (Fig 2a). Coronal reformation demonstrates a high-attenuation superior mesenteric vein wall surrounding a central filling defect, corresponding to an extensive superior mesenteric vein thrombosis (Fig 2b) and bilateral hypoattenuating swelling of both adrenal glands (Fig 2c), showing no contrast material uptake, consistent with adrenal infarction, probably due to thrombosis of the adrenal veins. The tail of the right adrenal vein thrombus can be seen at the posterior aspect of the inferior vena cava (Fig 2d). On cardiac MRI scans, subendocardial high signal intensity corresponding to ischemic edema is seen on the short-axis T2 short tau inversion-recovery image (Fig 3). Patchy subendocardial foci of delayed enhancement are observed in the late gadolinium enhancement sequence in the midanterior and midanterolateral segments.

(a) Wedge-shaped perfusion defect of the left kidney (arrow) corresponds to focal renal infarction and a small amount of peritoneal fluid around the gallbladder wall (arrowhead). (b) Extensive superior mesenteric vein thrombosis with an enhancing superior mesenteric vein wall surrounding a central filling defect (arrow). (c) Bilateral hypoattenuating swelling of both adrenal glands (arrows) shows no contrast material uptake, consistent with adrenal infarction. (d) Small filling defect at the posterior aspect of the inferior vena cava is consistent with the tail of a right adrenal vein thrombus (arrow) abutting the vena cava at this level.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2021203174/asset/images/large/radiol.2021203174.fig3.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 3: Short-axis T2-weighted short tau inversion-recovery (repetition time msec/echo time msec/inversion time msec, 1790/44/160; section thickness, 6 mm) image acquired with a 3-T MRI scanner shows subendocardial high signal intensity, corresponding to ischemic edema.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2021203174/asset/images/large/radiol.2021203174.fig4.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 4: Short-axis phase-sensitive inversion-recovery late gadolinium enhancement (repetition time msec/echo time msec/inversion time msec, 873.6/1.96/320; section thickness, 8 mm) image acquired 10 minutes after the injection of gadoterate meglumine (0.4 mL per kilogram of body weight, Dotarem; Guerbet) shows patchy subendocardial foci of delayed enhancement in the midanterior and midanterolateral segments (arrows).'}]]

history: A 57-year-old man with no remarkable past medical history presented to an outside institution with painless swelling in his right thigh of 6 months duration. He denied any trauma to the site. At that time, physical examination demonstrated swelling in his right upper thigh. All other work-up, including complete blood count and chest radiography, yielded negative results. The initial diagnosis was lymphangioma of the thigh. He continued to experience worsening swelling in his right upper thigh with no other symptoms over the next year. He was referred to our facility, where he underwent US evaluation of the thigh lesion (Fig 1), an MRI scan encompassing the entire extent of his thigh lesion (Fig 2), and a CT scan of his abdomen and pelvis (Fig 3).
findings: The US image showed a multiloculated hypoechoic lesion (Fig 1). The MRI scans showed a multiloculated lesion in intermuscular fascial planes of the thigh, with isointense signal intensity on T1-weighted images, hyperintense signal intensity on T2-weighted images and short inversion time inversion-recovery (STIR) images, and peripheral enhancement on the contrast-enhanced T1-weighted images (Fig 2). The coronal STIR images also showed that the lesion had thigh and intra-abdominal components (Fig 2). This finding of an intra-abdominal component prompted CT examination of the abdomen and pelvis. The axial CT images of the abdomen and pelvis showed a solid appendiceal mass and a cystic retroperitoneal lesion in the right lower quadrant. The cystic lesion also had a few areas of calcification (Fig 3).
diagnosis: Pseudomyxoma from Mucinous Adenocarcinoma of the Appendix Extending from the Retroperitoneum into the Thigh

history: A 55-year-old woman without systemic underlying disease, such as diabetes mellitus, inflammatory bowel disease, autoimmune disease, or chronic kidney disease, presented with generalized dull abdominal pain of 1-week duration. She had ingested herbal medicine for physical conditioning for several years. Laboratory findings, including biochemistry, electrolyte levels, and complete blood count, were all within normal limits, except for elevated serum C-reactive protein level (7.719 mg/dL; normal range,<1 mg/dL).
findings: Abdominal plain-film radiography demonstrated dendritic serpiginous radiopaque opacities alongside the ascending and transverse colon. The direction of these linear opacities was perpendicular to the long axis of the colon, corresponding to the course of pericolonic vessels (Fig 1). Coronal noncontrast CT showed vascular calcification of the pericolonic arcades in the distribution of the ascending and transverse colon. No atherosclerosis of the large or small arteries was noted, suggesting the calcified vessels were of venous origin (Fig 2). Axial noncontrast CT image showed segmental colonic wall thickening of the ascending and transverse colon with luminal narrowing, loss of haustra, and no sign of intestinal obstruction (Fig 3). Pericolonic and adjacent mesenteric fat stranding in the ascending and transverse colon were also noted. Subsequent colonoscopy showed black and purplish pigmentation of mucosa from the cecum to the transverse colon (Fig 4). Endoscopic biopsy of the discolored colon mucosa revealed fibrous thickening and deposition of hyalinized material in the vascular wall in the lamina propria, as well as focal erosion, glandular atrophy, and chronic infiltration of inflammatory cells. The picture is compatible with chronic ischemic colitis, with hyalinization in the lamina propria of the vascular wall (Fig 5).

history: A 70-year-old man was referred to our institution with chronic obstructive urinary symptoms and constipation for 2 years before admission. His medical history was unremarkable. Outside laboratory tests revealed an elevated serum prostate-specific antigen level (21.7 ng/mL [normal range, 0.00–4.00 ng/mL]), and urinalysis results were negative.
findings: Multiparametric MRI was performed with a 3-T imager without an endorectal coil and in compliance with Prostate Imaging Reporting and Data System guidelines.
images: [[{'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2021202948/asset/images/large/radiol.2021202948.fig1.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 1: (a) Axial, (b, d, e) sagittal, and (c) coronal T2-weighted MRI scans of the pelvis.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2021202948/asset/images/large/radiol.2021202948.fig2.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 2: (a) Axial T2-weighted, (b) diffusion-weighted (b value = 1000 sec/mm2), (c) apparent diffusion coefficient map, (d) unenhanced, and (e) contrast-enhanced T1-weighted MRI scans at the level of the base of the prostate.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2021202948/asset/images/large/radiol.2021202948.fig3.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 3: (a) Axial T2-weighted, (b) diffusion-weighted (b value = 1000 sec/mm2), (c) apparent diffusion coefficient map, (d) unenhanced, and (e) contrast-enhanced T1-weighted MRI scans at the level of the middle third of the prostate.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2021202948/asset/images/large/radiol.2021202948.fig4.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 4: (a) Axial T2-weighted and (b) contrast-enhanced T1-weighted MRI scans at the level of the iliac vessels'}], [{'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.202949/asset/images/large/radiol.202949.fig1.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 1: (a) Axial (repetition time msec/echo time msec, 9016/162.54), (b) sagittal (8664/149.776), and (c) coronal (2000/155.844) T2-weighted MRI scans show a bulky multicystic prostatic mass with multiple septa (arrowheads) situated posterosuperiorly to the prostate gland. (d, e) Parasagittal T2-weighted MRI scans (8664/149.776) of the pelvis show the relationship between the mass and the seminal vesicles (arrows). They show some areas of slightly infiltrative margins (arrowhead) and an atrophic right seminal vesicle (although a common finding, it could be an indirect feature that may be associated with local invasion) (d), and a normal appearance of the left seminal vesicle (e).'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.202949/asset/images/large/radiol.202949.fig2.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 2: (a) Axial T2-weighted MRI scan (repetition time msec/echo time msec, 9016/162.54) at the level of the base of the prostate shows the mucin component of the prostatic mass (arrowheads) and does not demonstrate restricted diffusion (arrows) on (b) axial diffusion-weighted MRI scan (3350/64.5; b value = 1000 sec/mm2) and (c) apparent diffusion coefficient map. Axial (d) noncontrast (4.312/1.964) and (e) contrast-enhanced (4.284/1.94) T1-weighted MRI scans show absence of enhancement on the fluid part of the lesion (white arrows) and enhancement of internal septa (arrowheads). Axial (d) unenhanced (4.312/1.964) and (e) contrast-enhanced (4.284/1.94) T1-weighted MRI scans show absence of significant enhancement of this solid component of the lesion (arrow).'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.202949/asset/images/large/radiol.202949.fig4.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 4: (a) Axial T2-weighted (repetition time msec/echo time msec, 9016/162.54) and (b) contrast-enhanced T1-weighted (4.284/1.94) MRI scans show a cystic and enlarged lymph node (arrow) in the external iliac right chain, most likely representing mucinous content.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.202949/asset/images/large/radiol.202949.fig5.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 5: (a) Biopsy fragment: photomicrograph of mucinous adenocarcinoma, composed of tumor cells arranged in trabecular and cribriform patterns (white arrowhead) and floating in extracellular mucin (black arrowhead). (Hematoxylin-eosin stain; original magnification, ×20.) (c) Histopathology specimen: neoplastic infiltration of the right seminal vesicle (arrow). Locally advanced disease. (Hematoxylin-eosin stain; original magnification, ×20.).'}]]

history: A 37-year-old man from the United States presented with a 1-year history of neck pain and stiffness that had been unsuccessfully treated with manipulative therapy by a chiropractor at another institution. Past medical history was remarkable only for marijuana and air duster abuse. He denied use of any prescription medications. Physical examination was notable for markedly reduced range of motion of the cervical spine. Laboratory work-up revealed an elevated alkaline phosphatase level (302 U/L [5.0 μkat/L]; normal range, 40–100 U/L [0.7–1.67 μkat/L]), but all other laboratory findings, including complete blood count, renal function, liver function, vitamin A level, serum protein electrophoresis, and hepatitis C antibodies were within normal limits. Cervical spine radiography was performed (Fig 1), followed by MRI (Fig 2). Subsequently, a full skeletal survey was ordered. Included are representative radiographs of the pelvis (Fig 3), left forearm (Fig 4), and distal right leg with ankle (Fig 5).
findings: The cervical spine extension radiograph (Fig 1) and representative radiographs from a skeletal survey including the pelvis (Fig 2), left forearm (Fig 3), and distal right leg and ankle (Fig 4) show diffuse osteosclerosis. Bone marrow signal intensity in the cervical spine is substantially decreased on both T1-weighted and short tau inversion recovery images (Fig 5). There is substantially decreased extension of the cervical spine, likely secondary to ossification of the interspinous ligaments and calcifications in the ligamentum flavum and posterior longitudinal ligament, which narrow the spinal canal (Figs 1–5). The anteroposterior view of the left forearm (Fig 3) shows mineralization of the muscular attachments and the interosseous membrane. An indolent periosteal reaction is seen in the distal left tibia and fibula near the ankle, and there is mineralization in the deltoid ligament attachments (Fig 4). This patient also admitted using marijuana and huffing air dust cleaner heavily within the past year, prompting a more specific work-up for fluorosis. His serum fluoride level was 38.1 μmol/L (normal range, 0.0–4.0 μmol/L), and his urine fluoride-to-creatinine ratio was 75.1 mg/g creatinine (normal range, 0.0–3.0 mg/g creatinine), enabling us to confirm the diagnosis of skeletal fluorosis.

history: A 32-year-old woman presented to an ophthalmologist for bilateral blurry vision. She underwent MRI of the brain and orbits, which showed a focal abnormality within the pituitary gland. The patient was referred to an endocrinologist for further evaluation. Review of systems and physical examination by the endocrinologist revealed no symptoms or signs of endocrine dysfunction. Anterior pituitary hormone levels, including growth hormone, prolactin, thyroid stimulating hormone, follicular stimulating hormone, luteinizing hormone, and adrenocorticotropic hormone, were normal. Dynamic contrast-enhanced MRI of the sella and pituitary gland (Figs 1–3) and subsequent CT of the anterior skull base (Figs 4, 5) were performed.
findings: Sagittal unenhanced T1-weighted MRI of the sella (Fig 1) showed a linear hypointensity coursing anteriorly and superiorly within the posterior aspect of the pituitary parenchyma. Sagittal and coronal enhanced fat-suppressed T1-weighted MRI through the sella (Fig 2) showed the linear area of interest within the posterior aspect of the pituitary gland was hypo- or nonenhancing and surrounded by normal enhancing pituitary parenchyma. Axial unenhanced fat-suppressed T2-weighted MRI of the sella (Fig 3) showed a midline spur arising from the central anterior portion of the dorsum sella and projecting anteriorly into the pituitary fossa. Axial (Fig 4) and sagittal (Fig 5) unenhanced CT of sella showed a midline bony spur projecting anteriorly from the central anterior aspect of dorsum sella, typical for a sellar spine. Cinematic rendering of CT images enabled us to confirm the sellar spine and its relationship to dorsum sella and pituitary fossa (Fig 6).
images: [[{'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2021203442/asset/images/large/radiol.2021203442fig1.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 1: Sagittal unenhanced T1-weighted MRI scans (repetition time msec/echo time msec, 250/2.66).'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2021203442/asset/images/large/radiol.2021203442fig2.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 2: (A) Sagittal (250/3.16) and (B) coronal (649/10) contrast-enhanced fat-suppressed T1-weighted MRI scans.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2021203442/asset/images/large/radiol.2021203442fig3.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 3: Axial unenhanced fat-suppressed T2-weighted MRI scan (3320/103).'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2021203442/asset/images/large/radiol.2021203442fig4.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 4: Axial unenhanced CT scan of the sella.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.2021203442/asset/images/large/radiol.2021203442fig5.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 5: Sagittal unenhanced CT scan of the sella.'}], [{'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.203443/asset/images/large/radiol.203443fig1.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 1: Sagittal unenhanced T1-weighted MRI scan (repetition time msec/echo time msec, 250/2.66) of the sella shows normal size of the pituitary gland. Within the posterior aspect of the pituitary gland, there is a linear area of T1 hypointensity (arrow) projecting anteriorly and superiorly through the pituitary gland. The optic chiasm and hypothalamus appear normal. The neurohypophysis was very small and off-midline (not shown).'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.203443/asset/images/large/radiol.203443fig2.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 2: (A) Sagittal (repetition time msec/echo time msec, 250/3.16) and (B) coronal (649/10) contrast-enhanced fat-suppressed T1-weighted MRI scans of the sella show a hypo- or nonenhancing area in the posterior aspect of the pituitary gland (arrow), which has a linear configuration on A and an oval cross-section on B. It appears encased by the normally enhancing anterior pituitary parenchyma. history: A 40-year-old woman presented to the outpatient department of our hospital with a 2-year history of abdominal pain, which had worsened in the past few days. There were no other constitutional symptoms; in particular, there was no weight loss or loss of appetite. The serum amylase and serum lipase levels were always within normal limits, even during the current episode. There was no history of pancreatitis, alcohol abuse, drug use, or trauma. The patient was evaluated at an outside clinic 2 years ago and underwent imaging, including US and dedicated pancreatic CT, which revealed a complex multiseptated noncalcified pancreatic cystic lesion. After CT, the patient underwent endoscopic US, which showed the lesion was suspected to be an infected parasitic cyst; fine-needle aspiration and cytology were not attempted due to the risk of iatrogenic rupture. The patient was advised to undergo surgical resection but declined the procedure and was lost to follow-up for 2 years before her current visit to our facility. On clinical examination, there were no clinically important findings, aside from mild to moderate pain on deep palpation and some shifting dullness that was suggestive of ascites. The patient always remained hemodynamically stable. US-guided ascitic fluid analysis was performed, which revealed amylase levels of 869 IU/L (normal range, 4–234 IU/L). Considering prior CT and endoscopic US reports, the patient was further evaluated with a pancreatic MRI protocol for lesion characterization and to explain the new-onset abdominal pain (Figs 1, 2).
findings: Axial T2-weighted images at the level of the pancreatic body revealed a thick-walled (>2 mm) multilocular hyperintense cystic lesion with free fluid in perihepatic and perisplenic locations (Fig 1A). Discontinuity of the wall of the cystic lesion was noted in the anteroinferior aspect, with rupture of the contents into the mesocolon (Fig 1B). Coronal T2-weighted imaging (Fig 1C) revealed similar findings, with rupture along the inferior aspect and spillage of contents in the mesocolon. A coronal T2-weighted thin-slab maximum intensity projection image (Fig 1D) revealed the rupture and showed the main pancreatic duct, with no obvious communication with the lesion. Unenhanced T1-weighted MRI scan (Fig 2A) showed hyperintense septae and wall (Fig 2B). Contrast-enhanced T1-weighted nonsubtracted image showed wall and septal enhancement within the lesion, which was substantiated on subtraction images (Fig 2C, 2D). The septae appeared irregular and mildly nodular at places that were concerning for malignant transformation.
diagnosis: Ruptured Mucinous Cystadenoma of the Pancreas

history: A 38-year-old man who had been in a motor vehicle collision was referred to our institute. He was suspected of having left-sided pneumothorax. This necessitated intercostal drainage with a chest tube, which had been placed elsewhere prior to his arrival. Paraparesis was noted on the initial clinical examination, with adequately maintained vital signs, while the blood work-up revealed a mildly reduced hemoglobin level of 10.1 mg/dL (normal range, 13.8–17.2 mg/dL); however, the rest of the laboratory values were within normal limits (Figs 1–5).
findings: Diffuse pneumocephalus was distributed predominantly along the sulcal spaces of the supratentorial cerebral parenchyma and bilateral frontal convexities. Pneumoventricle was observed with air foci in the frontal horn of the left lateral ventricle and the third ventricle, with multiple air foci in the perimesencephalic cisterns as well. However, no evidence of skull base, calvarial, or paranasal sinus injury was noted (Fig 1A–1C).

(A, B) Diffuse subcutaneous and intermuscular emphysema (orange arrow in A) involving the paratracheal, parapharyngeal, and posterior cervical spaces and paraspinal regions and pneumorrhachis (white arrow in A). (C) Subcutaneous emphysema and pneumorrhachis (arrow) extending along the anterolateral chest wall and neck predominantly on the left side.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.204314/asset/images/large/radiol.204314.fig5.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 5: (A) Anteroposterior chest radiograph obtained on day 1 of admission shows a veil-like opacity in the left hemithorax, with fracture of the posterior aspect of the fifth rib and diffuse subcutaneous emphysema along the left lateral chest wall and neck. (B) Anteroposterior chest radiograph taken on day 12 of admission shows an opaque left hemithorax, with no evidence of volume loss and midline shift suggestive of massive pleural effusion. Arrows indicate increase in pleural effusion over time.'}]]

history: A 21-year-old immunocompetent man who was a long-term resident of Qatar presented to the emergency department with recurrent episodes of unprovoked generalized tonic-clonic seizures lasting 2–3 minutes that spontaneously resolved and were associated with postictal confusion. The patient also had progressive mild diplopia, intermittent dizziness, and numbness in the left arm over the course of 3 months. The patient did not have any other systemic symptoms or chronic medical diseases. He did not have any history of intake of illicit drugs, supplements, or regular medications; he had not received any recent vaccinations; and he had not undergone any surgical procedures. He had no history of travel. At presentation, vital signs were normal. Neurologic examination showed mild left homonymous hemianopia, normal gait with no cerebellar signs, and preserved sensations, power, tone, and reflexes in all four limbs. An electroencephalogram showed no epileptiform discharges.
findings: Initial brain MRI demonstrated T2 fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) hyperintensity in the right parieto-occipital subcortical and periventricular white matter, extending to involve the right side of the splenium of the corpus callosum, with only minimal mass effect and T2 FLAIR tiny iso- and hypointensities within the hyperintense area (Fig 1A, 1B). This area demonstrated a patchy nodular and curvilinear peppering contrast enhancement pattern that was limited to supratentorial structures (Fig 2). The larger enhancing nodules that had low signal intensity on T2 FLAIR images had slightly high signal intensity on diffusion-weighted images with a similar apparent diffusion coefficient (Fig 3A, 3B). Brain perfusion MRI revealed a decrease in perfusion in the area (Fig 3C). Over the next 6 months, the patient’s symptoms improved after appropriate treatment and follow-up, with no relapse of seizures. Follow-up brain MRI was performed (Fig 4).
diagnosis: Supratentorial Lymphocytic Inflammation with Parenchymal Perivascular Enhancement Responsive to Steroids

(B) Coronal (593/8.4) and (C) sagittal (1900/3.6) contrast-enhanced (15 mL of 0.5 mmol/mL gadoterate meglumine, Dotarem; Guerbet) T1-weighted magnetization-prepared rapid gradient-echo images show the peppering pattern of contrast enhancement in the right parieto-occipital region (arrows).'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.204423/asset/images/large/radiol.204423.fig3.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 3: Initial brain MRI scans. history: A 54-year-old man was found by paramedics in his home face-down at his computer desk with a substantially reduced level of consciousness. He had not contacted his family for more than 50 hours. The patient lived alone and was a heavy smoker with a history of alcohol abuse. His medical history was otherwise unremarkable, and there was no history of cancer, psoriasis, or rheumatoid arthritis, nor was there a history of methotrexate administration. On presentation to the emergency department, he was mildly hypotensive and was experiencing hypercapnic respiratory failure and acute renal failure with rhabdomyolysis. His toxicology screen was mildly positive for opiates. He received naloxone (Narcan; Emergent) with minimal effect. An unenhanced CT scan of the head was obtained (Fig 1A). Of note, this patient’s presentation predated the COVID-19 pandemic.

history: In 2017, a 72-year-old woman was seen in the gastroenterology department with a 2-month history of mild and intermittent abdominal pain without other accompanying symptoms. Her medical history was unremarkable, except for a previous visit due to facial photodermatitis 3 years earlier. Diazepam for a sleeping disorder was the only chronic medication recorded. Results of physical examination, blood count, and basic metabolic panels including assessment of renal and liver function were normal; only the ferritin level was slightly elevated (265 ng/mL [595 pmol/L]; normal range, 10–120 ng/mL [22–269 pmol/L]). Abdominal US was performed, followed by multiphasic contrast-enhanced CT and liver MRI due to the findings of the first study. A diagnosis was not established in that moment, and acetaminophen was prescribed for pain relief. As the symptoms continued, laboratory tests and imaging studies were repeated 2 years later, with similar findings and no notable changes (Figs 1–5).
findings: Imaging examinations performed in 2017 and 2019 showed similar findings. Liver US revealed multiple solid and isoechoic nodules with a hyperechoic rim (Figs 1, 2). Some of them had a vessel-penetrating appearance, without mass effect (Fig 2). The lesions ranged in size from 1.6 to 2.9 cm. These nodules were not identified in two multiphasic contrast material–enhanced CT studies of the abdomen (Fig 3). Furthermore, there were no other abnormalities related to the liver structure, density, enhancement, or vascularity. On 1.5-T MRI scans obtained in 2017, no focal lesions were seen on images acquired with T2-weighted, chemical-shift gradient-echo, or diffusion-weighted imaging sequences (Fig 4). In 2019, MRI was repeated (Fig 5) but only with sequences for iron overload study according to the Osatek-SEDIA (Spanish Society of Abdominal Imaging) method (1), showing a normal result (16.2 mmol of iron per gram of liver tissue; normal, <20 mmol of iron per gram of liver tissue). However, slight heterogeneous T2* signal intensity loss in the liver parenchyma was observed.

(C) Axial fat-suppressed T2-weighted MRI scan (1750/90; section thickness, 6 mm). (D) Diffusion-weighted MRI scan (b value = 1000 sec/mm2).\nNo space-occupying lesions were seen.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.204599/asset/images/large/radiol.204599.fig5.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 5: Liver (A) proton density–weighted (repetition time msec/echo time msec, 120/4.2) and (B) T2*-weighted long-echo-time (120/21) MRI scans obtained in 2019 for liver iron quantification according to the Osatek-SEDIA (Spanish Society of Abdominal Imaging) method reveal a hepatic iron concentration of 16.2 mmol of iron per gram of liver tissue. Heterogeneous signal loss is seen (B), with slightly hyperintense areas in the periphery (arrows).'}]]

history: A 27-year-old man was admitted to the emergency department with fever and thoracic pain. In the previous 6 months, the patient lost a substantial amount of weight (12 kg). His family history was negative for cardiac disease. Electrocardiography revealed sinus rhythm, and diffuse T-wave inversion. Two-dimensional echocardiography was performed (Fig 1) and revealed normal left systolic function (ejection fraction, 60%). Laboratory tests showed elevated levels of high-sensitivity cardiac troponin (1.07 ng/mL; normal value, <0.015 ng/mL), high levels of C-reactive protein (16 mg/dL; normal range, 0–5 mg/dL), and leukocytosis with an eosinophilia level of 8710/μL (normal level, <400/μL). Parasitic and infectious diseases (Toxocara canis, strongyloides, filariasis, cysticercosis, fasciola, trichinella, echinococcosis) were excluded based on blood and fecal test results. Corticosteroid therapy was started, and the patient was dismissed.
findings: Two-dimensional transthoracic echocardiography four-chamber end-diastolic (Fig 1A) and end-systolic views showed left ventricle apical thickening (Fig 1B), demonstrating apical myocardial hypertrophy.
images: [[{'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.210452/asset/images/large/radiol.210452.fig1.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 1: Long-axis two-dimensional echocardiograms obtained in (A) diastolic and (B) systolic phases.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.210452/asset/images/large/radiol.210452.fig2.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 2: Axial diffusion-weighted (repetition time msec/echo time msec, 8250/72.4; section thickness, 5 mm; b value, 1000 sec/mm2) MRI scans of the brain at different levels.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.210452/asset/images/large/radiol.210452.fig3.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 3: (A) Unenhanced three-chamber cine steady-state free precession (repetition time msec/echo time msec, 4.5/2; section thickness, 8 mm) cardiac MRI scan. (B) Triple inversion recovery three-chamber (1.66/61.2; section thickness, 8 mm) cardiac MRI scan. (C, D) Short-axis cine steady-state free precession (4.1/1.8; section thickness, 8 mm) contrast-enhanced (gadoterate meglumine [0.4 mL per kilogram of body weight], Dotarem; Guerbet) cardiac MRI scans at the middle and distal levels. (E, F) Gradient-echo inversion recovery (7.6/3.5; section thickness, 8 mm) cardiac MRI scans with late gadolinium enhancement acquired 10 minutes after contrast agent administration.'}], [{'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.210453/asset/images/large/radiol.210453.fig1.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 1: Long-axis two-dimensional echocardiograms obtained in (A) diastolic and (B) systolic phases show left ventricle isoechoic apical thickening.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.210453/asset/images/large/radiol.210453.fig2.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 2: Axial diffusion-weighted (repetition time msec/echo time msec, 8250/72.4; section thickness, 5 mm; b value, 1000 sec/mm2) MRI scans of the brain at different levels show small multiple hyperintense lesions (ischemic subacute) localized in the cortical-subcortical frontal and occipital lobes (arrows).'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.210453/asset/images/large/radiol.210453.fig3.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 3: (A) Unenhanced three-chamber cine steady-state free precession (repetition time msec/echo time msec, 4.5/2; section thickness, 8 mm) cardiac MRI scan shows left ventricle apical obliteration by a thrombus (Th). (B) Triple inversion recovery three-chamber (1.66/61.2; section thickness, 8 mm) cardiac MRI scan shows diffuse endomyocardial hyperintensity, an indicator of active inflammation (arrows). (C, D) Short-axis cine steady-state free precession (4.1/1.8; section thickness, 8 mm) contrast-enhanced (gadoterate meglumine [0.4 mL per kilogram of body weight], Dotarem; Guerbet) cardiac MRI scans at the middle and distal levels distinguish high intensity of endomyocardial thickening to refer to diffuse endocardial hyperemia (#) from endoventricular hypointensity to refer to thrombotic deposition (Th). (E, F) Gradientecho inversion recovery (7.6/3.5; section thickness, 8 mm) cardiac MRI scans with late gadolinium enhancement acquired 10 minutes after contrast agent administration show the V sign of endomyocardial fibrosis at the apex, characterized by a three-layered appearance of dark overlying thrombus (Th), bright fibrotic endomyocardium (arrows), and dark underlying myocardium.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.210453/asset/images/large/radiol.210453.fig4.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 4: Follow-up cardiac MRI was performed at 1-month follow-up. (A) Unenhanced three-chamber cine steady-state free precession image (repetition time msec/echo time msec, 4.5/2; section thickness, 8 mm) shows reduction of left ventricle apical obliteration. (B) Triple inversion recovery four-chamber image (1.66/61.2; section thickness, 8 mm) shows extension reduction of the endomyocardial edema (arrows). (C, D) Postcontrast short-axis cine steady-state free precession images (4.1/1.8; section thickness, 8 mm) show substantial reduction of endomyocardial thickening and hyperemia. (E, F) Gradient-echo inversion recovery late gadolinium enhancement images (7.6/3.5; section thickness, 8 mm) show dimensional reduction of apical thrombus (Th) and extension reduction of endomyocardial fibrosis (arrows).'}]]

history: A 61-year-old woman was admitted to our institution to characterize an incidentally found mass in the porta hepatis. An episode of pulmonary embolism (18 months ago) and a pulmonary abscess (15 months ago) were reported. The patient had no history of known liver disease, previous cancer diagnosis, or trauma. She underwent total thyroidectomy for goiter several years ago, with initial iatrogenic hypothyroidism treated with levo-thyroxine hormone replacement therapy. During follow-up, this therapy was adjusted (50 µg per day) to induce euthyroidism and to achieve a target serum thyroid-stimulating hormone concentration of 1–2 mIU/L. Physical examination findings were unremarkable. Admission laboratory data were entirely normal, including tumor markers, such as carcinoembryonic antigen and carbohydrate antigen 19-9.
findings: Unenhanced multidetector CT images obtained at three different levels showed a 7.5-cm well-defined, lobulated partially hyperattenuating calcified mass in the porta hepatis (Fig 1).
diagnosis: Ectopic Thyroid Goiter in the Porta Hepatis
images: [[{'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.210538/asset/images/large/radiol.210538.fig1.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 1: (A–C) Axial unenhanced CT images obtained at three levels.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.210538/asset/images/large/radiol.210538.fig2.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 2: Axial contrast-enhanced CT images in the (A) arterial, (B) portal venous, and (C) delayed (3 minutes after injection) phases.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.210538/asset/images/large/radiol.210538.fig3.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 3: Axial maximum intensity projection reconstructed CT image in the arterial phase.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.210538/asset/images/large/radiol.210538.fig4.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 4: Coronal maximum intensity projection reconstructed CT image in the portal venous phase.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.210538/asset/images/large/radiol.210538.fig5.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 5: Anterior planar whole-body iodine 131 scintigraphy image.'}], [{'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.210539/asset/images/large/radiol.210539.fig1.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 1: (A–C) Axial unenhanced CT images at three different levels show a well-defined and lobulated mass in the porta hepatis. This mass appears partially hyperattenuated (arrows) with calcifications (arrowhead).'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.210539/asset/images/large/radiol.210539.fig2.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 2: (A–C) Axial contrast-enhanced CT images show the mass (arrow) had strong enhancement in the arterial phase (A), followed by inhomogenous enhancement with cystic components in the portal venous phase (B) and 3 minutes after injection (C).'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.210539/asset/images/large/radiol.210539.fig3.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 3: Axial maximum intensity projection CT reconstruction in the arterial phase shows how the mass is indissociable from the hepatic artery (arrow).'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.210539/asset/images/large/radiol.210539.fig4.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 4: Coronal maximum intensity projection CT reconstruction in the portal venous phase shows the mass is indissociable from the main portal vein (arrow).'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.210539/asset/images/large/radiol.210539.fig5.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 5: Anterior planar whole-body iodine 131 scintigraphy image shows biodistribution of radioiodine in the hepatic hilum mass (arrow), normal thyroid bed (arrowhead), and bladder (circle).'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.210539/asset/images/large/radiol.210539.fig6.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 6: (A) Cytohistologic examination shows ectopic thyroid tissue characterized by follicular cells and colloid (arrows), mixed with scant benign gastrointestinal mucosa and cyst contents comprised of macrophages. (Hematoxylin-eosin staining; original magnification, ×10.) (B) Immunostaining shows that the follicular cells are positive for thyroid transcription factor-1. (Original magnification, ×20.)'}]]

history: A 45-year-old woman presented to the emergency department with acute worsening of prolonged unexplained nausea, nonbilious vomiting, and mild upper abdominal pain of 4 years duration. Her bowel habits were regular, and there was no history of diarrhea or fresh or altered blood in her stool. On further inquiry, there was no history of facial flushing, excessive diaphoresis, or asthmalike symptoms. Her history was unrevealing; in particular, there was no history of known malignancy. On clinical examination, her vital signs were stable. The abdomen was soft, with no focal tenderness or palpable mass.
findings: Contrast-enhanced multidetector CT of the abdomen and pelvis revealed an enhancing 2.5 × 2.8 × 1.7 cm soft-tissue nodule in the jejunal mesentery, inseparable from the jejunal serosa (Fig 1). There was no definite intraluminal or mural component within the jejunum. The nodule had a microlobulated outline (Fig 1C, 1D). Although it was anatomically distinct from the orthotopic pancreas, its morphology and enhancement pattern closely followed those of normal pancreatic tissue (Fig 1C). This finding was not accompanied by adjacent lymph node enlargement, mesenteric fat stranding, calcification, or desmoplastic reaction. On the basis of the CT findings, the main diagnostic considerations were carcinoid tumor, gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST), peritoneal carcinomatosis or metastasis, and heterotopic pancreatic tissue.
images: [[{'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.210250/asset/images/large/radiol.210250.fig1.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 1: (A) Axial, (B) coronal, and (C) sagittal contrast-enhanced CT scans of the abdomen and pelvis.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.210250/asset/images/large/radiol.210250.fig2.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 2: Anterior and posterior whole-body planar indium 111 octreotide scans obtained 4 hours after injection.'}], [{'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.210251/asset/images/large/radiol.210251.fig1.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 1: (A) Axial contrast-enhanced abdominal multidetector CT image shows a bilobular enhancing soft-tissue nodule (arrows) in the jejunal mesentery, inseparable from the jejunal serosa. There is no clinically relevant fat stranding or desmoplastic reaction around the lesion. (B) Coronal contrast-enhanced CT image shows the enhancing soft-tissue nodule (arrow) in the jejunal mesentery, with a more readily apparent microlobulated appearance. (C) Sagittal contrast-enhanced CT image shows the enhancing soft-tissue nodule (arrow) in the jejunal mesentery, with a more readily apparent microlobulated appearance. Although the nodule is anatomically separate from the main gland (arrowheads), its microlobulated morphology and enhancement pattern follow those of normal pancreatic tissue. (D) Axial contrast-enhanced CT images show the microlobulated appearance of the enhancing soft-tissue nodule in the jejunal mesentery (white arrows), anatomically separate from the orthotopic pancreas (arrowheads) but closely mimicking its morphology and enhancement pattern. The microlobulated morphology and enhancement pattern of the soft-tissue nodule are different from the smooth contour and enhancement of the spleen (black arrows).'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.210251/asset/images/large/radiol.210251.fig2.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 2: Anterior and posterior whole-body planar indium 111 octreotide scans obtained 4 hours after injection do not show abnormal radiotracer uptake or scintigraphic evidence of a somatostatin-avid tumor in the left upper quadrant corresponding to the location of the nodule in the jejunal mesentery.'}]]

history: An 11-year-old girl presented to the pediatric gastroenterology outpatient department of our institution with gradually increasing painless abdominal distention. The distention started 2 years earlier and was not associated with any other constitutional symptoms, vomiting, diarrhea, jaundice, hematemesis, or melaena. She reported early satiety and heaviness in the lower abdomen. The abdominal swelling was predominantly in the infraumbilical region and was soft at palpation. She was the first child of nonconsanguineous parents and had an uneventful perinatal course after a normal vaginal delivery. Her developmental milestones were normal. She had an average scholastic performance at school. There was no history of visual problems, seizures, or inappropriate behaviors. She had an early menarche 2 years previously. Her menstrual cycles were regular, and there was no abnormal vaginal discharge. Her breast development was normal (Tanner stage III), while pubic and axillary hair were absent (Tanner stage I). She was short for her age (104 cm; normal range, 120–154 cm). There was no history of short stature among her siblings or parents.
findings: Pelvic US (Fig 1) revealed bilateral enlarged ovaries with multiple clear anechoic cysts. The cysts did not show any echogenic debris, solid component, or calcification. Contrast-enhanced CT (Fig 2A, 2B) of the pelvis enabled us to confirm the US findings. The uterus had a normal pubertal appearance. A radiograph of the hand (Fig 3A) showed delayed bone age (2.5 years with the Tanner-Whitehouse 2 method) and mild metaphyseal irregularity involving the lower ulna. A radiograph of the pelvis (Fig 3B) showed a delayed appearance of epiphyses around the hip joints. Mild metaphyseal irregularity was noted at the end of long bones as well. Although the pelvic US findings were suggestive of precocious puberty, the skeletal changes were consistent with hypothyroidism.
images: [[{'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.211118/asset/images/large/radiol.211118.fig1.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 1: Left and right parasaggital gray-scale US images of the pelvis.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.211118/asset/images/large/radiol.211118.fig2.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 2: Axial contrast-enhanced CT images of the pelvis obtained after intravenous injection of 50 mL of nonionic iodinated contrast material at (A) the level of pelvic brim and (B) 1 cm caudal to it.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.211118/asset/images/large/radiol.211118.fig3.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 3: Radiographs of the (A) left hand and (B) pelvis and bilateral thigh.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.211118/asset/images/large/radiol.211118.fig4.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 4: Sequential axial gray-scale US images of the neck.'}], [{'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.211119/asset/images/large/radiol.211119.fig1.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 1: Left and right parasaggital gray-scale US images of the pelvis show enlarged bilateral ovaries (visible on both images) with multiple cystic lesions having thin internal septations (arrows). There is no solid component, echogenic debris, nondependent echogenic foci, or calcification.'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.211119/asset/images/large/radiol.211119.fig2.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 2: Axial contrast-enhanced CT images of the pelvis obtained after intravenous injection of 50 mL of nonionic iodinated contrast material. (A) Image at the level of the pelvic brim shows the entire pelvis occupied by a cystic lesion with thin enhancing septae (arrows). No fat, calcification, or enhancing solid components are seen. (B) A section 1 cm caudal to that in A shows cystic lesions arranged on both sides of the uterus, implying bilateral ovarian cysts. Cysts (Cy) show thin internal septations. The uterus is in the middle of this image and shows a pubertal appearance. Anteroposterior diameter is increased, giving rise to a more globular shape. Note the well-depicted endometrial lining (E).'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.211119/asset/images/large/radiol.211119.fig3.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 3: (A) Radiograph of the left hand obtained to assess bone age shows ossification centers of three carpal bones. The base of the first metacarpal has faintly appeared. The distal ulnar epiphysis has not yet appeared. Bone age was assessed with the Tanner-Whitehouse 2 method and is delayed (2.5 years). Note the metaphyseal irregularity of the distal ulna (arrow). (B) Radiograph of the pelvis and bilateral hips shows delayed maturation of ossification centers around the hip joint. The femoral capital epiphyses are small for the patient’s age bilaterally, and the greater trochanters (wide arrows) have not yet appeared (normal age of appearance, 4 years). Note mild metaphyseal sclerosis and irregularity (thin arrows).'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.211119/asset/images/large/radiol.211119.fig4.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 4: Sequential transverse US images of the neck show absence of the thyroid gland anterior to the airway (A). Arrows indicate the space where echogenic thyroid lobes are normally seen. Strap muscles (SM) are opposed to the airway wall, owing to absence of the thyroid gland. C = common carotid artery, Eso = esophagus.'}]]

history: A 64-year-old man presented with a 6-month history of lightheadedness, intermittent balance, and coordination difficulties. Two months before admission, symptoms became more substantial and persistent, with a worsening sense of disequilibrium and unsteady gait. He reported difficulties pronouncing words and mild word-finding difficulties. His wife noted a change in his cognition and memory over the same time. His medical history included well-controlled chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) secondary to a long history of smoking with associated unintentional 30-lb (13.6-kg) weight loss over the previous 3 years, for which chest CT scanning was performed, revealing no abnormality.
findings: A T2-weighted fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) MRI examination of the brain at admission showed hyperintensity in the left frontoparietal corona radiata and centrum semiovale (Fig 1A, 1B), with facilitated diffusion (Fig 1C, 1D). Susceptibility-weighted imaging showed bilateral deep medullary veins had a normal appearance (Fig 2A). A T1-weighted three-dimensional volumetric interpolated breath-hold gadolinium-enhanced examination showed a subtle punctate and linear enhancement pattern extending from the periventricular region toward the centrum semiovale in the left frontoparietal region (Fig 2B, 2C). Perfusion imaging of the brain revealed unremarkable findings (Fig 3A, 3B). MR spectroscopy (MRS) performed at the left centrum semiovale revealed an abnormal increase in the choline peak and a slightly decreased N-acetylaspartate peak (Fig 3C).
diagnosis: Autoimmune Glial Fibrillary Acidic Protein Astrocytopathy
images: [[{'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.211953/asset/images/large/radiol.211953.fig1.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 1: MRI scans at the level of the centrum semiovale. There is confluent increased T2 and FLAIR signal intensity in the left frontoparietal region (dashed circle in A), with facilitated diffusion on the ADC map (dashed circle in D).'}, {'img': 'https://pubs.rsna.org/cms/10.1148/radiol.211954/asset/images/large/radiol.211954.fig2.jpeg', 'caption': 'Figure 2: (A) Axial susceptibility-weighted image (SWI) (repetition time msec/echo time msec 28/20; 1.5-mm section thickness) and (B) axial and (C) sagittal three-dimensional volumetric interpolated breath-hold examination images (8/3; 1-mm section thickness) after intravenous administration of a gadolinium-containing contrast agent (0.1 mmol per kilogram of body weight gadobutrol [Gadovist 1.0; Bayer Schering Pharma]) at the level of the centrum semiovale. history: A 49-year-old man presented with right foot drop, bilateral cruralgia mainly on the left side, and genital and perianal hypoesthesia, which started suddenly 12 days before.
findings: Basal CT of the lumbosacral spine revealed a gross asymmetric bulging L2-3 disk without focal structural bone alterations to the vertebral body or posterior arches (Fig 1). Multiplanar MRI revealed a large ovoid lesion with sharp edges in the posterolateral epidural space at L2-3 that was inhomogeneous on T2-weighted MRI scans, hypointense on T1-weighted MRI scans, and had intense peripheral enhancement after contrast medium administration (Figs 2, 3), indicative of a migrated and sequestrated disk. The paraspinal soft tissue and bones had normal signal intensity (Figs 2, 3). Axial contrast-enhanced images show a clear pathway of the nucleus pulposus from the disk to the posterolateral epidural space (Fig 3A).
diagnosis: Posterior Epidural Migration of a Lumbar Disk Herniation

history: A 14-year-old boy presented with asthenia, low back pain, and abdominal distention. The onset of symptoms was slow and progressive over a few months. The patient had no contributing past medical history. At physical examination, all vital signs were normal. Only pallor and positive fluid wave test results were noted; there was no lower limb edema, mucocutaneous lesions, or palpable lymph node enlargement. Laboratory work-up revealed a decreased hemoglobin concentration of 9.3 g/dL (normal range, 12–16 g/dL) and a decreased hematocrit level of 29.8% (normal range, 37%–45%), but all other laboratory values were normal. Contrast-enhanced CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis was performed (Figs 1–3).
findings: Contrast-enhanced CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis showed a well-defined cystic mass occupying the anterior and posterior mediastinum (Fig 1). Ascites and numerous small splenic and pancreatic cystic lesions were found in the abdomen (Fig 2). In the evaluation of the images with bone window settings, multiple osteolytic lesions within the medullary bone and without cortical bone destruction were revealed in the ribs, vertebral bodies, scapula, and pelvis (Fig 3).
